Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RF7-GHN1-JC6P-C2PS-00000-00Thune asks whether big tech is doing enough to combat the spread of extremist propaganda2018-01-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSThune asks whether big tech is doing enough to combat the spread of extremist propagandaEvan HendershotThe Daily Republic, Mitchell, S.D.

Jan. 17--In an effort to contain the spread of extremist propaganda across the web, South Dakota's longest tenured member of Congress had one key question to ask: Is big tech doing enough?

U.S. Sen. John Thune chaired a hearing of the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation on Wednesday about the relationship of terrorism and social media. And while he acknowledged social media can play a positive role in society, he was slightly pointed in his opening remarks.

"These services have thrived online because of the freedom made possible by the uniquely American guarantee of free speech, and by a light touch regulatory policy," Thune said. "But, as is so often the case, enemies of our way of life have sought to take advantage of our freedoms to advance hateful causes. Violent Islamic terrorist groups, like ISIS, have been particularly aggressive in seeking to radicalize and recruit over the internet and various social media platforms."

Thune, a Republican, questioned witnesses from Twitter, YouTube and Facebook on how they are working to identify and remove extremist content. But he also noted the contributions the same social media outlets have made.

"The positive contributions of social media platforms are well documented," Thune said. "YouTube, Facebook and Twitter, among others, help to connect people around the world, give voice to those oppressed by totalitarian regimes and provide a forum for discussions of every political, social, scientific and cultural stripe."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WKN-30G1-JCJY-G155-00000-00Thursday briefing: 'Ark did not take so long,' Churchill chafed;Archives reveal candid views of PMs and officials ... Corbyn sacks minister for 'Hitler bunker' jibe ... and sender of message in a bottle from 1969 is found2019-07-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisWORLD NEWSVersion:1Thursday briefing: 'Ark did not take so long,' Churchill chafedArchives reveal candid views of PMs and officials ... Corbyn sacks minister for 'Hitler bunker' jibe ... and sender of message in a bottle from 1969 is foundWarren Murray

Top story: 'Troops should not be called in'

Hello, I'm Warren Murray presenting the front page of your day.

Boris Yeltsin was looking "puffy around the neck and jaw" but at least "stayed off the vodka" after getting a chest infection. He got "v pissed off" after a phone call with Bill Clinton was botched by officials. The latter, as US president, was known for "talking loudly, then failing to act" while first lady Hillary Clinton was "highly intelligent and very highly motivated". These and other appraisals of foreign leaders are revealed in newly unlocked government papers from the National Archives that show colourful pen portraits were, as Caroline Davies writes, "a staple of the diplomatic cable long before the leaking of the former US ambassador Kim Darroch's emails".

The files show postwar prime ministers were irked by the length of time and rising costs of refurbishing Downing Street - a survey under Churchill in 1954 discovered dry rot and beetle damage, with risk of Nos 10, 11 and 12 partially collapsing. Churchill wrote: "I am shocked that the Ministry of Works contemplates two or three years. The Ark did not take so long." John Major enthusiastically supported   Manchester's bid for the 2000 Olympics, but ministers and officials were less convinced - the city ended up losing to Sydney. And in 1967 when anti-nuclear protesters threatened to expose the official purpose of "Turnstile" - a vast underground complex in Wiltshire meant to house central government in wartime - the "D-notice" committee of the Ministry of Defence stepped in to steer press coverage away. Official instructions stated that "unless the situation developed very abnormally, troops should not be called in".

* * *

'Hitler in the bunker' - The Labour peer Dianne Hayter has been sacked as shadow Brexit ­minister after she likened the "bunker mentality" around Jeremy Corbyn's leadership to the "last days of Hitler". Hayter remains the party's deputy leader in the Lords because it is an elected position. At a meeting of the centre-left Labour First group on Tuesday she attacked the Labour leadership over its response to antisemitism complaints. "Those of you who haven't [read the book] will have watched the film ­Bunker, about the last days of ­Hitler, of how you stop receiving into the inner group any information which suggests that things are not going the way you want." The Ilford North Labour MP, Wes Streeting, said Hayter's sacking was a "gross over-reaction ... The speed of this sacking shows that Labour's leader is quick to act to protect his feelings, but slow to act against racists. The double standards are extraordinary."

* * *

Trump escalates racial taunts - A crowd chanted "Send her back! Send her back!" about Ilhan Omar - the congresswoman who arrived in the US as a Somalian child refugee - in ugly scenes at one of the president's rallies last night.

The House of Representatives earlier voted down an attempt to impeach the president, after a motion was brought forward blasting Trump for bringing "disgrace" on the office with his racist remarks aimed at four congresswomen of colour. Democrats followed the lead of the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, who said multiple investigations into the president, his associates and their activities should be allowed to play out.

* * *

Sun holiday shame - British tourists' responsibility for foul beaches, overcrowding, traffic, aeroplane emissions and other environmental impacts will come under parliamentary scrutiny. The Commons environmental audit committee says global tourism is responsible for 5% of greenhouse gas emissions, while cheaper flights and zero tax on aviation fuel mean the holiday business has grown rapidly to account for more than 10% of global GDP. The committee will report back on ways to reduce impacts by using incentives, taxation, offsets and greater scrutiny of travel companies' claims of sustainability.

* * *

Spacey case over - Prosecutors have dropped charges against the actor Kevin Spacey of groping a young man at a Massachusetts resort island bar in 2016. The accuser had refused to testify about a missing cellphone that the defence says contains text messages supporting the actor's claims of innocence. The man accusing Spacey has also dropped a civil lawsuit he had just recently filed against the actor that sought damages for "severe and permanent mental distress and emotional injuries".

* * *

Sea mail - The British author of a 50-year-old message in a bottle that washed up on the South Australian coast has been found. On 17 November 1969, Paul Gilmore was a 13-year-old English boy travelling on Sitmar Line's ship the Fairstar, which brought many British migrants to Australia during the 1960s. South Australian man Paul Elliot and his son Jyah told Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio they found the bottle on the Eyre Peninsula's west coast recently while fishing. On Thursday the ABC reported that it had tracked down Gilmore's sister, Annie Crossland, who said Paul would be "chuffed to bits". His current location: out at sea, on a cruise in the Baltic. "The last time he was on a ship was probably going to Australia. Cruises aren't his thing," she said.

* * *

Hydration stations - Locations for the first 50 of London's new public water fountains have been announced. They are being installed from this week, predominantly in tube and mainline train stations, shopping centres, markets and recreation grounds. The fountains are attached to the mains water supply and feature a distinctive design with a giant blue "waterdrop" to make them easy to spot. From Abbey Wood Station to Worship Square in Hackney, here is where to find them.

Today in Focus podcast: Has Brexit saved the Lib Dems?

The anti-Brexit stance of the Liberal Democrats has seen them make an extraordinary comeback in 2019. The Observer's political editor, Toby Helm, discusses whether the party are here to stay. And: Oliver Wainwright on the inclusion of social housing in this year's Stirling prize.

Lunchtime read: Vanished neighbourhoods

In Prague the centuries-old Jewish quarter of Josefov was demolished using dynamite in 1896 - with the exception of few religious sites, the entire neighbourhood was destroyed. Black Bottom in Detroit was a vibrant community where John Lee Hooker, Della Reese and others played the clubs of Hastings Street until it was destroyed and replaced by the Chrysler Freeway.

A visitor to Shanghai in the late 19th century would have found the city dominated by narrow, winding lanes of shikumen, the equivalent of Britain's Victorian terraced workers' housing - today, as the city struggles to house its 26.3 million residents, many old neighbourhoods are being targeted. Guardian Cities chronicles how some of the world's most fascinating neighbourhoods have been razed by regeneration.

Sport

The Open gets under way today and, after a 68-year wait, Royal Portrush has the potential to prove one of the tournament's more exciting backdrops. Rory McIlroy   returns to his childhood course but has been keen to emphasise the wider context of a major being played in Northern Ireland. Meanwhile, the R&A has refused to condemn a "   celebration of marching bands " which is staging   a three-hour show on Saturday before marching to an Orange hall. Chris Froome has officially been named as   the winner of the 2011 Vuelta a España following a doping case involving Juan José Cobo, who originally finished in first place.

Formula One has revealed details on its proposed plans to improve the racing with new regulations for 2021 that are set to be officially confirmed in October.   England beat Trinidad and Tobago 72-46 in Liverpool and play South Africa next with a place in the Netball World Cup semi-finals already secured. And the Women's Ashes Test begins at Taunton today, with England needing victory to keep alive their hopes in the series, as Australia bowler Megan Schutt calls for red-ball cricket to become   more regular and widespread in the women's game.

Business

The pound could fall to parity with the US dollar in the event of a no-deal Brexit, investment bank Morgan Stanley has warned. With sterling sitting at $1.243 today, the bank's experts said it could drift lower to levels last seen in the 1980s as uncertainty continues to cloud British politics. A lack of clarity about US-China trade talks is dogging global stock markets with Asian shares falling broadly overnight. South Korea's central bank highlighted the alarm about shrinking demand for the country's export industries when it cut rates by 0.25% in the hope of stimulating the economy. The FTSE100 is seen falling 0.26% later this morning.

The papers

Only two papers have the same lead today with the Mirror and the Metro going with the brother of Manchester bomber Salman Abedi being extradited to Britain. The headlines say "Bomber bro flown to UK to face justice" and "Back to face British justice".

The Times and the Telegraph both agree that Boris Johnson brandishing a packet of kippers in a speech is the best picture (both caption it "Fishing for votes") but diverge on the top story. The former splashes with "Young drivers face night ban" and the latter says "Elderly face visit from TV licence fee police".

The Guardian leads with Theresa May's final speech as PM - "May swipes at 'rancour and hatred' of Brexit absolutists" - while the Express has "Boris: We need to get Brexit done by October 31". The FT's lead is "Vestager's parting shot at big tech aims for Amazon and Qualcomm", Mail has "Scandal of care bills divide" and the Sun leads with a story about an airline passenger billed £85,000 for trying to storm the cockpit in an alleged air rage incident. "Jumbo debt" the headline reads.

Sign up

The Guardian Morning Briefing is delivered to thousands of inboxes bright and early every weekday. If you are not already receiving it by email, you can sign up here.

For more news: www.theguardian.com

urn:contentItem:5Y7X-XGS1-F021-634N-00000-00Thursday briefing: Elizabeth Warren rips into Bloomberg;Most brutal Democratic debate yet ... 11 dead after Germany shisha bar attacks ... two Diamond Princess passengers die of Covid-192020-02-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisWORLD NEWSVersion:2Thursday briefing: Elizabeth Warren rips into BloombergMost brutal Democratic debate yet ... 11 dead after Germany shisha bar attacks ... two Diamond Princess passengers die of Covid-19Warren Murray

Top story: Mogul attacked over women, policing

Good morning - Warren Murray with you after a dramatic night in the news.

Michael Bloomberg has been fiercely attacked at his first Democratic debate appearance for being an architect of racist policing policies, indulging in sexist comments and silencing aggrieved female employees. Elizabeth Warren led the assault   on a disastrous night for the former New York mayor and multi-billionaire.

Bloomberg stumbled in his response to a series of questions about stop-and-frisk in New York, saying he was "embarrassed" by the racially charged tactic and had apologised. Warren also challenged Bloomberg to release women at his company from non-disclosure agreements they signed while settling lawsuits.

Bloomberg defended his record on women: "In my company, lots and lots of women have big responsibilities." Warren countered: "I hope you heard what his defence was: 'I've been nice to some women.'"

The debate at the Paris Theater in Las Vegas came one week after Sanders won the New Hampshire primary and ahead of a primary in Nevada in which Bloomberg is not competing. Here are five key takeaways as observed by our Guardian US team.

* * *

11 die in Germany shootings - At least 11 people have been killed and several others seriously injured after shooting   s at two shisha bars in the German town of Hanau, 25km east of Frankfurt, according to local police. Nine people died in the attacks on the two bars at around 10pm on Wednesday, police said. A hunt was launched for the perpetrators and police said at around 5am local time that officers had stormed the home of the alleged suspect where they found him dead along with another body. Police said they had no confirmed information on the background of the two attacks and appealed for witnesses to come forward. Hanau's MP, Katja Leikert, called it a "horrific scenario" while the Hanau mayor, Claus Kaminsky, lamented the "worst evening imaginable". It comes a few days after one person was shot dead and four more were injured outside a Berlin music venue that was hosting a Turkish comedy show.

* * *

Coronavirus cruise deaths - Two older Japanesepassengers from the Diamond Princess cruise ship have died of the Covid-19 virus, according to reports. An evacuation flight of Britons from the ship is now expected to depart Japan on Friday. The death toll in China stands at more than 2,100. Experts worldwide have signed a statement of support for their Chinese colleagues who are being attacked on social media and threatened with violence as false rumours circulate about the origins of the virus. There are warnings that the haranguing   could destroy   cooperation between Chinese scientists and their western counterparts to find treatments and vaccines. You can   follow all   the latest developments on our live blog.

* * *

Men who kill women - More than half the women killed by men in the UK in 2018 died at the hands of a current or former partner, according to the fourth Femicide Census. In half of the cases, perpetrators had previous histories of violence against women, with three found to have killed before. The census says 149 women were killed by 147 men in 2018, 10 more than the previous year and the highest number since the census began. Of the victims, 91 (61%) were killed by a current or former partner. There were also cases of women being killed by a son, stepson, son-in-law or former son-in-law. Only 6% were killed by a stranger. Karen Ingala Smith, from domestic violence charity Nia, said many died despite expressing their fear to police, other services, and friends and family, and that they had few options to find help due to under-resourcing of crisis services. Julie Bindel writes today: "As a feminist campaigner, I am often asked why women are still targeted by male rage. Our successes have been significant ... but   why has this not led to fewer women dying? "

* * *

'High-risk' Huawei barred - Huawei has been excluded from participating in £65m worth of pilot 5G projects for businesses and communities. They include a flood warning scheme in Yorkshire, a coastal search and rescue experiment in Dorset and an electric vehicle project involving Ford and Vodafone. "None of the winning projects, or future projects, will use equipment from high risk vendors," the Department of Digital, Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) said. In January the government announced limits on the use of the Chinese supplier's equipment in the 5G networks being rolled out across the UK.

* * *

'Prevent has got to go' - Rebecca Long-Bailey would commit Labour to scrapping the anti-extremism programme Prevent if elected party leader. The candidate said: "The Prevent programme has alienated the Muslim community, set back our freedoms and not made us safer. The evidence is clear: it's got to go." Long-Bailey said she would replace it with a government-funded system involving Muslim leaders. Labour members will be balloted in the party leadership contest from Friday.

* * *

Worthy of note - The new polymer £20 note featuring the artist JMW Turner is to go into circulation as the Bank of England begins replacing the most popular banknote in the country. At least two billion notes have been printed and half of the country's cash machines should have switched over within the next fortnight.

In Scotland, the Bank of Scotland and Clydesdale Bank will launch their polymer £20 notes on 27 February, with the Royal Bank of Scotland following on 5 March. Banks in Northern Ireland will also change over in 2020 but no date has been specified.

Today in Focus podcast: Flooded Britain - a new normal?

A series of storms have lashed Britain in the past two weeks resulting in widespread floods that have left residents and businesses devastated. But as the climate heats up and towns expand into floodplains, we ask is this the new normal? Also today: Richard Partington on the government's plans for Britain's new immigration rules.

Lunchtime read: Modi's way tearing India apart

For seven decades, India has been held together by its constitution, which promises equality to all. But Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata party is remaking the nation into one where some people count as more Indian than others, writes Samanth Subramanian.

Sport

José Mourinho refused to write off Tottenham's hope of reaching the Champions League quarter-finals after   their defeat by RB Leipzig, insisting that his team's spirit will give them a chance of overcoming their selection crisis in attack. Pep Guardiola said after   Manchester City's 2-0 win over West Ham that he was confident in the club's ability   to defend its position following alleged breaches of Uefa's financial fair play regulations.

Deontay Wilder controversially taunted his rival Tyson Fury about his mental health battles in a fiery press conference in readiness for Saturday's   WBC heavyweight title rematch. Kim Clijsters tasted defeat after her latest tennis comeback but the former women's world No 1 has found   returning to training transformative. Formula One team McLaren are   adhering to a strict policy in an attempt to safeguard their personnel from the coronavirus. Jemma Reekie's extraordinary start to the season continued with yet another victory -   this time over 800m against the reigning world champion Halimah Nakaayi in Lievin, France. And Rory McIlroy has delivered what may well prove to be a   fatal blow to plans for a breakaway golf tour by stating he has no interest in taking part.

Business

The world-renowned Axminster Carpets has gone into administration. The Devon-based company has provided carpets for prestigious buildings such as the US Capitol in Washington but has collapsed with the possible loss of 80 jobs. The FTSE100 is set to dip 0.25% at the opening this morning. The pound is on $1.29 and (EURO)1.196.

The papers

The Guardian moves the flooding coverage along to new homes and the fact that since 2003, one in 10 has been built on "land at high risk of floods". It potentially leaves tens of thousands of people in greater danger from extreme winter storms - one expert, Prof Robert Wilby, of the University of Loughborough, argues the government should review its housebuilding target: "We're compounding the existing risk by continuing to build on the floodplain." In the Mirror it's "Heroes and a zero" as the paper contrasts a flood rescuer's feat with Boris Johnson's failure to visit affected areas.

Others stay with the Conservatives' border control plans. "Immigration backlash over British carers" says the i - at issue is Priti Patel's claim that we have an untapped workforce of 8.5 million - when most of those are actually carers, students, sick or retired. The Metro repeats Patel's claim that "8m Brits can fill low-skill jobs gap" though its subheading points out that most of them actually can't. The secretary of state also comes under fire in the Times : "Home Office at war after staff accuse 'bully' Patel" saying she is at war with her own permanent secretary.

The Mail celebrates "House prices surging all over Britain" (a shame if you're trying to buy one) and claims it as evidence of a "Boris bounce". "Ofsted fears schools will 'squander' extra cash" - that's the Telegraph, covering the not-new-to-controversy chief inspector, Amanda Spielman, saying school budgeting procedures should be tightened up before they share in a £14bn funding boost. The Express joins the "Battle for new wonder drug to save lives" - it's called Tritafka and holds promise in treating cystic fibrosis. The FT has what sounds like a good idea: "EU aims to loosen big tech's grip by forcing groups to share data" - the likes of Amazon and Google that enjoy near-monopolies would have to open up their databases to smaller competitors.

Sign up

The Guardian Morning Briefing is delivered to thousands of inboxes bright and early every weekday. If you are not already receiving it by email, you can sign up here.

For more news: www.theguardian.com

urn:contentItem:5Y79-3331-JDVW-N253-00000-00Thursday Express: Hedge fund shutting; new digital money rules coming2020-02-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:50ZLexisNexisExclusiveThursday Express: Hedge fund shutting; new digital money rules comingMaricor Zapata

Also, JPMorgan faces a class lawsuit over racial discrimination; and JPMorgan shareholder activist groups get notices from the company over skipping their proxy proposals.

* Amid struggles in the hedge fund industry, former Citigroup head of currencies, Anil Prasad, is shutting Silver Ridge Asset Management, which he set up upon leaving Citigroup in 2014, Financial Times reports.

* In its biggest deal so far, Heartland Financial's planned purchase of Levelland, Texas-based AIM Bancshares tends to tilt the Dubuque, Iowa-based company to the west, but Executive Chairman Lynn Fuller said Heartland Financial is aiming for a rough geographic balance with its acquisition-fueled growth strategy.

* Fidelity National Information Services is also expected to release its financial results for the most recent quarter today.

* As the U.S. House Financial Services Committee released a report showing lack of workforce diversity at America's largest banks, lawmakers are now considering a suite of bills that would require banks to disclose the diversity makeup of their staff and consider investing in minority- or women-owned asset managers.

* JPMorgan faces a new class lawsuit in New Orleans federal court for alleged discriminatory practices against its black personal bankers, giving them lower pay, reduced chances for advancement and assignments in less performing branches, where they also risk physical harm.

* Shareholder activist groups focused on climate issues at JPMorgan said they had all received notification from the company that it will seek to omit their proposals from its 2020 proxy.

* Regulators' efforts to update the Community Reinvestment Act are an "ongoing process," Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell told the Senate Banking Committee Feb. 12, saying he is so far at ease with the Fed's stance, which is to further learn from the public comments on the other agencies' proposals.

* The Federal Reserve plans to deliver FedNow, the central bank's own real-time payment system, to the market in stages, initially in 2023 and 2024 with incremental refinements to come in the future, American Banker reports, citing Boston Fed Vice President Kenneth Montgomery, who is overseeing the project.

* Wells Fargo will no longer be requiring arbitration for employees involved in any future sexual harassment claims.

* A New Jersey jury has ordered PNC Financial Services to pay a former employee, Damara Scott, $2.4 million for allegedly failing to protect her from being sexually harassed by a client, Patrick Pignatello, American Banker reports. Pignatello, however, reportedly died shortly after the suit was filed in 2013, before the case could be brought to trial.

* Goldman Sachs is racing with big tech companies like Amazon, Microsoft, Google and Facebook on hiring technical staff, boasting 10,000 developers that now make up about a quarter of the investment bank's total workforce, CNBC reports, citing an interview with George Lee, the bank's co-chief information officer.

* Goldman Sachs is lining up Prince Harry as a guest speaker in its online interview series "Talks at GS," someone with knowledge of the matter told CNBC.

* Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin told a Senate Finance Committee hearing Feb. 12 that the U.S. will soon announce new rules on cryptocurrency and digital payment systems to improve transparency and to keep digital money from being used as "secret bank accounts," Bloomberg News reports.

* On the insurance front, Arch Capital Group executives have seen strengthening in pricing conditions in the property and casualty market but believe it has not yet become a hard market.

The Daily Dose: Express Edition is updated as of 6:30 a.m. ET. Some external links may require a subscription. Links are current as of publication time, and we are not responsible if those links are unavailable later.

Highlights of Thursday's proceedings in Parliament.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

isn't it now the time and in the public interest and the national interests to have a Robert Mueller style enquiry into the conduct of the EU Referendum that also examines the role played by the Russian state. He raises very serious issues and there is no doubt that the law as it stands has been up dated. The ICO have much increased powers and it will be encouraged to use them and there is no doubt that these serious matters concerning the European Referendum will be investigated but it is not a matter for my department. Tom Watson later took up his case for social media giants to be more accountable.

The problem seems to be that the government as a whole is either unwilling or unable to deal with the market dominance of the big tech giants. On this side of the house, we believe these companies are running rings around governments, legislators and regulators and the reasonably for example than Mark Zuckerberg refusing to appear before the Select Committee. Even Rupert Murdoch did that. Is it time now right for a new single, powerful regulator to take on the big tech giants and redress this imbalance of market power? The other aspect of this that was not mentioned is the range of on line hubs where we can expect more assistance. There are a range of areas we need to think about this. The tech economy has changed dramatically and the tech companies power has changed dramatically. Whatever actions of this government and this country takes me to be thought through. They will be substantially attacked and secondly, I hope they will be an example to the world on how to do this and it will only be so if we thought through them properly, it designed carefully so they can be robust under scrutiny. Jeremy Wright. Ministers have been told to come up with creative alternatives to London's night crime epidemic including banning offences from social media. -- offenders. Police have been logged nearly 1300 knife attacks. The MP Sarah Jones said harsher sentences were not working. 40% in 2010 to almost 70% today and get into the last five years knife crime has been on shocking increase suggesting that harsher sentences simply are not the answer. Can we look at two things that creative alternatives to prison, such as banning young people from social media is easing to incite violence and secondly education and rehabilitation to keep young people out of the prison system. I know the honourable lady has a key interest in the issue. I do not think there is a direct correlation. We have seen a rise in knife crimes and it is right that we have approached the issue of possession more seriously but I take on board the point about causation. I deeply impressed with work being done with young people and it is intervention in an early stage which can help. I know the government have been looking at hospital admissions falling in 12 years. Can you let us not what policies can be included? Glasgow is an excellent example. Only last month I spoke to Scottish law officers about their experiences and I am deeply interested. MPs spent the afternoon on debate entitled global Britain. It was all about the UK placed itself in the new world where the old structures no longer existed. We need to be clear. We need an assessment of our place in

to appear before the DCMS select committee. Even Rupert Murdoch did that. So, does the Secretary of State agree with me that the time is now right for a new single, powerful regulator to take on the big tech giants and redress this huge imbalance of market power? Well, Mr Speaker, the other aspect of this that the right onto Bill Johnson and hasn't mentioned which I know he shares my concern about is the range of online hubs where we can I think realistically expect -- expect more assistance from the tech company than we currently have.

There are a whole range of areas in which we need to think about this. The truth is the tech economy has changed dramatically. The online company's power has changed dramatically, and you understand that what I want to make sure is that whatever actions the government and this country takes are properly drop through. For two reasons, they will be substantially attacked -- properly thought through. Secondly all they'll example to the world of how to do this and they will only be so if we have thought them through properly, design them carefully so that they are robust under scrutiny, and he has my reassurance that that's exactly the process I intend to engage in. Jeremy Wright. Ministers have been told to come up with creative alternatives to including banning offenders from London's knife crime epidemic, social media. Labour says the crime rate in the capital has risen this having logged nearly 1,300 knife year, with the Metropolitan Police attacks. Labour MP Sarah Jones told the Commons that harsher sentences were simply not working. custodial sentence for a nice The proportion of people receiving a possession has risen from 40% in 2010 to almost 70% today, and yet in the last five years knife crime has been on a sustained and shocking increase suggesting that harsher sentences simply are not the answer. Will be Attorney General look at two things? One, creative alternatives to present such as electronic tagging or banning young people from social media if they are using it to incite violence? And secondly more ways to reduce reoffending through education and rehabilitation to keep young people out of the prison system? I thank the honourable Lady for her question and I know that she has a keen local interest in the issue which affects Croydon as much of the does parts of our country. What I would say to her is I don't think there is a direct correlation. We have seen a rise in knife crime since early 2016 and I think it's right that have approached the issue of possession in a more serious way, but I take on board her point about causation, and I recently visited the trust in Upland in which I know she's familiar with. I'm deeply impressed with the work they do with young people. It is that sort of intervention approach at an early stage that I think can help deal with this problem. With the current knife crime epidemic in England and Wales up 53% in three years and of the government and the Mets have been looking at the Scottish Government in Glasgow or hospital admissions for splashes and stab wounds have fallen by 65% in 12 years. Can she update the house with what policies are enacted and in Glasgow will be replicated in London or more widely following the delegation to Glasgow? The honourable gentleman is right to raise the Glasgow example and I'm making plans to visit Glasgow as soon as possible and early last month I spoke with the Scottish Law offices about their experience of what is happening there. I'm deeply interested and I want to learn more as quickly as possible. MPs spent the afternoon on a debate entitled global Britain. Affairs Committee told MPs The chair of the Foreign it was all about how the UK placed itself the old in a new World, where structures no longer existed. an assessment of our place in the We need to really be clear. We need world, and we need to be clearer as to what we are going to do to maximise our position into the future. And that means understanding. Understanding who we are, and what we want, because we have a real choice in this, Mr Deputy Speaker. Either we choose to shape events, or we will be shaped by them. Mr Deputy Speaker, I can tell you very clearly that though many people today do not believe in the devil, they do not believe in the evil of war coming back to Europe, they do not believe in the dangers of the undermining of the international system. They believe in many ways that rules are some somewhat optional. The truth is they are simply not. And I can tell you this, because I have seen myself, the cost of it, having been to Baghdad and middle-class homes that were wealthy areas, into which people lived in very civilized society in the 60s and 50s, having been to Kabul and seen family photos of people showing their daughters going to university in miniskirts, and now living with the reality of Islamic fundamentalism, barbarity and war. I can say very clearly, sir, just because you don't believe in the double but not mean he

urn:contentItem:5THF-VH01-DXKX-017W-00000-00Thursday News: 'Trump is providing cover for Saudi barbarism'; 'Trump's Idea of Hell'; Disgusting, Anonymous Facebook Attack Ads Against Wexton2018-10-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisThursday News: 'Trump is providing cover for Saudi barbarism'; 'Trump's Idea of Hell'; Disgusting, Anonymous Facebook Attack Ads Against Wexton

Oct 18, 2018( Blue Virginia: http://bluevirginia.us/Delivered by Newstex) FacebookTwitter Google+ Pinterest WhatsAppby Lowell Here are a few national and Virginia news headlines, political and otherwise, for Thursday, October 18.Mitch McConnell Blames the Poor for Trump8217;s Trillion-Dollar Deficit[1] (8220;8216;It8217;s disappointing, but it8217;s not a Republican problem,8217; says the man who just passed a $1.5 trillion tax cut.8221; In fact, this is VERY much a Republican problem) Trump attacks fuel GOP fears about losing suburban women[2] Rod Rosenstein Defends Mueller Probe as 8216;Appropriate and Independent8217;[3] (8220;In interview, deputy attorney general says investigation has revealed widespread Russian effort to meddle in 2016 election8221;) How One Journalist8217;s Death Provoked a Backlash That Thousands Dead in Yemen Did Not[4] (8220;Any reporter who has covered a humanitarian disaster should understand what Stalin is once reported to have said to a fellow Soviet official: The death of one person is a tragedy, but the death of one million is a statistic. This is why news coverage of a famine or a flood will often highlight the story of one victim.8221;) Trump to meet with Pompeo as Khashoggi crisis engulfs White House[5] Biden says Trump 8220;seems to have a love affair with autocrats8221;[6] EPA Boasts Of Reduced Greenhouse Gases, Even As Trump Questions Climate Science[7] (The EPA boasts about stuff that happened in SPITE of the Trump administration.

Kinda like the economy. Thanks Obama and Democrats!) Voter Turnout Could Hit 50-Year Record For Midterm Elections[8] (Don8217;t get left out; vote!) The President* Is in Violation of His Oath of Office[9] (8220;It appears Donald Trump is assisting a foreign government in a conspiracy to obstruct justice in the political murder of a resident of the United States.8221;) The Horseface Chronicles[10] (8220;Try to think of something worse than Trump8217;s 8216;unexpressed thoughts.'8221;) Trump says selling weapons to Saudi Arabia will create a lot of jobs. That8217;s not true.[11] (8220;The impact of foreign arms sales on the US economy is minuscule.8221; Wait, Trump yet again doesn8217;t have a clue what he8217;s talking about? I8217;m shocked, shocked!) Republicans were supposed to run on their tax cuts. Instead, they8217;re running away from them.[12] (8220;Turns out a tax bill that overwhelmingly benefits rich people and corporations isn8217;t the most winning issue with voters.8221; And explodes the deficit/debt!) Trump has given every despot on the planet a license to kill[13] (8220;This is a good time to be a dictator 8212; and a dangerous time to be a dissident.8221;) Saudi Arabia8217;s information war to bury news of Jamal Khashoggi[14] Jamal Khashoggi: What the Arab world needs most is free expression[15] U.S. Spy Agencies Are Increasingly Convinced of Saudi Prince8217;s Ties to Journalist8217;s Disappearance[16] A President Kowtowing to a Mad Prince[17] (8220;Trump is providing cover for Saudi barbarism.8221;) The rise and fall and rise of the budget deficit[18] (In short, the deficit comes down under Democrats 8211; or even heads into SURPLUS, as it did under Bill Clinton 8211; and explodes under Republicans.) Audio Offers Gruesome Details of Jamal Khashoggi Killing, Turkish Official Says[19] Trump8217;s Climate Denial Isn8217;t Just a War on Our Coastlines. It8217;s a War on Our Brains.[20] Election Update: How The Latest Fundraising Numbers Shifted Our House Forecasts[21] (8220;And why things barely budged in the Senate.8221;) Prominent evangelical leader on Khashoggi crisis: let8217;s not risk 8220;$100 billion worth of arms sales8221;[22] (This evangelical leader, for one, certainly is NOT a follower of Jesus Christ. More like the polar opposite.) Mueller8217;s quiet period has not been very quiet[23] McGahn, a Soldier for Trump and a Witness Against Him, Departs White House[24] Media Congratulates Trump for Spreading Lie About Elizabeth Warren[25] (8220;Axios reports that Trump is especially pleased with his insulting of Massachusetts senator Elizabeth Warren, a contender for the 2020 Democratic nomination. Axios brings us word that behind the scenes the bully-in-chief and his lackeys are chortling about their success.8221;) Former USA Gymnastics President Arrested For Tampering With Nassar Evidence[26] Now we can create blue roses. But our real talent is destruction.[27] (8220;As scientists fiddle with roses, we8217;re ignoring the crises we8217;ve inflicted upon the planet.8221;) Wilbur Ross, stop rigging the Census[28] (8220;The Trump administration should quit trying to depress the immigrant response.8221;) Sanders 2020? Many Bernie backers aren8217;t feeling it[29] (Yeah, definitely not.) How Kamala Harris8217; team thinks she can win the 2020 nomination[30] Michael Avenatti Is Making Concrete Moves to Run for President in 2020 Against Trump[31] (8220;8230;the group made payments to Adam Parkhomenko, a former adviser to Hillary Clinton, for a food and transportation reimbursement worth $1,491.37, and a reimbursement payment of $342.52 to the TRR Group LLC. TRR Group is a firm run by both Parkhomenko and Virginia-based political strategist Ben Tribbett.8221;) 8220;You Can8217;t Out-Trump Trump8221;: Elizabeth Warren Shows Democrats How to Lose in 2020[32] (8220;Warren8217;s maneuver stands as a warning sign for other presidential contenders. Getting into the mud pit with Trump8212;who doesn8217;t care about political decorum, rules, sexism, racism, name-calling, facts, or reason8212;has revealed itself as a sucker8217;s game. Like a scientist trying to argue with a climate-change denier, you8217;ll just end up drowning in a tide of bad faith.8221;) Is Mattis About To Get Voted Off the Island?[33] (8220;Insiders believe the Defense secretary8217;s days are numbered8212;and that Trump didn8217;t come up with the idea that Mattis is a Democrat on his own.8221;) How Sen. Mark Warner Wants to Crack Down on Tech[34] (8220;The Senate Intel Committee8217;s top Democrat on how government might regulate tech and what his colleagues need to learn to catch up.8221;) 8220;America8217;s Failure to Lead Is Going to Come Back and Bite Us8221;[35] (8220;Sen. Mark Warner wants Congress to get tough with Big Tech. How would he do it?8221;) How Democrats Could Beat Back Voter Suppression at the Ballot Box[36] (8220;A new crop of Democratic candidates for secretary of state could bolster voting rights.8221;) Fox News8217; ad chief admits that advertisers are leaving. Here8217;s what8217;s going on.[37] (8220;Most national advertisers reject Fox News8217; most prominent hosts 8212; and with good reason8221;) File This One Under: Racist Stuff From the 8217;60s Happening in Georgia in 2018[38] (8220;And down in Virginia, Scott Taylor8217;s lost sight of ratfkcing fundamentals.8221;) Georgia mayor goes on racist rant after county stops Black Voters Matter from helping elderly vote[39] (8220;The mayor works in Jefferson County, where administrators stopped the group from bringing seniors to the polls.8221;) The Coverage of Elizabeth Warren8217;s Heritage Has Been Completely Distressing[40] (8220;We8217;re having the wrong debate about all of this.8221;) Leslie Cockburn (D-VA05) Named to 8220;Red to Blue8221; List[41] #DaveBratSaidThat . . . Whines To Inmates In Addiction Recovery About His Tough Life[42] In Virginia House Race, Anonymous Attack Ads Pop Up on Facebook[43] (This is absolutely appalling, also a failure by Facebook: 8220;The ads paint Ms. Wexton as an 8220;evil socialist,8221; with language and imagery not typically found in even the roughest campaigns. In one ad, which began running on Monday, Ms. Wexton is pictured next to an image of Nazi soldiers, and the ad8217;s text refers to her supporters as 8216;modern-day brown shirts.'8221;) Dominion pays for transfer to state of scenic property in Nelson to compensate for pipeline8217;s impact on state land[44] (So sweet of them.) Former VP Biden to join wife Jill in Newport News[45] Advisory council asks Northam to stop pipeline work, but governor passes[46] (8220;8217;Governor Northam and his Environmental Chief have now laid waste to any notion this administration and its agencies are capable of doing anything but advancing the business of the fracked gas industry,8217; the Protect Our Water Heritage Rights Coalition said in a statement Wednesday after the letter was released.8221;) Long-Time Arlington Political Guru Predicts Record Voter Turnout, Tim Kaine with 80% of Arlington Vote, Victory for Dem County Board Candidate Matt de Ferranti[47] Virginia spaceport to grow with new launch pad for California company[48] CASEY: Absentee voting8217;s up in Virgina; will the number of late, uncounted ballots rise, too?[49] Nohe running for Prince William County board chair in 2019 election[50] (Once we kick Corey8217;s butt on 11/6, we need to turn our focus to ending his political career completely.) Gerrymandering runs deep in Virginia8217;s roots, CNU professor says[51] Hampton Roads Transit to rethink services, foster more regional collaboration[52] Sunny and brisk today, and then another cool surge by Sunday[53] FacebookTwitter Google+ Pinterest WhatsAppPrevious article#DaveBratSaidThat . . . urn:contentItem:5THH-BXT1-JCMN-Y1DH-00000-00Thursday News: 'Trump is providing cover for Saudi barbarism'; 'Trump's Idea of Hell'; Disgusting, Anonymous Facebook Attack Ads Against Wexton2018-10-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisThursday News: 'Trump is providing cover for Saudi barbarism'; 'Trump's Idea of Hell'; Disgusting, Anonymous Facebook Attack Ads Against Wextonlowkell

Oct 18, 2018( Blue Virginia: http://bluevirginia.us/ Delivered by Newstex) FacebookTwitter Google+ Pinterest WhatsAppby Lowell Here are a few national and Virginia news headlines, political and otherwise, for Thursday, October 18.Mitch McConnell Blames the Poor for Trump...7;s Trillion-Dollar Deficit[1] (...0;...6;It...7;s disappointing, but it...7;s not a Republican problem,...7; says the man who just passed a $1.5 trillion tax cut....1; In fact, this is VERY much a Republican problem) Trump attacks fuel GOP fears about losing suburban women[2] Rod Rosenstein Defends Mueller Probe as ...6;Appropriate and Independent...7;[3] (...0;In interview, deputy attorney general says investigation has revealed widespread Russian effort to meddle in 2016 election...1;) How One Journalist...7;s Death Provoked a Backlash That Thousands Dead in Yemen Did Not[4] (...0;Any reporter who has covered a humanitarian disaster should understand what Stalin is once reported to have said to a fellow Soviet official: The death of one person is a tragedy, but the death of one million is a statistic. This is why news coverage of a famine or a flood will often highlight the story of one victim....1;) Trump to meet with Pompeo as Khashoggi crisis engulfs White House[5] Biden says Trump ...0;seems to have a love affair with autocrats...1;[6] EPA Boasts Of Reduced Greenhouse Gases, Even As Trump Questions Climate Science[7] (The EPA boasts about stuff that happened in SPITE of the Trump administration.

Kinda like the economy. Thanks Obama and Democrats!) Voter Turnout Could Hit 50-Year Record For Midterm Elections[8] (Don...7;t get left out; vote!) The President* Is in Violation of His Oath of Office[9] (...0;It appears Donald Trump is assisting a foreign government in a conspiracy to obstruct justice in the political murder of a resident of the United States....1;) The Horseface Chronicles[10] (...0;Try to think of something worse than Trump...7;s ...6;unexpressed thoughts.'...1;) Trump says selling weapons to Saudi Arabia will create a lot of jobs. That...7;s not true.[11] (...0;The impact of foreign arms sales on the US economy is minuscule....1; Wait, Trump yet again doesn...7;t have a clue what he...7;s talking about? I...7;m shocked, shocked!) Republicans were supposed to run on their tax cuts. Instead, they...7;re running away from them.[12] (...0;Turns out a tax bill that overwhelmingly benefits rich people and corporations isn...7;t the most winning issue with voters....1; And explodes the deficit/debt!) Trump has given every despot on the planet a license to kill[13] (...0;This is a good time to be a dictator ...2; and a dangerous time to be a dissident....1;) Saudi Arabia...7;s information war to bury news of Jamal Khashoggi[14] Jamal Khashoggi: What the Arab world needs most is free expression[15] U.S. Spy Agencies Are Increasingly Convinced of Saudi Prince...7;s Ties to Journalist...7;s Disappearance[16] A President Kowtowing to a Mad Prince[17] (...0;Trump is providing cover for Saudi barbarism....1;) The rise and fall and rise of the budget deficit[18] (In short, the deficit comes down under Democrats ...1; or even heads into SURPLUS, as it did under Bill Clinton ...1; and explodes under Republicans.) Audio Offers Gruesome Details of Jamal Khashoggi Killing, Turkish Official Says[19] Trump...7;s Climate Denial Isn...7;t Just a War on Our Coastlines. It...7;s a War on Our Brains.[20] Election Update: How The Latest Fundraising Numbers Shifted Our House Forecasts[21] (...0;And why things barely budged in the Senate....1;) Prominent evangelical leader on Khashoggi crisis: let...7;s not risk ...0;$100 billion worth of arms sales...1;[22] (This evangelical leader, for one, certainly is NOT a follower of Jesus Christ. More like the polar opposite.) Mueller...7;s quiet period has not been very quiet[23] McGahn, a Soldier for Trump and a Witness Against Him, Departs White House[24] Media Congratulates Trump for Spreading Lie About Elizabeth Warren[25] (...0;Axios reports that Trump is especially pleased with his insulting of Massachusetts senator Elizabeth Warren, a contender for the 2020 Democratic nomination. Axios brings us word that behind the scenes the bully-in-chief and his lackeys are chortling about their success....1;) Former USA Gymnastics President Arrested For Tampering With Nassar Evidence[26] Now we can create blue roses. But our real talent is destruction.[27] (...0;As scientists fiddle with roses, we...7;re ignoring the crises we...7;ve inflicted upon the planet....1;) Wilbur Ross, stop rigging the Census[28] (...0;The Trump administration should quit trying to depress the immigrant response....1;) Sanders 2020? Many Bernie backers aren...7;t feeling it[29] (Yeah, definitely not.) How Kamala Harris...7; team thinks she can win the 2020 nomination[30] Michael Avenatti Is Making Concrete Moves to Run for President in 2020 Against Trump[31] (...0;...0;the group made payments to Adam Parkhomenko, a former adviser to Hillary Clinton, for a food and transportation reimbursement worth $1,491.37, and a reimbursement payment of $342.52 to the TRR Group LLC. TRR Group is a firm run by both Parkhomenko and Virginia-based political strategist Ben Tribbett....1;) ...0;You Can...7;t Out-Trump Trump...1;: Elizabeth Warren Shows Democrats How to Lose in 2020[32] (...0;Warren...7;s maneuver stands as a warning sign for other presidential contenders. Getting into the mud pit with Trump...2;who doesn...7;t care about political decorum, rules, sexism, racism, name-calling, facts, or reason...2;has revealed itself as a sucker...7;s game. Like a scientist trying to argue with a climate-change denier, you...7;ll just end up drowning in a tide of bad faith....1;) Is Mattis About To Get Voted Off the Island?[33] (...0;Insiders believe the Defense secretary...7;s days are numbered...2;and that Trump didn...7;t come up with the idea that Mattis is a Democrat on his own....1;) How Sen. Mark Warner Wants to Crack Down on Tech[34] (...0;The Senate Intel Committee...7;s top Democrat on how government might regulate tech and what his colleagues need to learn to catch up....1;) ...0;America...7;s Failure to Lead Is Going to Come Back and Bite Us...1;[35] (...0;Sen. Mark Warner wants Congress to get tough with Big Tech. How would he do it?...1;) How Democrats Could Beat Back Voter Suppression at the Ballot Box[36] (...0;A new crop of Democratic candidates for secretary of state could bolster voting rights....1;) Fox News...7; ad chief admits that advertisers are leaving. Here...7;s what...7;s going on.[37] (...0;Most national advertisers reject Fox News...7; most prominent hosts ...2; and with good reason...1;) File This One Under: Racist Stuff From the ...7;60s Happening in Georgia in 2018[38] (...0;And down in Virginia, Scott Taylor...7;s lost sight of ratfkcing fundamentals....1;) Georgia mayor goes on racist rant after county stops Black Voters Matter from helping elderly vote[39] (...0;The mayor works in Jefferson County, where administrators stopped the group from bringing seniors to the polls....1;) The Coverage of Elizabeth Warren...7;s Heritage Has Been Completely Distressing[40] (...0;We...7;re having the wrong debate about all of this....1;) Leslie Cockburn (D-VA05) Named to ...0;Red to Blue...1; List[41] #DaveBratSaidThat . . . Whines To Inmates In Addiction Recovery About His Tough Life[42] In Virginia House Race, Anonymous Attack Ads Pop Up on Facebook[43] (This is absolutely appalling, also a failure by Facebook: ...0;The ads paint Ms. Wexton as an ...0;evil socialist,...1; with language and imagery not typically found in even the roughest campaigns. In one ad, which began running on Monday, Ms. Wexton is pictured next to an image of Nazi soldiers, and the ad...7;s text refers to her supporters as ...6;modern-day brown shirts.'...1;) Dominion pays for transfer to state of scenic property in Nelson to compensate for pipeline...7;s impact on state land[44] (So sweet of them.) Former VP Biden to join wife Jill in Newport News[45] Advisory council asks Northam to stop pipeline work, but governor passes[46] (...0;...7;Governor Northam and his Environmental Chief have now laid waste to any notion this administration and its agencies are capable of doing anything but advancing the business of the fracked gas industry,...7; the Protect Our Water Heritage Rights Coalition said in a statement Wednesday after the letter was released....1;) Long-Time Arlington Political Guru Predicts Record Voter Turnout, Tim Kaine with 80% of Arlington Vote, Victory for Dem County Board Candidate Matt de Ferranti[47] Virginia spaceport to grow with new launch pad for California company[48] CASEY: Absentee voting...7;s up in Virgina; will the number of late, uncounted ballots rise, too?[49] Nohe running for Prince William County board chair in 2019 election[50] (Once we kick Corey...7;s butt on 11/6, we need to turn our focus to ending his political career completely.) Gerrymandering runs deep in Virginia...7;s roots, CNU professor says[51] Hampton Roads Transit to rethink services, foster more regional collaboration[52] Sunny and brisk today, and then another cool surge by Sunday[53] FacebookTwitter Google+ Pinterest WhatsAppPrevious article#DaveBratSaidThat . . . urn:contentItem:5RXR-FCV1-F03R-N34N-00000-00Thursday News: Zuckerberg's 'Really Sorry' Is 'Totally Inadequate'; 'Why Is Trump So Afraid of Russia?'; Virginia Republicans 'divided, impassioned, and fearful'2018-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisThursday News: Zuckerberg's 'Really Sorry' Is 'Totally Inadequate'; 'Why Is Trump So Afraid of Russia?'; Virginia Republicans 'divided, impassioned, and fearful'lowkell

Mar 22, 2018( Blue Virginia: http://bluevirginia.us/ Delivered by Newstex) SHAREFacebook Twitter by Lowell Here are a few national and Virginia news headlines, political and otherwise, for Thursday, March 22. [embedded content]Behind the scenes: Fox News analyst...7;s stunning note hit network ...6;like a bombshell...7;[1] In case of dumb Trump tweet on climate change and snow storms, read this[2] (...0;Global warming is heating the ocean waters that make nor...7;easters more intense....1;) Never mind the indictments and poisonings, Trump just wants to ...6;get along...7; with Putin[3] (...0;His latest tweets put him at odds with his own advisers....1;) The 2,232 page omnibus spending bill, explained in less than 1000 words[4] (...0;The Bad: The massive spending bill is does not have any significant new restrictions on gun purchases ...2; something student activists from Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School have explicitly called for....1;) Why Is Trump So Afraid of Russia?[5] (...0;Nary a bad word about Vladimir Putin can the U.S. president find....1; I...7;d bet a lot of money the Russians have seriously compromising material on Trump.) Trump Told Putin He...7;d Meet With Him Soon, Forgot to Inform White House[6] What We Know About Austin Bomber Mark Conditt[7] (...0;The Austin American-Statesman reports that Conditt wrote about his opposition to gay marriage and abortion, and his support for the death penalty.

He also advocated for the abolishment of sex-offender registries...0;It...7;s not clear whether Conditt...7;s political views, which he described as conservative, motivated the bombings...1;) Yes, we should be outraged about Facebook[8] Were the Austin bombings terrorism? In the heart of Texas, it sure feels that way[9] Texas serial bomber made video confession before blowing himself up: police[10] (...0;Conditt, who was home-schooled, described himself as a conservative but said he was not politically inclined, according to blog posts he wrote as part of a U.S. politics class at Austin Community College....1;) Cambridge Analytica boss went from ...6;aromatics...7; to psyops to Trump...7;s campaign[11] (...0;While Alexander Nix draws headlines for his role in the Trump 2016 digital operation, his colorful business partner Nigel Oakes may be an equally important figure....1;) Kelly furious over Putin ...6;DO NOT CONGRATULATE...7; leak[12] (...0;Other GOP officials have expressed alarm that such a closely guarded detail found its way into media accounts....1;) Zuckerberg...7;s Plan to Fix Facebook Is Sensible, Comforting, and Totally Inadequate[13] (...0;The Cambridge Analytica story, in this view, is just the fuse to a powder keg of discontentment with the company...7;s central project of mining users...7; personal data to help advertisers target them. If that...7;s the case, then what Zuckerberg has just announced is a plan to disable the fuse after the bomb has already gone off....1;) Mark Zuckerberg says he...7;s ...6;open...7; to testifying to Congress, fixes will cost ...6;many millions...7; and he ...6;feels really bad...7;[14] Who...7;s Worse ...2; Trump Lawyers or Their Client?[15] What Trump and Putin Have in Common[16] (...0;Bullies like Trump and Putin are relentless. They will keep driving through red lights, smirking all the way, as long as we let them. But American voters can stop Trump, and America and its allies can stop Putin ...2; if they act together....1;) Congressional negotiators reach deal on $1.3 trillion spending bill[17] (...0;The legislation would make good on President Trump...7;s promises to increase military funding while blocking much of his immigration agenda. The release of the 2,000-plus-page bill Wednesday evening touched off a legislative sprint as lawmakers try to pass it before Friday night, the deadline to avoid a government shutdown....1;) Dem senator responds to Zuckerberg: ...6;You need to come...7; testify[18] What Would Regulating Facebook Look Like?[19] Mark Zuckerberg: ...6;I Actually Am Not Sure We Shouldn...7;t Be Regulated...7;[20] Cambridge Analytica and Our Lives Inside the Surveillance Machine[21] House leaders...7; biggest 2018 fear: The lazy Republican[22] (...0;GOP members who haven...7;t had a tough race in years are being warned to start running scared....1;) Unarmed black man shot to death in own backyard after police mistake cell phone for weapon[23] (Totally f...7;ed up.) 2020 Dems compete for top campaign operatives[24] GOP pushes to change Senate rules for Trump[25] (The exact opposite of what the Senate should be doing.) Director at pro-Trump group boasted of asking airline passengers with ...0;a rag...1; on their heads if they were terrorists[26] (...0;America First Policies...7; Carl Higbie: ...6;You put a rag on your head, it...7;s my right to be suspicious'...1; Bigots, of course.) Karen McDougal is the woman with the best chance of bringing down Trump[27] (...0;Stormy Daniels is in the headlines, but Karen McDougal is a bigger problem for Trump....1;) 60 Minutes interview with Stormy Daniels to be broadcast Sunday[28] 20,000 Republicans just voted for an actual Nazi[29] (...0;Illinois Republicans nominated Arthur Jones for a U.S. House seat....1; These people will literally vote for ANYONE with an ...0;R...1; by their name. Sick.) Cambridge Analytica sets quandary for right: hate Facebook, love Trump[30] (...0;The scandal of the data mining company produced complicated feelings on the right as hatred of big tech companies vied with sensitivity about Trump...7;s victory...1;) Which U.S. House Race Is The Best 2018 Bellwether?[31] (...1; I chose Virginia...7;s 10th Congressional District, currently held by Republican Barbara Comstock. This is somewhat similar to Mimi Walters and to the broader theme that Republicans might have trouble in districts near big cities (Comstock represents a suburban area near Washington, D.C., that is full of federal workers.) She won by 6 percentage points in 2016, but Trump lost there by 10....1;) It...7;s official: Republican Rick Saccone concedes to Conor Lamb in Pennsylvania special election[32] 5th District Democratic hopefuls gather at forum[33] (...0;Hosted by the Danville Democrat[ic] Committee, Leslie Cockburn, Ben Collup, Roger Dean Huffstetler and Andrew Sneathern talked to more than 100 voters at Danville Community College....1;) A tale of two forums: What the primary debates tell us about politics in Virginia[34] (...0;The Republicans are divided, impassioned, and fearful...1;) Census data: Growth in northern Virginia, decline in south[35] Gov. Ralph Northam introduces new state budget with Medicaid expansion and a twist: He wants extra revenue saved, not spent[36] Va. Gov. Ralph Northam proposes new budget. And it looks really familiar.[37] (...0;The governor reverts to ...6;straight...7; Medicaid expansion as the legislature prepares to resume budget battle....1;) CASEY: Is Goodlatte providing cover for President Donald Trump?[38] Former Gov. Douglas Wilder sues dean of school bearing his name claiming assistant was harassed[39] Bowser proposes tax increases, including on Lyft and Uber rides, to pay for Metro[40] (And if we didn...7;t have godawful legislators like anti-tax, anti-transit Republican Tim Hugo, maybe we could do things the right way as well. But noooooooo.) Fairfax Co. pushes for changes to landmark Va. Metro funding deal[41] (Republican John Cook rips Republican Tim Hugo...7;s Metro funding deal: ...0;If you had sat down in January and said, ...6;Let...7;s write a bill that meets Metro...7;s needs but does it in the way that hurts local government in Northern Virginia the most and does the absolute minimum from the state,...7; you would come up with something very similar to what...7;s on his desk now...1;) Microsoft adds 315 megawatts of new solar power in Virginia in largest corporate solar agreement in the United States[42] (...0;Microsoft Corp. announced on Wednesday the purchase of 315 MW of energy from Pleinmont I and II, two new solar projects in the commonwealth of Virginia. This represents the single largest corporate purchase of solar energy ever in the United States. This will enable Microsoft to make significant progress toward its goal of reaching 60 percent by early 2020. The Pleinmont projects are part of a larger 500-MW solar development, owned and operated by sPower, an AES and AIMCo company....1;) Spring snowfall causes power outages, hazardous roads[43] Editorial: Time to renegotiate the bum deal with the Redskins[44] (The deal should be that Dan Snyder pays every penny, the city pays zero.) Slavery reparations, memorials discussed at UVA conference[45] Hampton Roads Regional Jail...7;s superintendent steps down[46] March for Our Lives event planned for this weekend in downtown Norfolk[47] Residents participate in both sides of gun debate with events this weekend[48] Norfolk council members blame everybody but themselves on Meeks...7; waste plant[49] Election of Richmond Democratic Party leaders thrown out following complaints[50] (...0;James ...0;J.J....1; Minor...7;s election to a fifth term as the leader of the Richmond arm of the state Democratic Party was thrown out last week after complaints of a flawed process and voter intimidation....1; This crap should not acceptable in the Democratic Party. At all.) Breezy and cold through Friday; close call on snow Saturday night[51] SHAREFacebook Twitter Previous articleTim Hugo Puts the F-I-X in Fairfax Judicial Nominations[52]Next articleWayyyy Beyond Parody: urn:contentItem:5RXR-91D1-JB4V-82D6-00000-00Thursday News: Zuckerberg's 'Really Sorry' Is 'Totally Inadequate'; 'Why Is Trump So Afraid of Russia?'; Virginia Republicans 'divided, impassioned, and fearful'2018-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisThursday News: Zuckerberg's 'Really Sorry' Is 'Totally Inadequate'; 'Why Is Trump So Afraid of Russia?'; Virginia Republicans 'divided, impassioned, and fearful'

Mar 22, 2018( Blue Virginia: http://bluevirginia.us/Delivered by Newstex) SHAREFacebook Twitter by Lowell Here are a few national and Virginia news headlines, political and otherwise, for Thursday, March 22. [embedded content]Behind the scenes: Fox News analyst8217;s stunning note hit network 8216;like a bombshell8217;[1] In case of dumb Trump tweet on climate change and snow storms, read this[2] (8220;Global warming is heating the ocean waters that make nor8217;easters more intense.8221;) Never mind the indictments and poisonings, Trump just wants to 8216;get along8217; with Putin[3] (8220;His latest tweets put him at odds with his own advisers.8221;) The 2,232 page omnibus spending bill, explained in less than 1000 words[4] (8220;The Bad: The massive spending bill is does not have any significant new restrictions on gun purchases 8212; something student activists from Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School have explicitly called for.8221;) Why Is Trump So Afraid of Russia?[5] (8220;Nary a bad word about Vladimir Putin can the U.S. president find.8221; I8217;d bet a lot of money the Russians have seriously compromising material on Trump.) Trump Told Putin He8217;d Meet With Him Soon, Forgot to Inform White House[6] What We Know About Austin Bomber Mark Conditt[7] (8220;The Austin American-Statesman reports that Conditt wrote about his opposition to gay marriage and abortion, and his support for the death penalty.

He also advocated for the abolishment of sex-offender registries8230;It8217;s not clear whether Conditt8217;s political views, which he described as conservative, motivated the bombings8221;) Yes, we should be outraged about Facebook[8] Were the Austin bombings terrorism? In the heart of Texas, it sure feels that way[9] Texas serial bomber made video confession before blowing himself up: police[10] (8220;Conditt, who was home-schooled, described himself as a conservative but said he was not politically inclined, according to blog posts he wrote as part of a U.S. politics class at Austin Community College.8221;) Cambridge Analytica boss went from 8216;aromatics8217; to psyops to Trump8217;s campaign[11] (8220;While Alexander Nix draws headlines for his role in the Trump 2016 digital operation, his colorful business partner Nigel Oakes may be an equally important figure.8221;) Kelly furious over Putin 8216;DO NOT CONGRATULATE8217; leak[12] (8220;Other GOP officials have expressed alarm that such a closely guarded detail found its way into media accounts.8221;) Zuckerberg8217;s Plan to Fix Facebook Is Sensible, Comforting, and Totally Inadequate[13] (8220;The Cambridge Analytica story, in this view, is just the fuse to a powder keg of discontentment with the company8217;s central project of mining users8217; personal data to help advertisers target them. If that8217;s the case, then what Zuckerberg has just announced is a plan to disable the fuse after the bomb has already gone off.8221;) Mark Zuckerberg says he8217;s 8216;open8217; to testifying to Congress, fixes will cost 8216;many millions8217; and he 8216;feels really bad8217;[14] Who8217;s Worse 8212; Trump Lawyers or Their Client?[15] What Trump and Putin Have in Common[16] (8220;Bullies like Trump and Putin are relentless. They will keep driving through red lights, smirking all the way, as long as we let them. But American voters can stop Trump, and America and its allies can stop Putin 8212; if they act together.8221;) Congressional negotiators reach deal on $1.3 trillion spending bill[17] (8220;The legislation would make good on President Trump8217;s promises to increase military funding while blocking much of his immigration agenda. The release of the 2,000-plus-page bill Wednesday evening touched off a legislative sprint as lawmakers try to pass it before Friday night, the deadline to avoid a government shutdown.8221;) Dem senator responds to Zuckerberg: 8216;You need to come8217; testify[18] What Would Regulating Facebook Look Like?[19] Mark Zuckerberg: 8216;I Actually Am Not Sure We Shouldn8217;t Be Regulated8217;[20] Cambridge Analytica and Our Lives Inside the Surveillance Machine[21] House leaders8217; biggest 2018 fear: The lazy Republican[22] (8220;GOP members who haven8217;t had a tough race in years are being warned to start running scared.8221;) Unarmed black man shot to death in own backyard after police mistake cell phone for weapon[23] (Totally f8217;ed up.) 2020 Dems compete for top campaign operatives[24] GOP pushes to change Senate rules for Trump[25] (The exact opposite of what the Senate should be doing.) Director at pro-Trump group boasted of asking airline passengers with 8220;a rag8221; on their heads if they were terrorists[26] (8220;America First Policies8217; Carl Higbie: 8216;You put a rag on your head, it8217;s my right to be suspicious'8221; Bigots, of course.) Karen McDougal is the woman with the best chance of bringing down Trump[27] (8220;Stormy Daniels is in the headlines, but Karen McDougal is a bigger problem for Trump.8221;) 60 Minutes interview with Stormy Daniels to be broadcast Sunday[28] 20,000 Republicans just voted for an actual Nazi[29] (8220;Illinois Republicans nominated Arthur Jones for a U.S. House seat.8221; These people will literally vote for ANYONE with an 8220;R8221; by their name. Sick.) Cambridge Analytica sets quandary for right: hate Facebook, love Trump[30] (8220;The scandal of the data mining company produced complicated feelings on the right as hatred of big tech companies vied with sensitivity about Trump8217;s victory8221;) Which U.S. House Race Is The Best 2018 Bellwether?[31] (8221; I chose Virginia8217;s 10th Congressional District, currently held by Republican Barbara Comstock. This is somewhat similar to Mimi Walters and to the broader theme that Republicans might have trouble in districts near big cities (Comstock represents a suburban area near Washington, D.C., that is full of federal workers.) She won by 6 percentage points in 2016, but Trump lost there by 10.8221;) It8217;s official: Republican Rick Saccone concedes to Conor Lamb in Pennsylvania special election[32] 5th District Democratic hopefuls gather at forum[33] (8220;Hosted by the Danville Democrat[ic] Committee, Leslie Cockburn, Ben Collup, Roger Dean Huffstetler and Andrew Sneathern talked to more than 100 voters at Danville Community College.8221;) A tale of two forums: What the primary debates tell us about politics in Virginia[34] (8220;The Republicans are divided, impassioned, and fearful8221;) Census data: Growth in northern Virginia, decline in south[35] Gov. Ralph Northam introduces new state budget with Medicaid expansion and a twist: He wants extra revenue saved, not spent[36] Va. Gov. Ralph Northam proposes new budget. And it looks really familiar.[37] (8220;The governor reverts to 8216;straight8217; Medicaid expansion as the legislature prepares to resume budget battle.8221;) CASEY: Is Goodlatte providing cover for President Donald Trump?[38] Former Gov. Douglas Wilder sues dean of school bearing his name claiming assistant was harassed[39] Bowser proposes tax increases, including on Lyft and Uber rides, to pay for Metro[40] (And if we didn8217;t have godawful legislators like anti-tax, anti-transit Republican Tim Hugo, maybe we could do things the right way as well. But noooooooo.) Fairfax Co. pushes for changes to landmark Va. Metro funding deal[41] (Republican John Cook rips Republican Tim Hugo8217;s Metro funding deal: 8220;If you had sat down in January and said, 8216;Let8217;s write a bill that meets Metro8217;s needs but does it in the way that hurts local government in Northern Virginia the most and does the absolute minimum from the state,8217; you would come up with something very similar to what8217;s on his desk now8221;) Microsoft adds 315 megawatts of new solar power in Virginia in largest corporate solar agreement in the United States[42] (8220;Microsoft Corp. announced on Wednesday the purchase of 315 MW of energy from Pleinmont I and II, two new solar projects in the commonwealth of Virginia. This represents the single largest corporate purchase of solar energy ever in the United States. This will enable Microsoft to make significant progress toward its goal of reaching 60 percent by early 2020. The Pleinmont projects are part of a larger 500-MW solar development, owned and operated by sPower, an AES and AIMCo company.8221;) Spring snowfall causes power outages, hazardous roads[43] Editorial: Time to renegotiate the bum deal with the Redskins[44] (The deal should be that Dan Snyder pays every penny, the city pays zero.) Slavery reparations, memorials discussed at UVA conference[45] Hampton Roads Regional Jail8217;s superintendent steps down[46] March for Our Lives event planned for this weekend in downtown Norfolk[47] Residents participate in both sides of gun debate with events this weekend[48] Norfolk council members blame everybody but themselves on Meeks8217; waste plant[49] Election of Richmond Democratic Party leaders thrown out following complaints[50] (8220;James 8220;J.J.8221; Minor8217;s election to a fifth term as the leader of the Richmond arm of the state Democratic Party was thrown out last week after complaints of a flawed process and voter intimidation.8221; This crap should not acceptable in the Democratic Party. At all.) Breezy and cold through Friday; close call on snow Saturday night[51] SHAREFacebook Twitter Previous articleTim Hugo Puts the F-I-X in Fairfax Judicial Nominations[52]Next articleWayyyy Beyond Parody: urn:contentItem:5XSH-JMB1-F0HT-S1N8-00000-00Thursday Papers: UK to create regulator to police big tech companies2019-12-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisThursday Papers: UK to create regulator to police big tech companiesHimanshu Singh

And car workers’ jobs ‘at risk’ after PSA and FiatChrysler agree merger.

Top stories

Financial Times: The UK government will create a technology regulator next year to police companies such as Facebook and Google after Brexit.

The Times: Merger of Groupe PSA and FiatChrysler has raised fears of layoffs in Britain, Italy and France; trade unions representing Vauxhall workers have demanded an urgent meeting with executives at PSA.

The Daily Telegraph: Bet365 chief Denise Coates has bagged £320 million this year and is expected to be the world's best-paid female boss.

Financial Times: The Bank of England is to set up the world’s stiffest climate stress tests, which will scrutinise lenders and insurers in the UK against three different environmental scenarios.

Financial Times: European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen has warned that Britain will suffer more than the EU if the two sides cannot broker a trade deal by the end of next year.

Business and economics

Daily Mail: Hargreaves Lansdown has removed the popular M&G Recovery fund from its Wealth 50 list, citing poor performance and a lack of confidence in the manager's ability.

The Times: London’s junior market was rattled yesterday by a flurry of profit warnings, prompting concerns that political uncertainty and a global economic slowdown have hit smaller British businesses.

The Daily Telegraph: Shares in NMC Health dropped again as the private hospital firm fought back against explosive claims of financial mismanagement made by US hedge fund Muddy Waters.

The Times: Premium paint maker Farrow and Ball posted a small widening of losses after being hit by closures of Homebase stores.

The Daily Telegraph: Pensioners are being stung by higher inflation than the rest of the population due to rising holiday package costs.

Daily Mail: Annual house price growth across the country has slowed to its lowest level since 2012, new data from the Office for National Statistics shows; however, industry insiders think the figures mark the end of a stagnate market.

The Daily Telegraph: BT’s WiFi kiosk business InLink has collapsed into administration after encountering delays in obtaining planning permission.

The Guardian: Small literary publisher Galley Beggar Press has been forced to make a public appeal for support after the Book People’s fall into administration left it with a £40,000 hole in its finances.

The Times: Pearson boss John Fallon has resigned only months after a profits warning knocked his plan to reshape the troubled education publisher off course.

The Times: Tesla is considering a sharp price cut for the Model 3s it builds and sells in China amid stalling demand there for electric vehicles.

The Guardian: Google has agreed to pay $481.5 million to the Australian Tax Office in a major win for the agency; the settlement covers a decade’s worth of tax between 2008 and 2018.

The Times: Google, Apple and Amazon have made an unusual pact to improve smart home devices together for consumers.

The Daily Telegraph: The US has drawn up a set of rules that will limit the export of sensitive technology to China.

The Times: Pacific Gas and Electric Company, the utility blamed for causing a series of devastating wildfires in California, has secured court approval for a $13.5 billion settlement with victims.

Share tips, comment and bids

The Times (Tempus share tips): AVOID ITV; BUY Renewables Infrastructure Group.

The Daily Telegraph: Andy Bell, the founder of investment platform AJ Bell, insisted he remains committed to the business after selling £23 million worth of shares.

The Daily Telegraph: Blackstone has snapped up warehouse owner Hansteen for £500 million, sparking hopes of a post-election dealmaking spree.

The Daily Telegraph: JaguarLand Rover has bought niche car manufacturer Bowler out of administration.

The Daily Telegraph: Hyve Group, one of the world's biggest exhibition organisers, has added two major US events, Shoptalk and Grocerystop, to its portfolio in a deal worth $145 million.

The Times: The Pearson board has ended a 50-year relationship with the sale of its remaining stake in the owner of Penguin Books.

The Daily Telegraph (Comment): Boris Johnson's hard Brexit makes Scottish independence all but impossible, whatever the emotions.
