Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5J2R-GRW1-JBHT-D1Y4-00000-00TIBCO CEO Vivek Ranadive Intvd on Blmbg Surveillance2014-08-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisTIBCO CEO Vivek Ranadive Intvd on Blmbg SurveillanceWalthamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

VIVEK RANADIVE, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, TIBCO, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE

AUGUST 18, 2014

SPEAKERS: VIVEK RANADIVE, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, TIBCO

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

ADAM JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] TOM KEENE, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: We are thrilled to bring you today one of America's great success stories in digital science, in computing. Vivek Ranadive joins us from TIBCO. He's also got a side job as an owner of a basketball team. His balance sheet has been adjusted by Steven Ballmer.

I mean sports, as you know, with your heritage in India, is a great solution for the Indian culture, whether it's cricket, as an example, or basketball within America. We have seen so much animosity before Mr. Ballmer at the Clippers. What would you like to see the NBA do this season and particularly in the opening of the season to help America heal or come together?

VIVEK RANADIVE, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, TIBCO: Well, I thought that our commissioner Adam Silver acted decisively and very, very quickly. And I welcome Steve into the NBA fraternity.

I think it's going to be a fantastic season for the NBA. It's a global sport. We're taking our team to China this offseason, the preseason. And I just expect a lot of the troubles of the past to be behind us.

KEENE: Within this and within what we see in Ferguson, Missouri, sport has always brought America together. Somewhat reluctantly--

RANADIVE: Right.

KEENE: I can remember some of that as a kid. What needs to be done right now given the events of the past week?

RANADIVE: Well, we actually have a player Ben McLemore who's from the St. Louis area. He had great sympathy for the protesters. And he's been posting to Instagram. He's actually in China right now representing the Kings.

KEENE: Mm-hmm.

RANADIVE: And I think full transparency is what everybody is asking for. And, as you said, sport is the great unifier. All we care about in basketball is do we have game? And that's really what America is about.

ADAM JOHNSON, HOST, BLOOMBERG TELEVISION: Well, you talk about a great unifier, I remember when Yao Ming because the first Chinese player in the NBA and you have now just brought in the first India player, Sim Bhullar, if I've got his name right. He's like 7'5 and 360 pounds. How's this going to change the game?

RANADIVE: Well, I believe that basketball could be one of the most popular sports in India. I have this vision -- I call it NBA 3.0, making basketball the global sport of the 21st century. And markets like India and China are going to help make it that.

KEENE: So TIBCO didn't get comp tickets to the World Cup right?

RANADIVE: No, no, no.

(LAUGHTER)

RANADIVE: We are using TIBCO technology. In many ways, a basketball team is like any other business. It's a social network-type of perishable inventory. And whether you're selling basketball tickets, airline tickets, banking products--

KEENE: Did you really end up in Boston with $50 in your pocket before you went to MIT? Is that story true or did they make that up for you?

RANADIVE: Well, that is true. We have the rupee isn't a convertible currency.

KEENE: Right.

RANADIVE: So you could only have a little bit converted. And so I had about $50 when I showed up.

KEENE: Very good. I hope you didn't switch it at American Express, because you would have gotten killed back then. Vivek Ranadive with us from TIBCO. We have so much to talk about, about his success in computers as well.

0710

(BREAK)

0724

SCARLET FU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Vivek Ranadive, you played a big role in digitizing Wall Street. So when you hear about the banks recovering, resurging really, what are your thoughts in terms of how much more they should be utilizing technology?

RANADIVE: Well, I think that more than regulation a bigger threat to the banks is technology. And the bank of the future will probably have no walls. It will be a social network attached to a computer program. And so I don't think they use a lot of technology right now. I think the best is yet to come.

FU: The best is yet to come, Vivek Ranadive, our guest host for the hour.

0725

(BREAK)

0729

KEENE: Good morning, everyone. "This Matters Now" to our guest host. Vivek Ranadive runs TIBCO. They are the bridge for countless big companies interacting with customers. Think Citigroup Asia and Delta Airlines, just as two examples.

Mr. Ranadive landed in Cambridge with the proverbial $50 and dreams. After MIT, after corporate success, he still knows math is what matters. This is a major American debate. People will say you, Raghuram Rajan, now the head of the Central Bank in India out of Booth School, Chicago and others. This is easy for those Indians. How do we make this easy for Americans who seem to have a math phobia?

RANADIVE: Well, I believe that math is going to trump science, so it's essential that we have a strong math curriculum for kids growing up. And you can make math fun and you can make it interesting.

KEENE: You can make it fun is the heart of the matter.

RANADIVE: Yeah, in fact, you can have fantasy sports, which is all math. Everything ends up being a math problem, so whether you're trying to win a basketball, find a cure for cancer, prevent power outages, prevent lost baggage, all math problems.

KEENE: I am absolutely fascinated as a leader in the NBA, as an owner of the Sacramento Kings. The math people say America's a jockocracy. The jockocracy say math's going to get me nowhere. You're one of the few people in the nation to truly bridge this gap.

RANADIVE: Well, I believe that all the answers are in the data. We're now living at a time when we generated ten times as much data in the last couple of years as has existed in the history of mankind. So if you can find the patterns, those patterns will give answers. So math is essential.

KEENE: Math's essential for those that value your company as well. You have stated that you feel your company's undervalued. There's been all sorts of discussion of who would take out your TIBCO. Hewlett Packard, I think of IBM. Seems like IBM buys a company about every 8 hours. What kind of business would take out TIBCO and give it a proper valuation?

RANADIVE: Well, I can't say, but TIBCO is a valuable franchise we're the leaders in integration, we're the leaders in big data. Those are two of the top three priorities for most companies right now. So it's viewed as a valuable company by all the giants.

KEENE: Within that and the other mystery as we go into the autumn of 2014, is cloud-itis. Everybody's into the cloud. When you hear people that have no idea what the cloud is, talking about the cloud, how do you respond to that?

RANADIVE: Well, I think a lot of things will be put in the cloud, but perhaps not everything. And so most companies will end up with what I call a hybrid cloud. Where there will be some things in the cloud, but some things by government regulation are required to be on premise. And what TIBCO does is we provide integration so all of that works together.

KEENE: Right. Is the cloud any different than the fad of big data? Or the fad of nanosphere? I mean, are we going to have over investment in the cloud or more importantly mal-investment (ph)?

RANADIVE: Well, just like any other bubble, you go through these cycles where the latest buzzword becomes the next big thing. But the cloud is very much here to stay. So the way that people will consume technology will be through cloud-based services.

KEENE: How do you respond within TIBCO's work to the idea that all the computer jobs go to Asia, all the computer jobs go to India. Is that true?

RANADIVE: Well, I think that a lot of the jobs do go to Asia. But typically they're lower on the value chain and so most of the innovation is still happening in Silicon Valley and it's a win-win situation. So it's really not a win-lose.

KEENE: OK, I've got about 8 more questions. We didn't even get to these. Vivek Ranadive with us as well.

0733

(BREAK)

0738

KEENE: Well, part of that, and Vivek Ranadive with us with TIBCO and from India, is our diplomacy with India. The drama of Mr. Modi visiting Nepal as his first visit. Describe the symbolism of India's nascent diplomacy with the United States.

RANADIVE: The Indian community both over here as well as all Indians are very excited about Modi right now. And so the Indians are looking to how the United States reacts to Modi. And it's well known that he didn't have a visa to travel here before.

KEENE: Yes.

RANADIVE: And so throwing out the welcome mat for him is viewed as extremely important by Indians right now.

KEENE: And I would suggest within many cultures, you don't do this by telephone or by technology.

FU: It's got to be in person.

KEENE: You've got to go.

JOHNSON: Which is why Secretary Kerry has been traveling extensively.

KEENE: A little busy.

FU: Yeah. Maybe too much for one person, some might say.

0738

(BREAK)

0744

KEENE: Well, Vivek Ranadive with us who does computer systems for the likes, this is right up your alley isn't it?

RANADIVE: Well, it is. And retail is nothing more than a social network tied to perishable inventory. And every retail is in danger of getting "Amazoned" and this is the real threat that all of these companies have.

KEENE: I mean, there it is across any number of businesses.

0744

(BREAK)

0749

KEENE: TIBCO has been doing big data for years. Vivek Ranadive, Founder, Chief Executive Officer of TIBCO. Well, he knows that your LOB needs SAAS. Is that enough jargon for you?

He also respectfully suggests that the big data craze is baloney and what's needed is fast data. And I guess it's something that Bloomberg lives every single day. You need those two seconds beforehand versus the big data after the fact. You're living this aren't you?

RANADIVE: That's right. Many of the 20th century companies would have you believe that big data = big database. But those companies tell you that you've lost the customer after the customer leaves. Or that you have a power outage when you're already sitting in darkness.

And with fast data, we prevent the customer from walking out the door. We want to make the customer the offer before he leaves the aisle, not six months after he leaves.

KEENE: Well, let's talk about the aisle down the airplane. If I'm on a Delta Airlines, you represent Delta Airlines as one of your customers. What do you sell Delta Airlines or Citigroup or anybody else on fast data?

RANADIVE: So if there is a weather delay, then with slow data what would happen is that the entire airline value chain would be disrupted.

KEENE: No, I go get a large Starbucks, have three cups of coffee. And then the three hour flight, you're awake.

JOHNSON: What about the Cinnabon?

KEENE: That's right the Cinnabon.

RANADIVE: They know everything that's happening in real time. They can combine that with historical information about you. And they can give you something to make you happy even before you have a chance to become unhappy.

JOHNSON: When you say make me happy, does that mean they're going to try to sell me something or they're going to give me information? An article I might find interesting and want to read?

RANADIVE: Well, it could be information, it could perishable inventory they have. So if you're sitting at one of my games and you tweet you had cold pizza, I'd pick that up and I know that you're coming to the next game, you don't have parking, your kids are there, my hot dogs will go bad. So rather than waste the hot dogs or the parking, we give that to you and you're happy even before you become unhappy.

KEENE: Within this, Scarlet, we talked earlier about Hewlett Packard and IBM to get this conversation started on the future of TIBCO. Why is big tech so cheap? Every person including Adam Parker that comes on here says big tech is cheap?

FU: The non-social media tech company.

KEENE: Yeah. Why is big tech so inexpensively priced?

RANADIVE: I think that that's not something that should be the case. I think there's a lot of frenzy right now around companies that lose large amounts of money and they have crazy multiples. And many of the big tech companies are highly profitable, they have good cash flow. But they don't seem to be viewed as the sexy investments.

But I do believe that there is an argument to be made that many of the older companies will get replaced and so there is some justification for that line of thinking.

FU: Well, a lot of activist investors have looked at these old tech companies thinking there's a lot of opportunity there. I know that Presidium Investment Management said that it wanted to actively engage TIBCO's board in dialogue. Can you give us an update on that?

RANADIVE: Well, not really. I think that activists have been in Apple, Microsoft, Yahoo, Adobe, EMC, and I think that if you have a profitable company, that's basically well-run, you can be a target of activists. If you have a company that loses large amounts of money and has a crazy multiple, then there's nothing that the activist would do with a company like that.

KEENE: It is August. People are taking the GMATs; they're getting smarter. You were a Baker Scholar at the Harvard Business School. That's the pantheon. That's the LeBron James--

FU: This was after MIT.

KEENE: Yeah. The LeBron James of NBA. What should someone study within an MBA curricula? My guess is more math, more acuity and that's not there is it?

RANADIVE: Well, this last year we looked at 30 gigabytes of data, which is more data than had been generated in the entire history of the NBA just for our Sacramento Kings. So basketball to me is really a big data problem. In fact when I coach my daughter's basketball team. I converted it into a math equation and I believe that how you win games is really a math problem.

KEENE: Should LeBron have gone to Sacramento?

RANADIVE: We would have loved to--

(LAUGHTER)

JOHNSON: Yeah, I can only imagine. Hey, how do you use those 30 gigabytes of data to make my experience better when I go to watch your Sacramento Kings?

RANADIVE: So once you opt in, we know everything about you. And we pick up everything that you put out. So we can give you an experience that's extremely customized to you. Your kids could be with you. We know what your likes are. We know what your dislikes are.

JOHNSON: So literally if I tweet next Tuesday I'm with my best bud and we're at bah-bah-bah-bum, somehow that gets stored and you use that information?

RANADIVE: That's right. So, like I said earlier, even if you say you had cold pizza or you are with your bud, we know everything. And at the root of everything we have what we call a psychological router where we can take sentiment and figure out what kind of actions will convert that into intention and then into action. So again it's all about marrying the social network to the perishable inventory we have.

JOHNSON: I don't know if I should be scared or think this is really cool. Because literally you're using, I'm putting all this out there on social media but you're actually using it.

FU: It's a little too late for that if you're putting that out.

JOHNSON: Yeah, right.

RANADIVE: And it's if you opt in. If you opt in then you start getting the cool stuff.

FU: Vivek Ranadive, CEO, Founder, Chairman of TIBDO, and by the way he was also Grand Marshall at the India Day Parade yesterday in New York City. So that's why he was in town. That was a lot of fun?

RANADIVE: It was a blast. There were I think 150,000 people there.

JOHNSON: Oh my gosh.

RANADIVE: And the mayor was there--

JOHNSON: In one parade?

RANADIVE: In one parade, they had Madison Avenue shut down and it was a huge honor to be a part of it.

0755

(BREAK)

0757

KEENE: Again Vivek, thank you so much. Vivek Ranadive with TIBCO and the Sacramento Kings as well.

RANADIVE: Thank you.

0758

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

AUGUST 18, 2014

ADAM JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG NEWS

KEENE: Within this and within what we see in Ferguson, Missouri, sport has always brought America together. Somewhat reluctantly--

RANADIVE: Right.

KEENE: I can remember some of that as a kid. What needs to be done right now given the events of the past week?

RANADIVE: Well, we actually have a player Ben McLemore who's from the St. Louis area. He had great sympathy for the protesters. And he's been posting to Instagram. He's actually in China right now representing the Kings.

KEENE: Mm-hmm.

RANADIVE: And I think full transparency is what everybody is asking for. And, as you said, sport is the great unifier. All we care about in basketball is do we have game? And that's really what America is about.

ADAM JOHNSON, HOST, BLOOMBERG TELEVISION: Well, you talk about a great unifier, I remember when Yao Ming because the first Chinese player in the NBA and you have now just brought in the first India player, Sim Bhullar, if I've got his name right. He's like 7'5 and 360 pounds. How's this going to change the game?

RANADIVE: Well, I believe that basketball could be one of the most popular sports in India. I have this vision -- I call it NBA 3.0, making basketball the global sport of the 21st century. And markets like India and China are going to help make it that.

RANADIVE: No, no, no.

(LAUGHTER)

RANADIVE: Well, that is true. We have the rupee isn't a convertible currency.

KEENE: Right.

RANADIVE: So you could only have a little bit converted. And so I had about $50 when I showed up.

KEENE: Very good. I hope you didn't switch it at American Express, because you would have gotten killed back then. Vivek Ranadive with us from TIBCO. We have so much to talk about, about his success in computers as well.

0710

(BREAK)

0724

SCARLET FU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Vivek Ranadive, you played a big role in digitizing Wall Street. So when you hear about the banks recovering, resurging really, what are your thoughts in terms of how much more they should be utilizing technology?

It will be a social network attached to a computer program. And so I don't think they use a lot of technology right now. I think the best is yet to come.

FU: The best is yet to come, Vivek Ranadive, our guest host for the hour.

0725

(BREAK)

0729

KEENE: Good morning, everyone. "This Matters Now" to our guest host. Vivek Ranadive runs TIBCO. They are the bridge for countless big companies interacting with customers. Think Citigroup Asia and Delta Airlines, just as two examples.

Mr. Ranadive landed in Cambridge with the proverbial $50 and dreams. After MIT, after corporate success, he still knows math is what matters. This is a major American debate. RANADIVE: Yeah, in fact, you can have fantasy sports, which is all math. Everything ends up being a math problem, so whether you're trying to win a basketball, find a cure for cancer, prevent power outages, prevent lost baggage, all math problems.

RANADIVE: Well, I believe that all the answers are in the data. We're now living at a time when we generated ten times as much data in the last couple of years as has existed in the history of mankind. So if you can find the patterns, those patterns will give answers. So math is essential.

KEENE: Math's essential for those that value your company as well. You have stated that you feel your company's undervalued. There's been all sorts of discussion of who would take out your TIBCO. Hewlett Packard, I think of IBM. Seems like IBM buys a company about every 8 hours. What kind of business would take out TIBCO and give it a proper valuation?

RANADIVE: Well, I can't say, but TIBCO is a valuable franchise we're the leaders in integration, we're the leaders in big data. Those are two of the top three priorities for most companies right now. So it's viewed as a valuable company by all the giants.

KEENE: Within that and the other mystery as we go into the autumn of 2014, is cloud-itis. Everybody's into the cloud. When you hear people that have no idea what the cloud is, talking about the cloud, how do you respond to that?

RANADIVE: Well, I think a lot of things will be put in the cloud, but perhaps not everything. And so most companies will end up with what I call a hybrid cloud. Where there will be some things in the cloud, but some things by government regulation are required to be on premise. And what TIBCO does is we provide integration so all of that works together.

KEENE: Right. Is the cloud any different than the fad of big data? Or the fad of nanosphere? I mean, are we going to have over investment in the cloud or more importantly mal-investment (ph)?

RANADIVE: Well, just like any other bubble, you go through these cycles where the latest buzzword becomes the next big thing. But the cloud is very much here to stay. So the way that people will consume technology will be through cloud-based services.

KEENE: How do you respond within TIBCO's work to the idea that all the computer jobs go to Asia, all the computer jobs go to India. Is that true?

RANADIVE: Well, I think that a lot of the jobs do go to Asia. But typically they're lower on the value chain and so most of the innovation is still happening in Silicon Valley and it's a win-win situation. So it's really not a win-lose.

KEENE: OK, I've got about 8 more questions. We didn't even get to these. Vivek Ranadive with us as well.

0733

(BREAK)

0738

KEENE: Well, part of that, and Vivek Ranadive with us with TIBCO and from India, is our diplomacy with India. The drama of Mr. Modi visiting Nepal as his first visit. Describe the symbolism of India's nascent diplomacy with the United States.

RANADIVE: The Indian community both over here as well as all Indians are very excited about Modi right now. And so the Indians are looking to how the United States reacts to Modi. And it's well known that he didn't have a visa to travel here before.

KEENE: Yes.

RANADIVE: And so throwing out the welcome mat for him is viewed as extremely important by Indians right now.

KEENE: And I would suggest within many cultures, you don't do this by telephone or by technology.

FU: It's got to be in person.

KEENE: You've got to go.

JOHNSON: Which is why Secretary Kerry has been traveling extensively.

KEENE: A little busy.

FU: Yeah. Maybe too much for one person, some might say.

0738

(BREAK)

0744

KEENE: Well, Vivek Ranadive with us who does computer systems for the likes, this is right up your alley isn't it?

RANADIVE: Well, it is. And retail is nothing more than a social network tied to perishable inventory. And every retail is in danger of getting "Amazoned" and this is the real threat that all of these companies have.

KEENE: I mean, there it is across any number of businesses.

0744

(BREAK)

0749

KEENE: TIBCO has been doing big data for years. Vivek Ranadive, Founder, Chief Executive Officer of TIBCO. Well, he knows that your LOB needs SAAS. Is that enough jargon for you?

He also respectfully suggests that the big data craze is baloney and what's needed is fast data. And I guess it's something that Bloomberg lives every single day. You need those two seconds beforehand versus the big data after the fact. You're living this aren't you?

RANADIVE: That's right. Many of the 20th century companies would have you believe that big data = big database. But those companies tell you that you've lost the customer after the customer leaves. Or that you have a power outage when you're already sitting in darkness.

And with fast data, we prevent the customer from walking out the door. We want to make the customer the offer before he leaves the aisle, not six months after he leaves.

KEENE: Well, let's talk about the aisle down the airplane. If I'm on a Delta Airlines, you represent Delta Airlines as one of your customers. What do you sell Delta Airlines or Citigroup or anybody else on fast data?

RANADIVE: So if there is a weather delay, then with slow data what would happen is that the entire airline value chain would be disrupted.

KEENE: No, I go get a large Starbucks, have three cups of coffee. And then the three hour flight, you're awake.

JOHNSON: What about the Cinnabon?

KEENE: That's right the Cinnabon.

RANADIVE: They know everything that's happening in real time. They can combine that with historical information about you. And they can give you something to make you happy even before you have a chance to become unhappy.

JOHNSON: When you say make me happy, does that mean they're going to try to sell me something or they're going to give me information? An article I might find interesting and want to read?

RANADIVE: Well, it could be information, it could perishable inventory they have. So if you're sitting at one of my games and you tweet you had cold pizza, I'd pick that up and I know that you're coming to the next game, you don't have parking, your kids are there, my hot dogs will go bad. So rather than waste the hot dogs or the parking, we give that to you and you're happy even before you become unhappy.

KEENE: Within this, Scarlet, we talked earlier about Hewlett Packard and IBM to get this conversation started on the future of TIBCO. Why is big tech so cheap? Every person including Adam Parker that comes on here says big tech is cheap?

FU: The non-social media tech company.

KEENE: Yeah. Why is big tech so inexpensively priced?

RANADIVE: I think that that's not something that should be the case. I think there's a lot of frenzy right now around companies that lose large amounts of money and they have crazy multiples. And many of the big tech companies are highly profitable, they have good cash flow. But they don't seem to be viewed as the sexy investments.

But I do believe that there is an argument to be made that many of the older companies will get replaced and so there is some justification for that line of thinking.

FU: Well, a lot of activist investors have looked at these old tech companies thinking there's a lot of opportunity there. I know that Presidium Investment Management said that it wanted to actively engage TIBCO's board in dialogue. Can you give us an update on that?

RANADIVE: Well, not really. I think that activists have been in Apple, Microsoft, Yahoo, Adobe, EMC, and I think that if you have a profitable company, that's basically well-run, you can be a target of activists. If you have a company that loses large amounts of money and has a crazy multiple, then there's nothing that the activist would do with a company like that.

KEENE: It is August. People are taking the GMATs; they're getting smarter. You were a Baker Scholar at the Harvard Business School. That's the pantheon. That's the LeBron James--

FU: This was after MIT.

KEENE: Yeah. The LeBron James of NBA. What should someone study within an MBA curricula? My guess is more math, more acuity and that's not there is it?

RANADIVE: Well, this last year we looked at 30 gigabytes of data, which is more data than had been generated in the entire history of the NBA just for our Sacramento Kings. So basketball to me is really a big data problem. In fact when I coach my daughter's basketball team. I converted it into a math equation and I believe that how you win games is really a math problem.

KEENE: Should LeBron have gone to Sacramento?

RANADIVE: We would have loved to--

(LAUGHTER)

JOHNSON: Yeah, I can only imagine. Hey, how do you use those 30 gigabytes of data to make my experience better when I go to watch your Sacramento Kings?

RANADIVE: So once you opt in, we know everything about you. And we pick up everything that you put out. So we can give you an experience that's extremely customized to you. Your kids could be with you. We know what your likes are. We know what your dislikes are.

JOHNSON: So literally if I tweet next Tuesday I'm with my best bud and we're at bah-bah-bah-bum, somehow that gets stored and you use that information?

RANADIVE: That's right. So, like I said earlier, even if you say you had cold pizza or you are with your bud, we know everything. And at the root of everything we have what we call a psychological router where we can take sentiment and figure out what kind of actions will convert that into intention and then into action. So again it's all about marrying the social network to the perishable inventory we have.

JOHNSON: I don't know if I should be scared or think this is really cool. Because literally you're using, I'm putting all this out there on social media but you're actually using it.

FU: It's a little too late for that if you're putting that out.

JOHNSON: Yeah, right.

RANADIVE: And it's if you opt in. If you opt in then you start getting the cool stuff.

FU: Vivek Ranadive, CEO, Founder, Chairman of TIBDO, and by the way he was also Grand Marshall at the India Day Parade yesterday in New York City. So that's why he was in town. That was a lot of fun?

RANADIVE: It was a blast. There were I think 150,000 people there.

JOHNSON: Oh my gosh.

RANADIVE: And the mayor was there--

JOHNSON: In one parade?

RANADIVE: In one parade, they had Madison Avenue shut down and it was a huge honor to be a part of it.

0755

(BREAK)

0757

KEENE: Again Vivek, thank you so much. Vivek Ranadive with TIBCO and the Sacramento Kings as well.

RANADIVE: Thank you.

0758

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:52JS-RKC1-JCMB-G4RM-00000-00TI CFO: How Nat Semi Will Grow Our Revenue2011-04-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisNEWS & ANALYSISTechTI CFO: How Nat Semi Will Grow Our RevenueJames RogersStaff Reporter

DALLAS () --Texas Instrumentssees its $6.5 billion acquisition ofNational Semiconductoras a launch pad for selling analog chips into a vast array of everyday electrical devices, according to the company's CFO Kevin March."The combined portfolio of products can sell into any electrical device anywhere in the world," he told TheStreet. "Anything that has electricity going through it will be an opportunity for us to sell analog semiconductors into."

Texas Instruments CFO Kevin March says the company's Nat Semi deal opens the door to a vast array of electrical devices.

Analog chips play an increasingly crucial role in everyday life, converting real-world signals such as sound, pressure, temperature and electricity into the 1s and 0s used in the digital world.March noted the use of analog chips in LED lighting, cars, security cameras and TVs as a growing source of revenue. The CFO also sees a window of opportunity for Texas Instrumentsin the emerging smart energy grid market, where big tech firms includingIBMandOraclehave already made significant investments. "What makes a smart grid is smart semiconductors," said March. "We're already seeing demand occur there."The CFO explained that National Semi will add 12,000 analog parts to his company's 30,000-strong analog portfolio. March also dismissed the suggestion that the National Semi deal was the, one of its biggest customers. "Absolutely not," he said. "This was part of our ongoing strategic review to see opportunities that dovetail with our skill set."The $6.5 billion price tag for the deal has also been closely scrutinized -- Texas Instrumentsis paying a premium of almost 80% for National Semi. "We think that it's a very effective price and acquisition for our shareholders," said March. "Within three to four years after [the acquisition's] close, we would expect that our return on this acquisition would exceed our cost to capital."The finance chief also told TheStreet that he is confident that the deal will gain regulatory approval, explaining that the combined companies will still only account for 17% of the total analog semiconductor market. "The analog market is extremely competitive," he said, adding that there is little overlap in the two companies' product portfolios. Texas Instrumentsexpects the deal to close in the next six to nine months.Speaking on CNBC Tuesday, Texas InstrumentsCEO Rich Templeton discussed the analog market's strong "financial model," which March explained during his interview with TheStreet."The R&D that you spend [on analog] is relatively small compared to other semiconductor segments," he said. "The shelf life of analog products can be ten years or longer -- you get a tremendously long usage for your capital assets."Shares of Texas Instrumentsdipped 3 cents, or 0.09%, to $34.72 on Wednesday, while National Semi's stock crept up 6 cents, or 0.25%, to $24.12. --Written by James Rogers in New York. >To follow the writer on Twitter, go to.>To submit a news tip, send an email to:.

urn:contentItem:6041-Y691-DXVP-V440-00000-00Ticker: Market Basket to open Warwick, R.I. store; Microsoft drops facial recognition tech2020-06-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisMAINPg. 16ATicker: Market Basket to open Warwick, R.I. store; Microsoft drops facial recognition tech

Grocer to open in Warwick, R.I.

Massachusetts-based supermarket chain Market Basket has announced plans for a second Rhode Island store.

The 89,000-square-foot store in Warwick expected to open next year will be located at a site that was previously home to a Sam's Club and later an At Home store, according to a statement from Mayor Joseph Solomon and Market Basket President and CEO Arthur T. Demoulas.

"Our city's central location in the state, combined with our growing business climate, continue to make Warwick a natural choice for multiple companies looking to expand their reach in the Ocean State," Solomon said.

Microsoft won't sell tech to cops

Microsoft has become the third big tech company this week to say it won't sell its facial recognition software to police, following similar moves by Amazon and IBM.

Microsoft's president and chief counsel, Brad Smith, announced the decision and called on Congress to regulate the technology during a Washington Post video event on Thursday.

"We've decided we will not sell facial recognition technology to police departments in the United States until we have a national law in place, grounded in human rights, that will govern this technology," Smith said.

The trio of tech giants is stepping back from law-enforcement use of systems that have faced criticism for incorrectly identifying people with darker skin.

-- HERALD WIRE SERVICES

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X5Y-GBX1-JBSN-31YX-00000-00Ticker Tape: A Financial Briefing by Baruch College's Investment Management Group2019-09-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 1Ticker Tape: A Financial Briefing by Baruch College's Investment Management GroupGloria Ghita

Technology sector headlines over the summer were dominated by the trade dispute between the United States and China, uncertainty in the semiconductor industry, a large number of tech initial public offerings, regulatory cases against Big Tech and the ongoing growth in cloud.

Cloud, date centers and 5G connectivity remain the largest investment categories spoken about, with cloud growth driving revenue growth across technology companies.

Less talked about are cognitive computing and automation tools, which are now under a spotlight for vastly improving customer insights and increase efficiency.

The advancement of digital tools has allowed companies to better analyze data and gain insights on not just customers, but also competitors.

Efficiency is also growing in the bankruptcy process, and the restructuring afterwards as tech companies play a larger role in assisting companies.

Antitrust investigations continue in the United States, with the House Judiciary Committee asking for a variety of documents including emails between executives, financial statements and information about competitors, market share, mergers and key business decisions from big tech executives.

These executives include Amazon's CEO Jeff Bezos, Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg, Apple's CEO Tim Cook and Google's Larry Page, Sergey Brin and Eric Schmidt.

It's very unlikely these companies will give such access to the house committee, so negotiations over the documents requested are likely to commence soon. Several other investigations are underway against Big Tech, including investigations from the Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission, Texas AG Group and NY AG Group.

However, any U.S. action against Big Tech is likely years away considering the large ramp-up in spending such companies have put in place to influence antitrust discourse, and that any sanctions against the companies must be imposed by federal or state law enforcers, not congress.

Despite that, technology companies might not wait for the U.S. to act.

Microsoft CLO Brad Smith recently came out and said, "The laws around the world are going to change, and because technology is so global, American companies will adopt a new approach even if the U.S. Congress does nothing"

However, his call for regulation is skeptical as any laws geared to make internet platforms more accountable for their content pose a greater threat to competition than Microsoft.

On another note, 2019 has been an extremely active year for tech IPOs. Despite Uber and Lyft's disappointing performances, top tech IPOs have outperformed the S&P 500 this year at a 67% gain, including Cloudflare which jumped 20% on its first trading day Sept. 13.

There are many caveats in this comparison, including it does not factor in market caps, lock-up expirations and most notably, the necessity of Beyond Meat in the IPO basket, which is up 524% since its market debut.

Following Beyond Meat's stellar performance is videoconferencing company Zoom, up 120%, and security vendor CrowdStrike, up 91%. The biggest laggard is Lyft being down 36%, followed by Uber which is down 26% and e-commerce company The RealReal, down by 15%.

From a macro viewpoint, technology companies continue to expand into emerging markets, swallowing currency headwinds and highlighting the risks of continued geopolitical uncertainties; including the United States and China trade dispute, unpredictability in China and declining smartphone demand.

Cloud computing continues to be the center of attention in the tech industry with significant margin improvements, followed by artificial intelligence computing, data centers, cybersecurity solutions, 5G connectivity and "internet of thing."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X41-SJW1-JBSN-32PK-00000-00Ticker Tape A Financial Briefing by Baruch College s Investment Management Group -- the ticker2019-09-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 1Ticker Tape A Financial Briefing by Baruch College s Investment Management Group -- the tickerGloria Ghita

Technology sector headlines over the summer were dominated by the trade dispute between the United States and China, uncertainty in the semiconductor industry, a large number of tech initial public offerings, regulatory cases against Big Tech and the ongoing growth in cloud.

Cloud, date centers and 5G connectivity remain the largest investment categories spoken about, with cloud growth driving revenue growth across technology companies.

Less talked about are cognitive computing and automation tools, which are now under a spotlight for vastly improving customer insights and increase efficiency.

The advancement of digital tools has allowed companies to better analyze data and gain insights on not just customers, but also competitors.

Efficiency is also growing in the bankruptcy process, and the restructuring afterwards as tech companies play a larger role in assisting companies.

Antitrust investigations continue in the United States, with the House Judiciary Committee asking for a variety of documents including emails between executives, financial statements and information about competitors, market share, mergers and key business decisions from big tech executives.

These executives include Amazon's CEO Jeff Bezos, Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg, Apple's CEO Tim Cook and Google's Larry Page, Sergey Brin and Eric Schmidt.

It's very unlikely these companies will give such access to the house committee, so negotiations over the documents requested are likely to commence soon. Several other investigations are underway against Big Tech, including investigations from the Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission, Texas AG Group and NY AG Group.

However, any U.S. action against Big Tech is likely years away considering the large ramp-up in spending such companies have put in place to influence antitrust discourse, and that any sanctions against the companies must be imposed by federal or state law enforcers, not congress.

Despite that, technology companies might not wait for the U.S. to act.

Microsoft CLO Brad Smith recently came out and said, "The laws around the world are going to change, and because technology is so global, American companies will adopt a new approach even if the U.S. Congress does nothing"

However, his call for regulation is skeptical as any laws geared to make internet platforms more accountable for their content pose a greater threat to competition than Microsoft.

On another note, 2019 has been an extremely active year for tech IPOs. Despite Uber and Lyft's disappointing performances, top tech IPOs have outperformed the S&P 500 this year at a 67% gain, including Cloudflare which jumped 20% on its first trading day Sept. 13.

There are many caveats in this comparison, including it does not factor in market caps, lock-up expirations and most notably, the necessity of Beyond Meat in the IPO basket, which is up 524% since its market debut.

Following Beyond Meat's stellar performance is videoconferencing company Zoom, up 120%, and security vendor CrowdStrike, up 91%. The biggest laggard is Lyft being down 36%, followed by Uber which is down 26% and e-commerce company The RealReal, down by 15%.

From a macro viewpoint, technology companies continue to expand into emerging markets, swallowing currency headwinds and highlighting the risks of continued geopolitical uncertainties; including the United States and China trade dispute, unpredictability in China and declining smartphone demand.

Cloud computing continues to be the center of attention in the tech industry with significant margin improvements, followed by artificial intelligence computing, data centers, cybersecurity solutions, 5G connectivity and "internet of thing."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XR7-V5D1-F0J6-J3W5-00000-00Tide slowly starts to turn on tech's brave new world2019-12-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisCOMPANIES AND MARKETSPg. 22Tide slowly starts to turn on tech's brave new worldMax Mason | Media and marketing editor

Social media An ACCC inquiry is mobilising regulators worldwide.

"I do have one question ... what took you so long?"

It was an awkward introduction to one of the biggest shifts in Facebook's attitude towards journalism and the media industry.

But one could hardly be surprised. News Corp global chief executive Robert Thomson had taken the stage with the social media giant's founder and chief executive Mark Zuckerberg in October to announce a new initiative for Facebook to pay for news.

Thomson, a quirky but hard-nosed Australian journalist who rose to the top of Rupert Murdoch's media empire, has been one of the loudest global voices calling for action on "big tech". And despite his target finally relenting, as Zuckerberg did that day, he was ready to stir the pot further.

"After the last few years, I now have an appreciation that that is the nicest thing he could have said because that means he actually thinks we've done something good," Zuckerberg laughed. "I will take that as a compliment."

However, the model Facebook agreed to with News Corp and other US publishers is far from perfect. It still leaves Facebook as the arbiter of which news media deserves to be paid for its work on the platform. Facebook is paying some publishers in the US between $US1 million ($1.5 million) and $US3 million, but not all.

Still, it was a perfect confluence of events in every corner of the world. Despite Facebook and Google executives downplaying the significance of a regulatory inquiry going on down in Australia, that too played a major role in bringing Facebook to a point where it knew the tide had turned against it.

"In my view, Facebook would not have contemplated that a year ago ... that demonstrates a willingness to move," Australian Competition and Consumer Commission chairman Rod Sims says.

The ACCC's code of conduct could also be a model for other jurisdictions.

Facebook could see change coming in Australia driven by the ACCC and local media companies. The ACCC's inquiry has also been a major input into a similar inquiry in the UK, and has been heavily referenced by the UK competition regulator and in submissions to its inquiry. Sims has also briefed competition regulators and lawmakers in the US states and Europe on his plans.

"I think every internet platform has a responsibility to try to help fund and form partnerships to support news," Zuckerberg said in the fireside chat with Thomson.

Meanwhile, Facebook is coming under increasing pressure in its home market. Zuckerberg, his Google counterpart Sundar Pichai and other tech executives have been dragged to Capitol Hill to front US lawmakers with increasing regularity in recent years over a range of issues. The Wall Street Journal, owned by News Corp, reported on Thursday that the US Federal Trade Commission is seeking an injunction over antitrust concerns to do with its apps and interactions with rivals.

Now the Morrison government has taken up Sims' recommendation for a code of conduct to force tech giants like Facebook and Google to negotiate with local media companies over the sharing of revenue, data and algorithm changes.

The government has given the tech giants a chance to come up with a voluntary code, along with industry and the ACCC, before stating it will force a mandatory code on them in November if they can't come to a satisfactory agreement. Facebook and Google both initially came out strong against a code of conduct. Google stepped back from that position, later calling it a "sensible" idea.

Hugh Marks, chief executive of Nine, which owns The Australian Financial Review, says the code provides a clear timeline and method for media big tech to find a solution that "we ultimately believe will be a win-win not only for our industry and the people that work in it, but the social platforms as well".

The devil will be in the detail - particularly whether the government has enough bite to come down on Facebook and Google with something that helps local media companies should the tech giants refuse to come to the table on a voluntary basis.

In the UK, the Competition and Markets Authority is undertaking a similar study into digital platforms and online advertising with a final report due by mid-2020. And Facebook and Google could face a similar code of conduct to govern their business relationships with other players in the market to tackle the issue of market power.

"We will consider whether ex-ante rules are required to overcome any concern we identify in relation to market power in consumer-facing markets or digital advertising markets," the CMA says in its statement of scope.

"Potential areas that could be covered through such a regime could include: rules on the terms on which platforms transact with other market participants, relating for example to discrimination and pricing; increased transparency in the different activities undertaken by the platforms; and separation between certain activities in the digital advertising value chain."

UK media outlets such as broadcaster Channel 4 and Guardian Media Group are rallying behind the idea of a code of conduct, including revenue sharing, to help mitigate the imbalance of bargaining power with technology giants and the take-it-or-leave-it terms they are forced to accept on Facebook and Google.

"Given the similarity in these trading terms and the lack of strong competition in the market, Channel 4 is left with little choice but to accept the revenue shares we are offered by the digital giants," Channel 4 says in its submission. "However, these fail to take account of the expense we incur when producing premium, PSB-quality content."

There's a brave new world forming for big tech. It's now up to government to ensure the industry gets there.

urn:contentItem:5WS3-TFD1-JC8Y-81X2-00000-00Tide turns on social media giants in US;California leads legislative moves with privacy law modelled in part on GDPR2019-08-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisFINANCEPg. 6Tide turns on social media giants in USCalifornia leads legislative moves with privacy law modelled in part on GDPRSuzanne Lynch

As Democrats reeled from Donald Trump's shock victory in the 2016 US presidential election, thoughts soon turned to who could take on the Republican president in 2020. One name that surfaced was that of Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg. Speculation about the young executive's political ambitions were prompted when he set off on a "listening tour" across the country, despite denials that he was mulling a bid for office.

Less than a year later things looked very different.

In November 2017 Zuckerberg was summoned to Washington to testify before Congress. Under questioning by two Senate committees, the Facebook founder was probed about his company's role in Russia's interference in the 2016 election. Concerns about Facebook had surfaced earlier in the year when US intelligence services announced that Russia had tried to influence US voters. Zuckerberg initially dismissed suggestions of the company's involvement as a "pretty crazy idea," saying voters "make decisions based on their lived experience".

It was a comment he would come to regret. In September 2017, as revelations emerged that a Russian-based institution had spent thousands on politically divisive ads on Facebook, he posted a statement on the platform apologising for the comment.

Political concerns Zuckerberg's fall from darling of the left to the target of political concerns about the power of tech companies

reflects a shift in attitude in the United States towards social media giants.

Since the establishment of companies such as Google, Facebook and Twitter more than a decade ago, the United States has taken a laissez-faire approach to regulation compared with Europe. Fuelled by growing concern in countries such as Germany - a country acutely aware of the importance of citizens' privacy given its history - the European Union moved quickly to regulate tech companies, not only in terms of user privacy, but also in the fields of competition and tax. Following years of negotiations in Brussels and Strasbourg, the EU's GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) entered into force a year ago, introducing sweeping new powers for consumers. Simultaneously the EU's powerful anti-trust arm opened competition inquiries into companies such as Google, amid alarm about their dominance in the market.

Google was hit by multibillion-dollar fines, while Amazon remains under scrutiny by Brussels over how it used third-party data to boost its own sales.

Models and motivations

In the US, the attitude was very different, with regulators slow to question the models and motivations of the tech sector. In 2015 President Obama angered the EU when he suggested that EU inquiries into companies such as Google and Facebook were "commercially driven". He implied that Europe was simply annoyed that its own companies were unable to compete with the US. "We have owned the internet. Our companies have created it, expanded it, perfected it in ways that they can't compete," he said.

Relations deteriorated further when WikiLeaks revealed that the US National Security Agency had tapped German chancellor Angela Merkel's phone for decades.

Four years later, the attitude in the US is very different.

The first sign that change was in the offing emerged last year when California introduced a new privacy law. Modelled in part on the EU's landmark GDPR law, the California Consumer Privacy Act is due to come into effect early next year. Under the regulation, consumers will be allowed to view the types of data collected by companies and request the right for companies to delete data. In addition, companies will be required to include an "opt-out" link conspicuously on their website, whereby users can request that their data is not sold to a third party.

Several other states are considering introducing their own version of the law.

The imminent introduction of the new regulations has sparked alarm among tech companies, and prompted a scramble in Congress to come up with a US-wide approach to privacy.

"Basically, the game was up in terms of ignoring tech regulation any longer. California's law has completely changed the debate. The writing has been on the wall for some time that the US needs to do something when it comes to oversight," said one policy official involved in efforts to introduce the new privacy law in Washington.

But tech companies' enthusiastic support for the introduction of a federal law, and Washington's apparent willingness to come up with a new regulatory system for tech companies after years of sitting on its hands, have prompted scepticism.

Many suspect that the reason for the new-found interest in regulating tech companies at a federal level is because industry is hoping that the new national rules will be weaker than California's law.

Echoing what took place in the European Parliament four or five years ago, there is now intense debate taking place in Congress, and within the White House, about how far new restrictions on how companies handle data should go. Tech companies and consumer rights advocates are pouring resources into lobbying members of congress as they shape the most significant technology regulation in a generation.

The pressure on big tech companies has intensified in recent weeks. Democratic presidential contender Elizabeth Warren has called for the break-up of tech companies such as Amazon and Google, arguing that they harm competition by prioritising their own services on their platforms and buying up competitors.

Her proposal followed an explosive New York Times article by Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes in which he called for the company he founded with Zuckerberg to be broken up and more tightly regulated.

The woes of the tech giant have continued this month as the US Federal Trade Commission reached a $5 billion settlement with Facebook - the biggest in its history, though still a fraction of the company's annual revenue.

The regulator alleged that the social media company had eroded privacy rights and misused customers' data to target advertisements. The justice department's anti-trust division also announced an investigation into social media platforms to see if powerful tech companies were "engaging in practices that have reduced competition, stifled innovation or otherwise harmed consumers".

Tech companies have hit back, arguing that too much regulation may allow Chinese competitors to muscle in on the sector, in ways that would be bad for democracy and privacy.

But the American public is reassessing its views on Silicon Valley for other reasons amid growing awareness that the rapid development of the US tech sector has brought downsides.

The greater San Francisco area is suffering from an acute housing crisis, with rents the highest in the country. Much of this is a side effect of the booming tech industry, with a new raft of Silicon valley IPOs slated for this year likely to push up prices even further.

Amazon's decision to pull out of a planned investment in Queens in New York after concern was raised by many local residents including congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, also suggests that American consumers are beginning to question if the relentless expansion of big tech is really benefiting them.

Negative headlines

A continuing slew of negative headlines regarding the role of social media companies in promoting fake news is also contributing to the "techlash".

The circulation of a doctored video purporting to show House speaker Nancy Pelosi slurring her words on Facebook and Twitter again highlighted the role social media companies play in online disinformation - a major concern for the US ahead of the 2020 election.

Concerns are not just emanating from the left. Trump, in many ways the master manipulator of Twitter, convened a "social media summit" at the White House earlier this month at which he berated social media companies for exhibiting liberal bias and silencing his supporters.

Josh Hawley, a young Republican senator from Missouri, is bringing forward a new Bill that would remove tech giants' protection from liability over third-party content.

Nonetheless, threats to curb the power of online giants are still likely to meet resistance in Washington.

At a Senate committee hearing in May, which was addressed by data-protection experts including Ireland's Helen Dixon, several Republican members warned about excessive regulation as Congress mulls a federal law as an alternative to the Californian model.

"At the same time that we want to protect privacy, we want to avoid a regulatory system that imposes unnecessary burdens and that threatens jobs," said senator Ted Cruz. Quoting research last year from the US national bureau of economic research, he claimed that Europe had lost up to 39,000 tech jobs due to GDPR.

Legislators will also be mindful of another aspect of American consumers' relationship with tech companies. Technology giants have been driving the strong performance of the stock market, an upward trajectory that has benefited millions of Americans who own saving and retirement accounts.

Many legislators will be loath to do anything to jeopardise that success. While the tide is turning when it comes to the regulation of tech companies, the coming months will be crucial in determining whether the change of perspective is here to stay.

urn:contentItem:5YY9-K901-F03R-N18T-00000-00Tiger Global Management€™s Top 1st-Quarter Updates2020-05-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:50ZLexisNexisTiger Global Management€™s Top 1st-Quarter Updates

May 20, 2020( GuruFocus.com: http://www.gurufocus.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Tiger Global Management's Top 1st-Quarter Updates - GuruFocus.com Tiger Global Management's Top 1st-Quarter Updates - GuruFocus.com   https://www.gurufocus.com/ic/space.php?do=article&uid=561517&author=Margaret+Moran Bookmark of this page has been deleted. Tech-focused hedge fund invests in Alibaba, trims UberTiger Global Management recently disclosed its portfolio updates for the first quarter of 2020, which ended on March 31. Tiger Global Management was founded in 2001 by Chase Coleman[1] (Trades[2], Portfolio[3]) after hedge fund legend Julian Robertson[4] (Trades[5], Portfolio[6]) gave him $25 million to start his own fund. The fund's strategy is to deploy capital globally, focusing on big tech stocks as well as early and late stage venture, post-initial public offering, private equity and secondary market small caps.

In January, the firm closed on a new $3.75 billion fund for investing in private technology, revealing continued investor enthusiasm for tech companies. Using the above investing criteria, the firm established three new common stock holdings during the quarter, most notably Athene Holding Ltd (NYSE:ATH[7]), and added to several other positions, including Workday Inc. (NASDAQ:WDAY[8]) and Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. (NYSE:BABA[9]). It also sold out of two holdings and reduced others, including Uber Technologies Inc. (NYSE:UBER[10]). Athene Holding The firm's biggest new buy for the quarter was Athene Holding, which it acquired 7,464,626 shares of, impacting the equity portfolio by 1.12%. During the quarter, shares traded at an average price of $40.16. https://www.gurufocus.com/guru/chase+coleman/stock-picksAthene is a retirement services company that issues, reinsures and acquires retirement savings for a population with an increasing percentage of old and retired persons. The company is headquartered in Bermuda for tax reasons, though its main clientele is in the U.S. On May 20, shares of Athene traded around $26.69 for a market cap of $5.2 billion and a price-earnings ratio of 14.35. The Peter Lynch chart indicates that the stock is trading near its fair value.   https://www.gurufocus.com/stock/ATH/summaryGuruFocus gives the company a financial strength score of 4 out of 10 and a profitability score of 5 out of 10. The cash-debt ratio of 3.91 is higher than the industry median of 2.29. As shown in the chart below, the company has a general uptrend of revenue and net income, though results are affected by the stock market prices of assets.   https://www.gurufocus.com/stock/ATH/chart?q=N4IglgdgJmDGCGAXA9gJwM4gFynS2A1tgNqgECmAntiKuQG7kQCu5IANCBPALZtYgASgyasOISvAAeYTFgBMnWAAtyhclGwAzeABt05AL7syVGhHKIA%2BpFjI%2B47g4EA5SwAIAkhDsPOkmTlFEBU1Ck0sHX0jAF1ONWQSOJDmPHswAC8NJM5ENWUIOD0k4xAoJHIAFUoAB34QeHFkGsQwZAgAWVEANT0xLGJaNXJ0dDaIcQAjeFQQZLTCAEFUWYHQGHQa3XhKK3RKHknkXRoXAE0AZQBRLEXKgAlxcikVeAgAc3rz6-F9w%2BOaHdHoZkuU8oI3p9sABGaGGIAWorkday The firm bought 2,040,000 additional shares of Workday, increasing the stake by 733.81%. The trade had a 1.60% impact on the equity portfolio. Shares were trading at an average price of $169.05 during the quarter.   https://www.gurufocus.com/guru/chase+coleman/stock-picks Headquartered in Pleasanton, California, Workday is an enterprise cloud solutions company that provides software for the management of financial assets as well as human capital. On May 20, shares of Workday traded around $159.54 for a market cap of $37.22 billion. Morningstar analyst estimates produce a forward price-earnings ratio of 73.97%, though the company has yet to turn a yearly profit.   https://www.gurufocus.com/stock/WDAY/chart?q=N4IglgdgJmDGCGAXA9gJwM4gFynS2A1tgNqgECmAntiKuQG7kQCu5IANCBPALZtYgASgyasOISvAAeYTFgBMnWAAtyhclGwAzeABt05AL7syVGhHKIA%2BpFjI%2B47g4EA5SwAIAkhDsPOkmTlFEBU1Ck0sHX0jAF1ONWQSOJDmPHswAC8NJM5ENWUIOD0k4xAoJHIAFUoAB34QeHFkGsQwZAgAWVEANT0xLGJaNXJ0dDaIcQAjeFQQZLTCAEFUWYHQGHQa3XhKK3RKHknkXRoXRYBlLAB1ABFFgE1xcikVeAgAc3qz8-F9w%2BOaLcHiBDMlynlBG9PtgAIwwwxAAGuruFocus gives Workday a financial strength score of 5 out of 10 and a profitability score of 3 out of 10. The company's cash-debt ratio of 1.24 and Altman Z-Score of 4.58 indicate that it is not in danger of bankruptcy. The three-year revenue growth rate is an impressive 26.2%, but the operating margin of -13.85% and net margin of -13.25% confirm that the company is burning more cash than it is generating.   https://www.gurufocus.com/stock/WDAY/chart?q=N4IglgdgJmDGCGAXA9gJwM4gFynS2A1tgNqgECmAntiMgA7mpKQDmA%2BgLbyouQgA0ICPA7kaAeQZNErAAQBZbrwiyApAJCV4ADzCYsARkGwAFuULko2AGbwANunIBffmSo0I5RJyV9Bw0RoAOS8FXxV1QS1dfSMQU3MKKyxbB2cAXUFzZBJM%2BIBXPGQOMAAvS1zBRHMTCDh7XJcQKCRyABVKBhp4DXoZZAh5cgh8gDV7fLEsYhBUc3J0dDABkDyiwgBBVFQSUBh0Ojt4SjZ0Sg4AI2Q7YI2AZSwAdQARDYBNDXJtU3gIFimQEF7hozpdrjQXu8QE48i1qgAlX7-bAGAxOIAAlibabaTiger Global Management added 976,000 shares, or 27.76%, to its Alibaba position, bringing the total number of shares owned to 4,491,662 and impacting the equity portfolio by 1.14%. Shares were trading at an average price of $209.23 during the quarter.   https://www.gurufocus.com/guru/chase+coleman/stock-picksAlibaba is a Chinese multinational conglomerate with holdings in e-commerce, retail, internet and technology assets, among many others. By volume, Alibaba is the largest e-commerce company in the world, with millions of merchants and hundreds of millions of users. On May 20, shares of Alibaba traded around $215.04 for a market cap of $573.99 billion and a price-earnings ratio of 23.11. According to the Peter Lynch chart, the stock trades above its intrinsic value but below its median historical valuation.   https://www.gurufocus.com/stock/BABA/summaryAlibaba has a GuruFocus financial strength score of 7 out of 10 and a profitability score of 10 out of 10. It has a cash-debt ratio of 2.92 and an Altman Z-Score of 6.82, indicating high financial stability. The operating margin of 19.21% is higher than 94.86% of competitors. Revenue and net income have grown steadily in recent years.   https://www.gurufocus.com/stock/BABA/chart?q=N4IglgdgJmDGCGAXA9gJwM4gFynS2A1tgNqgECmAntiKuQG7kQCu5IANCBPALZtYgASgyasOISvAAeYTFgBMnWAAtyhclGwAzeABt05AL7syVGhHKIA%2BpFjI%2B47g4EA5SwAIAkhDsPOkmTlFEBU1Ck0sHX0jAF1ONWQSOJDmPHswAC8NJM5ENWUIOD0k4xAoJHIAFUoAB34QeHFkGsQwZAgAWVEANT0xLGJaNXJ0dDaIcQAjeFQQZLTCAEFUWYHQGHQa3XhKK3RKHknkXRoXAE0AZQBRLAAhRfvxcikVeAgAc3rz6-F9w%2BOaPdHoZkuU8oI3p9sABGaGGIAUber Technologies The firm reduced its holding of Uber Technologies by 11,640,071 shares, or 53.85%, bringing the total number of shares owned to 9,974,716. The trade had a -1.19% impact on the equity portfolio. During the quarter, shares traded for an average price of $33.   https://www.gurufocus.com/guru/chase+coleman/stock-picks Most famous for being the world's largest ridesharing company, Uber also offers food delivery, electric bikes and scooters and has various technology projects. The company is based in San Francisco and operates in 63 countries worldwide. On May 20, shares of Uber traded around $34.38 for a market cap of $59.63 billion. Excluding its first quarter as a publicly traded company, which was affected by divestments, the company has not had a profitable quarter.   https://www.gurufocus.com/stock/UBER/chart?q=N4IglgdgJmDGCGAXA9gJwM4gFynS2A1tgNqgECmAntiKuQG7kQCu5IANCBPALZtYgASgyasOISvAAeYTFgBMnWAAtyhclGwAzeABt05AL7syVGhHKIA%2BpFjI%2B47g4EA5SwAIAkhDsPOkmTlFEBU1Ck0sHX0jAF1ONWQSOJDmPHswAC8NJM5ENWUIOD0k4xAoJHIAFUoAB34QAEdxZBrEMGQIAFlRADU9MSxiWjVydHR2iHEAI3hUEGS0wgBBVDnB0Bh0Gt14Sit0Sh4p5F0aFwBNAGUAUSwAVQAha8FxcikVeAgAc3qLm-EDkcTjRHs8QIZkuU8oJPj9sABGeGGIAGuruFocus gives the company a financial strength rating of 4 out of 10 and a profitability rating of 1 out of 10. The cash-debt ratio of 1.06 is lower than 62.81% of competitors, while the Altman Z-Score of 0.58 means that the company may need to source additional liquidity to avoid bankruptcy. The operating margin of -60.48% and net margin of -71.48% indicate that the company is burning through significantly more cash than it is earning.   https://www.gurufocus.com/stock/UBER/summary Portfolio overview As of the quarter's end, the firm held shares in 74 stocks valued at a total of $16.61 billion. Its top holdings were JD.com Inc. (JD) with 12.35% of the equity portfolio, Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) with 10.25% and Facebook Inc. (FB) with 8.79%. In terms of portfolio weighting, the firm was most invested in technology, consumer cyclical and communication services.   https://www.gurufocus.com/guru/chase+coleman/sector-weighting Disclosure: Author owns no shares in any of the stocks mentioned. The mention of stocks in this article does not at any point constitute an investment recommendation. Portfolio updates reflect only common stock positions as per the regulatory filings for the quarter in question and may not include changes made after the quarter ended. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VDF-BBP1-F0JP-W42V-00000-00Tighter rein on Google, Facebook2019-02-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 3Tighter rein on Google, FacebookLilly Vitorovich

Momentum is gathering around the world to increase regulation of major technology companies, including Google and Facebook, with a British government--commissioned report recommending a "news quality" regulator.

The Cairncross Review, undertaken by former journalist Dame Frances Cairncross at the request of the UK government, has proposed a "news quality" regulator to hold online platforms to account for spreading misinformation.

It also recommended that digital news products should enjoy the same tax exemption as newspapers, and the nation's public broadcaster, BBC, should face restrictions on its digital -operation.

The Cairncross review comes three months after Australia's competition regulator said -Google and Facebook had -"substantial market power", and outlined 11 recommendations, including closer scrutiny of their activities by a government -agency and tough new data collection rules.

Bridget Fair, who represents Australia's commercial free-to-air television broadcasters through industry group Free TV Australia, said there was a "growing appetite for regulatory oversight of the global tech -giants", which she supports.

"Google and Facebook are great at making money but they do it off the back of other people's content," Ms Fair told The Australian.

"We are cautious about subjective assessments of quality but there is a clear need for regulation to ensure that producers of local content, including news, can monetise their product fairly on the digital platforms," she added.

Foad Fadaghi, managing director of local tech research firm Telsyte, said there was a "growing push from governments around the world for more regulation of big tech companies given their reach and impact on democracy".

"However, it might be hard to cherrypick a handful of companies for specific regulations," Mr Fadaghi said.

"It will be hard for governments to have different rules for some companies and not others. It needs to be equitable.

"While the Cairncross review might inform the ACCC, its focus will likely be more recommendations for the regulation of digital advertising rather than journalism.

"Regulation is not necessarily bad if it can establish easy-to-implement industry guidelines, but it might be futile or draconian if it tries to manage individuals' news feeds." Richard Gingras, Google's vice-president of news, said the company had worked closely with the Cairncross inquiry and looked forward to discussing the proposals further "to ensure sustainable, high-quality journalism in the UK".

"We are committed to supporting vibrant and sustainable quality journalism, directing our users to news websites more than 10 billion times a month and sharing more than 70 per cent of any revenue generated from our ad technology with news publishers."Responses to the ACCC's digital platforms preliminary report are due by Friday, with a final report to be delivered to the federal government by June 3.
