Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TMM-HSS1-DY0W-42XJ-00000-00Tight Race In South Carolina, Heckling In Florida, New Poll In Texas; Donald Trump Pays Tribute To Pittsburgh Synagogue Shooting Victims; Apple CEO Tim Cook Calls For 'Comprehensive Federal Privacy Law;' Stock Market Volatility; Kanye's Done With Politics2018-10-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:50ZLexisNexisTight Race In South Carolina, Heckling In Florida, New Poll In Texas; Donald Trump Pays Tribute To Pittsburgh Synagogue Shooting Victims; Apple CEO Tim Cook Calls For 'Comprehensive Federal Privacy Law;' Stock Market Volatility; Kanye's Done With PoliticsLanhamFULL TEXT

LISA KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Thanks so much, Trish. The most important midterm election in the history of the world just one week from today, and by all accounts it will be a brutal sprint to the finish line. The Senate up for grabs, the House up for grabs, and so are many governor's mansions, so which party has the edge as we enter this critical homestretch? Well, first, let's go to the high-profile gubernatorial race in Florida, former Republican Congressman Ron DeSantis is battling Tallahassee's Democratic Mayor Andrew Gillum.

And several polls show Gillum still in the lead today. They each made a pitch to voters. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. RON DESANTIS (R-FL), GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE: Andrew Gillum, he may be a third rate mayor, but he is a first class demagogue and I think he's been doing this stuff throughout the whole campaign.

ANDREW GILLUM (D), GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE, FLORIDA: On November 6th right here in the State of Florida, we have a chance to send a message to Donald Trump and all of their followers that America is still America and the common sense and decency can still prevail right here in our state.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: Hallelujah. The race for Senate in Texas also a nail-biter, a new Quinnipiac poll shows Republican incumbent Ted Cruz, lying Ted, he's up by five points over the skateboarding challenger Beto O'Rourke. That number seeming to narrow by the day. Most analysts will tell you Republicans will likely hold onto the Senate. But the House, that's a vastly different story. If Democrats win in that of 23 seats, they take control. That's right. Nancy Pelosi gets her hands right the end on the scepter once more.

The stakes are very high because many Democrats have promised to impeach the president to undo the tax cuts and to generally stymie the Republican agenda and the latest real clear politics average has Democrats almost eight points ahead on that generic House ballot. That apparently has the Republican Party pretty spooked. As we are already seeing some finger- pointing as to why they may lose. But is it possible the blue wave stalls at the last moment?

Joining me now Fox News Politics Editor Chris Stirewalt. Welcome back.

CHRIS STIREWALT, FOX NEWS POLITICS EDITOR: Ma'am.

MONTGOMERY: I'm so glad your tie and my dress are of a matching hue, sir.

STIREWALT: Kiss met, meant to be. Meant to be this Tuesday.

MONTGOMERY: Great word. You win. So let's talk about this a little bit because Republicans are hoping some of these last-ditch efforts and some of the immigration passion translates to secret voters who have been hanging up on pollsters where Democrats just want to ride the donkey of history right into the stable. What do you think is going to happen?

STIREWALT: I think that your metaphors will collide somewhere over the third District of Iowa and we may all be crushed. Look, I think -- I think this. I think that people have overstated the polls. They have overstated the -- the polls are always wrong. How about this? The polls are generally right but they're always wrong somewhere, and they're always wrong somehow, and we don't know whether we're going to have Republicans outperforming a point or so which could save a bunch of House seats for them in key districts that might hold on for them, or the Democrats could outperform by three or four points because we have a hard time polling lower income and especially Hispanic voters in places like Texas --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: OK. There are certain groups that are difficult to poll and others who are just abstinent and leave it -- flat-out lie or just will not answer the phone. We saw that in 2016. That obviously changed polling. So those seem like some static variables, what are the dynamic ones? What are the ones that can actually be influenced in this last minute jockeying?

STIREWALT: So that's why the president all of a sudden is revisiting birthright citizenship. Remember, he started talking about Ted Cruz. You revisit stuff like that. You talk about the caravan. You try to keep people afraid. The goal here is you got to have people either angry or afraid. Those are the good motivators, right? You heard Andrew Gillum, be angry at Donald Trump. You challenge your -- channel your anger for Donald Trump into something, so the way that you want to keep your voters at a frenetic pace.

You want them federative and feverish because it's not enough for them to go vote. They also -- you need them to drag their spouse. Get their family, drive their mother. You want them so fired up that they're a forced multiplier and fear and anger are the politician's best tools to do those things.

MONTGOMERY: Interesting. And I don't know that a stock market that has the yips right now is helpful to that economic message that has been driving the president's improving poll numbers. That's how the president has been tweeting about it. But you're absolutely right about immigration. One thing that's interesting, there was talk of impeaching Justice Brett Kavanaugh, but with all the horrific news that we saw last week with the shooting at the Pittsburgh synagogue and, of course, with the pipe bombs, Brett Kavanaugh is way on the back burner.

Is there anything within this seven-day forecast that you see coming up that we haven't thought about that also might influence?

STIREWALT: It's the silly season now and it's hard to have it actually come in effect. But you're quite right. The consequence -- the electoral consequence, the polls are unambiguous on this count. It's a sharp turn away from the Republicans and sharp turn away from the president in the wake of the pipe bombing guy, but specifically on Saturday was unmistakable. We've seen it already. People are grossed out about the national conversation about how rough they are, and now the Democrats and Republicans are fighting about whose fault it is.

But generally, the -- here's the rule. When things aren't good, the party in power pays the price and the Republicans are the party of power.

MONTGOMERY: And they're also trying to make the case that things are good and to maintain the status quo. Now, let's say and the off chance that Republicans lose the house, who gets the blame?

STIREWALT: There will be plenty to go around and everybody will say that if only the party would have followed whatever their own ideological -- ideologically based argument was then they would have won. And none of it will matter because it will start a bitter period of recriminations. That's OK thought for whether you're a Republican or Democrat, that's OK because the real show will be one day -- one week from tomorrow when the Democratic 2020 primary starts in earnest.

MONTGOMERY: Now, the president has a lot invested in Florida, and some of the House races and certainly with the governor's race, is he somehow laying the foundation for 2020? Is that part of his two-year strategy?

STIREWALT: Yes. He can't win without Florida in 2020. And the other -- here's the big test that's coming up for Donald Trump. Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan, Wisconsin, in the upper Midwest, he has stunning victories especially in Michigan, Wisconsin, and Pennsylvania. If voters are this sour on Republicans, that's a big warning sign for his party, so he's looking at Scott Walker in Wisconsin. He's looking at host ever congressional seats in Pennsylvania. He's --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: Does Walker have a chance by the way?

STIREWALT: He's got a chance. But boy, if -- he's in for some very rough sledding and he knows it. And he's been one of the people whose been telling Republicans for six months, hey, this is happening. Get serious.

MONTGOMERY: Yes. And don't take anything for granted and certainly don't get complacent. He is one of the few people who was like, we're going to get chillax. But if he does survive, what will that do for -- how does that cement his legacy?

STIREWALT: If Scott Walker can survive this, this will be his fourth -- his fourth statewide win in like five years against all odds. And he's a guy who wore a duck hunting overcoat with a suit to be interviewed by Bret Baier yesterday, so this would just mean that he can do anything.

MONTGOMERY: He really can. I think the man can levitate quite -- he doesn't even need a hover board. Chris Stirewalt, thank you so much.

STIREWALT: You bet.

MONTGOMERY: I can't wait to see what happens this next week. President Trump always talked tough on immigration. But today, he dialed it up to 11 and said he plans to sign an executive order that would end the practice of birthright citizenship. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We can definitely do it with an act of Congress. But now they're saying I can do it just with an executive order. Now, how ridiculous. We're the only country in the world where a person comes in, has a baby, and the baby is essentially a citizen of the United States for 85 years with all of those benefits. It's ridiculous. It's ridiculous. And it has to end.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Have you talked about that with counsel?

TYRUMP: Yes, I have.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: So where in the process --

TRUMP: It's in the process. It will happen with an executive order.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: Man, those things make me nervous. Legal experts believe such an order would lead to a battle in the Supreme Court over the 14th Amendment which states that all persons, "Born or naturalized in the United States are citizens of the United States and of the state wherein they reside." But the president is facing skepticism even from some in his own party including that rascal Paul Ryan.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. PAUL RYAN (R-WI), SPEAKER OF THE UNITED STATES HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES: Well, you obviously cannot do that. You cannot end birthright citizenship with an executive order. We didn't like it when Obama tried changing immigration laws, the executive action. And, obviously, as conservatives, you know, we believe in the constitution.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: I love the constitution so much. Democratic lawmakers have roundly trashed the president as racist and accused him of demagoguery. But despite the blowback, Republican Senator Lindsey Graham says he plans to introduce legislation that would end birthright citizenship when Congress returns. There is fighting words everywhere you look on this issue. But will the president's pen be mightier than the legislative or cultural sword?

Joining me now, Cato Supreme Court Review Editor, and Senior Fellow there at the Cato Institute, it's Ilya Shapiro. He is back. Welcome back.

ILYA SHAPIRO, SENIOR FELLOW, CATO INSTITUTE: Good to be back, Kennedy.

MONTGOMERY: It is great to have you. So let's talk a little bit about this and let's talk about it from a constitutional angle because there is a bit of wiggle room you pointed out within the 14th Amendment because obviously the president cannot undo a constitutional amendment with executive order, but there is a tricky line in there which gives him some leeway. What is that?

SHAPIRO: Well, the part of the 14th Amendment opening clause that you didn't read when you quoted it. I have my handy Cato pocket constitution. Shapiro wedding edition I might add. And subject to the jurisdiction thereof that is where the debate is. That is originally that excluded the kids of diplomats, foreign armies, and Indian tribes because those are foreign sovereigns. Those are different sovereigns. They're not beholden to the United States.

At the time in 1868, there was no such thing as illegal immigrants. But I think it's a close call. There are good arguments on both sides. But I think that you would need a constitutional amendment because the kids of immigrants, tourists, what have you, unless they're diplomats or, you know, these foreign aggressors what have you, they are -- they are subject to the jurisdiction of the United States. If illegal immigrants commit crimes, form contracts, they are subject to American law.

And by the way, this is a debate about whether you need a constitutional amendment or an act of law like what Lindsey Graham is proposing. That's where the fight is going to be. I can't fathom a plausible legal argument for how the president can do this by himself. If the Justice Department offers legal counsel or whatever is hiding some sort of memo, I would love to see that because that would be some ingenious lawyering.

MONTGOMERY: Well, I agree with Paul Ryan here that I was critical of President Obama when he was issuing so many executive orders on immigration because he said he just simply couldn't work with Congress. But said he had a pen and he had a phone, and by gum, he was going to get stuff done. But as we've seen, as this president continues to undo much of President Obama's legacy. The next president is going to do the exact same thing and it's going to be even more chaotic and more confusing for people who are trying to come to this country legally.

SHAPIRO: That's right. If you -- if you live by the pen and phone, you die by the pen and phone, and I was highly critical of President Obama. The president simply doesn't get more power when Congress doesn't act. That's not part of the constitution. I think this was more of a political ploy by Donald Trump. It might be effective. We'll see what happens in the elections next week as Chris was just describing. But ultimately, the legal debate before we even get to the policy debate about whether we should end birthright citizenship.

The legal debate is going to be over Lindsey Graham's legislation. He has proposed it before. I'm not sure he can get it through Congress frankly. You would have to get rid of the legislative filibuster. I'm not sure cocaine Mitch in the Senate is willing to go there. But that's where the debate is --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: I want to bring something also because not only will you see a lot of congressional fighting if Democrats take the House and Republicans maintain the Senate. House Republicans and Senate Republicans already hate each other, so I don't see -- I don't see how they pass something like this. The only thing meaningful thing they've been able to come to any agreement on is the tax cuts so far and immigration.

That is something that is much, much more hotly contested as we are seeing right now. Go ahead, last word.

SHAPIRO: My position on the policy side is we don't want to create a permanent underclass like Germany has with its third generation Turks that are still not citizens that sort of thing. But on the legality, it's a closer call for me than the policy. I think you need a constitutional amendment, but there are good arguments on both sides as long as you don't do it by executive order. A president is not a king.

MONTGOMERY: Absolutely right. Not yet. We'll see what happens in 2020. It's only going to get stranger. Ilya Shapiro, thank you so much.

SHAPIRO: My pleasure.

MONTGOMERY: Very good. Coming up, we got much more on immigration including the number of people in that caravan on its way to the U.S. It's reportedly shrinking like we've been telling you for weeks. So why are we sending more U.S. troops down to the border and how much is that going to cost? What happens when they get there? The panel, they're going to come by to explain how the caravan really affects you. That's coming up after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MONTGOMERY: What happens to the asylum seekers when the caravan arrives at the U.S. border? Why am I talking like a 1930s movie star? I don't know. President Trump sat down with our own Laura Ingraham to answer that very question last night. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We're not letting them into this country. We're not going to let gang members --

(CROSSTALK)

LAURA INGRAHAM, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST: But what if they're applying for asylum, isn't the law because Congress is --

(CROSSTALK)

DON YEALY, CHAIR OF EMERGENCY MEDICINE, UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH MEDICAL CENTER: He expressed his thanks for their service and sorrow over their injuries and really wanted to hear some of their stories about the event and what's been going on since then.

MONTGOMERY: Thank you so much, Garrett. All right. Coming up, tech companies and the government have been spying on you for years. But Apple CEO Tim Cook says that's enough. Silicon Valley is a grab bag for sticky fingered politicians in particular, California Democrats, who were more than happy to steal your wealth to ensure their power. And if they're on the take and beholden to hoodie wrapped millennial billionaires, why wouldn't they let this technocratic pentaverate fiddle with the legislative nib?

It's not right to steal and sell information, and who's to say Facebook isn't buying favor to stay in Uncle Sam's good graces? Tech companies will shamelessly work with the government to help the feds streamline what they already do so clumsily. Take your stuff.

MONTGOMERY: Yes. Also, clear at the airport. I just signed up for it which goes to show you that you think there's a certain level of ignorance. I think it is rational ignorance. MONTGOMERY: Yes. Biometrics, and -- but that's the thing, that's the other thing tech will always be ahead of the government. DUPPLER: in a way that prices -- that is -- that is a -- I think, a major factor on what we've seen this week. Democrats may take control of the House, in which case, we'll certainly see some of the economic fundamental policies shift, tax reform, regulatory reform, all of the things that have contributed to positive stock market conditions. That is certainly is in danger when it comes to the midterm.

That's certainly (INAUDIBLE)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W9V-B721-JBHT-D27W-00000-00Tight Race In South Carolina, Heckling In Florida, New Poll In Texas; Donald Trump Pays Tribute To Pittsburgh Synagogue Shooting Victims; Apple CEO Tim Cook Calls For 'Comprehensive Federal Privacy Law;' Stock Market Volatility; Kanye's Done With Politics2018-10-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisTight Race In South Carolina, Heckling In Florida, New Poll In Texas; Donald Trump Pays Tribute To Pittsburgh Synagogue Shooting Victims; Apple CEO Tim Cook Calls For 'Comprehensive Federal Privacy Law;' Stock Market Volatility; Kanye's Done With PoliticsLanhamFULL TEXT

LISA KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Thanks so much, Trish. The most important midterm election in the history of the world just one week from today, and by all accounts it will be a brutal sprint to the finish line. The Senate up for grabs, the House up for grabs, and so are many governor's mansions, so which party has the edge as we enter this critical homestretch? Well, first, let's go to the high-profile gubernatorial race in Florida, former Republican Congressman Ron DeSantis is battling Tallahassee's Democratic Mayor Andrew Gillum.

And several polls show Gillum still in the lead today. They each made a pitch to voters. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. RON DESANTIS (R-FL), GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE: Andrew Gillum, he may be a third rate mayor, but he is a first class demagogue and I think he's been doing this stuff throughout the whole campaign.

ANDREW GILLUM (D), GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE, FLORIDA: On November 6th right here in the State of Florida, we have a chance to send a message to Donald Trump and all of their followers that America is still America and the common sense and decency can still prevail right here in our state.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: Hallelujah. The race for Senate in Texas also a nail-biter, a new Quinnipiac poll shows Republican incumbent Ted Cruz, lying Ted, he's up by five points over the skateboarding challenger Beto O'Rourke. That number seeming to narrow by the day. Most analysts will tell you Republicans will likely hold onto the Senate. But the House, that's a vastly different story. If Democrats win in that of 23 seats, they take control. That's right. Nancy Pelosi gets her hands right the end on the scepter once more.

The stakes are very high because many Democrats have promised to impeach the president to undo the tax cuts and to generally stymie the Republican agenda and the latest real clear politics average has Democrats almost eight points ahead on that generic House ballot. That apparently has the Republican Party pretty spooked. As we are already seeing some finger- pointing as to why they may lose. But is it possible the blue wave stalls at the last moment?

Joining me now Fox News Politics Editor Chris Stirewalt. Welcome back.

CHRIS STIREWALT, FOX NEWS POLITICS EDITOR: Ma'am.

MONTGOMERY: I'm so glad your tie and my dress are of a matching hue, sir.

STIREWALT: Kiss met, meant to be. Meant to be this Tuesday.

MONTGOMERY: Great word. You win. So let's talk about this a little bit because Republicans are hoping some of these last-ditch efforts and some of the immigration passion translates to secret voters who have been hanging up on pollsters where Democrats just want to ride the donkey of history right into the stable. What do you think is going to happen?

STIREWALT: I think that your metaphors will collide somewhere over the third District of Iowa and we may all be crushed. Look, I think -- I think this. I think that people have overstated the polls. They have overstated the -- the polls are always wrong. How about this? The polls are generally right but they're always wrong somewhere, and they're always wrong somehow, and we don't know whether we're going to have Republicans outperforming a point or so which could save a bunch of House seats for them in key districts that might hold on for them, or the Democrats could outperform by three or four points because we have a hard time polling lower income and especially Hispanic voters in places like Texas --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: OK. There are certain groups that are difficult to poll and others who are just abstinent and leave it -- flat-out lie or just will not answer the phone. We saw that in 2016. That obviously changed polling. So those seem like some static variables, what are the dynamic ones? What are the ones that can actually be influenced in this last minute jockeying?

STIREWALT: So that's why the president all of a sudden is revisiting birthright citizenship. Remember, he started talking about Ted Cruz. You revisit stuff like that. You talk about the caravan. You try to keep people afraid. The goal here is you got to have people either angry or afraid. Those are the good motivators, right? You heard Andrew Gillum, be angry at Donald Trump. You challenge your -- channel your anger for Donald Trump into something, so the way that you want to keep your voters at a frenetic pace.

You want them federative and feverish because it's not enough for them to go vote. They also -- you need them to drag their spouse. Get their family, drive their mother. You want them so fired up that they're a forced multiplier and fear and anger are the politician's best tools to do those things.

MONTGOMERY: Interesting. And I don't know that a stock market that has the yips right now is helpful to that economic message that has been driving the president's improving poll numbers. That's how the president has been tweeting about it. But you're absolutely right about immigration. One thing that's interesting, there was talk of impeaching Justice Brett Kavanaugh, but with all the horrific news that we saw last week with the shooting at the Pittsburgh synagogue and, of course, with the pipe bombs, Brett Kavanaugh is way on the back burner.

Is there anything within this seven-day forecast that you see coming up that we haven't thought about that also might influence?

STIREWALT: It's the silly season now and it's hard to have it actually come in effect. But you're quite right. The consequence -- the electoral consequence, the polls are unambiguous on this count. It's a sharp turn away from the Republicans and sharp turn away from the president in the wake of the pipe bombing guy, but specifically on Saturday was unmistakable. We've seen it already. People are grossed out about the national conversation about how rough they are, and now the Democrats and Republicans are fighting about whose fault it is.

But generally, the -- here's the rule. When things aren't good, the party in power pays the price and the Republicans are the party of power.

MONTGOMERY: And they're also trying to make the case that things are good and to maintain the status quo. Now, let's say and the off chance that Republicans lose the house, who gets the blame?

STIREWALT: There will be plenty to go around and everybody will say that if only the party would have followed whatever their own ideological -- ideologically based argument was then they would have won. And none of it will matter because it will start a bitter period of recriminations. That's OK thought for whether you're a Republican or Democrat, that's OK because the real show will be one day -- one week from tomorrow when the Democratic 2020 primary starts in earnest.

MONTGOMERY: Now, the president has a lot invested in Florida, and some of the House races and certainly with the governor's race, is he somehow laying the foundation for 2020? Is that part of his two-year strategy?

STIREWALT: Yes. He can't win without Florida in 2020. And the other -- here's the big test that's coming up for Donald Trump. Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan, Wisconsin, in the upper Midwest, he has stunning victories especially in Michigan, Wisconsin, and Pennsylvania. If voters are this sour on Republicans, that's a big warning sign for his party, so he's looking at Scott Walker in Wisconsin. He's looking at host ever congressional seats in Pennsylvania. He's --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: Does Walker have a chance by the way?

STIREWALT: He's got a chance. But boy, if -- he's in for some very rough sledding and he knows it. And he's been one of the people whose been telling Republicans for six months, hey, this is happening. Get serious.

MONTGOMERY: Yes. And don't take anything for granted and certainly don't get complacent. He is one of the few people who was like, we're going to get chillax. But if he does survive, what will that do for -- how does that cement his legacy?

STIREWALT: If Scott Walker can survive this, this will be his fourth -- his fourth statewide win in like five years against all odds. And he's a guy who wore a duck hunting overcoat with a suit to be interviewed by Bret Baier yesterday, so this would just mean that he can do anything.

MONTGOMERY: He really can. I think the man can levitate quite -- he doesn't even need a hover board. Chris Stirewalt, thank you so much.

STIREWALT: You bet.

MONTGOMERY: I can't wait to see what happens this next week. President Trump always talked tough on immigration. But today, he dialed it up to 11 and said he plans to sign an executive order that would end the practice of birthright citizenship. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We can definitely do it with an act of Congress. But now they're saying I can do it just with an executive order. Now, how ridiculous. We're the only country in the world where a person comes in, has a baby, and the baby is essentially a citizen of the United States for 85 years with all of those benefits. It's ridiculous. It's ridiculous. And it has to end.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Have you talked about that with counsel?

TYRUMP: Yes, I have.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: So where in the process --

TRUMP: It's in the process. It will happen with an executive order.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: Man, those things make me nervous. Legal experts believe such an order would lead to a battle in the Supreme Court over the 14th Amendment which states that all persons, "Born or naturalized in the United States are citizens of the United States and of the state wherein they reside." But the president is facing skepticism even from some in his own party including that rascal Paul Ryan.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. PAUL RYAN (R-WI), SPEAKER OF THE UNITED STATES HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES: Well, you obviously cannot do that. You cannot end birthright citizenship with an executive order. We didn't like it when Obama tried changing immigration laws, the executive action. And, obviously, as conservatives, you know, we believe in the constitution.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: I love the constitution so much. Democratic lawmakers have roundly trashed the president as racist and accused him of demagoguery. But despite the blowback, Republican Senator Lindsey Graham says he plans to introduce legislation that would end birthright citizenship when Congress returns. There is fighting words everywhere you look on this issue. But will the president's pen be mightier than the legislative or cultural sword?

Joining me now, Cato Supreme Court Review Editor, and Senior Fellow there at the Cato Institute, it's Ilya Shapiro. He is back. Welcome back.

ILYA SHAPIRO, SENIOR FELLOW, CATO INSTITUTE: Good to be back, Kennedy.

MONTGOMERY: It is great to have you. So let's talk a little bit about this and let's talk about it from a constitutional angle because there is a bit of wiggle room you pointed out within the 14th Amendment because obviously the president cannot undo a constitutional amendment with executive order, but there is a tricky line in there which gives him some leeway. What is that?

SHAPIRO: Well, the part of the 14th Amendment opening clause that you didn't read when you quoted it. I have my handy Cato pocket constitution. Shapiro wedding edition I might add. And subject to the jurisdiction thereof that is where the debate is. That is originally that excluded the kids of diplomats, foreign armies, and Indian tribes because those are foreign sovereigns. Those are different sovereigns. They're not beholden to the United States.

At the time in 1868, there was no such thing as illegal immigrants. But I think it's a close call. There are good arguments on both sides. But I think that you would need a constitutional amendment because the kids of immigrants, tourists, what have you, unless they're diplomats or, you know, these foreign aggressors what have you, they are -- they are subject to the jurisdiction of the United States. If illegal immigrants commit crimes, form contracts, they are subject to American law.

And by the way, this is a debate about whether you need a constitutional amendment or an act of law like what Lindsey Graham is proposing. That's where the fight is going to be. I can't fathom a plausible legal argument for how the president can do this by himself. If the Justice Department offers legal counsel or whatever is hiding some sort of memo, I would love to see that because that would be some ingenious lawyering.

MONTGOMERY: Well, I agree with Paul Ryan here that I was critical of President Obama when he was issuing so many executive orders on immigration because he said he just simply couldn't work with Congress. But said he had a pen and he had a phone, and by gum, he was going to get stuff done. But as we've seen, as this president continues to undo much of President Obama's legacy. The next president is going to do the exact same thing and it's going to be even more chaotic and more confusing for people who are trying to come to this country legally.

SHAPIRO: That's right. If you -- if you live by the pen and phone, you die by the pen and phone, and I was highly critical of President Obama. The president simply doesn't get more power when Congress doesn't act. That's not part of the constitution. I think this was more of a political ploy by Donald Trump. It might be effective. We'll see what happens in the elections next week as Chris was just describing. But ultimately, the legal debate before we even get to the policy debate about whether we should end birthright citizenship.

The legal debate is going to be over Lindsey Graham's legislation. He has proposed it before. I'm not sure he can get it through Congress frankly. You would have to get rid of the legislative filibuster. I'm not sure cocaine Mitch in the Senate is willing to go there. But that's where the debate is --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: I want to bring something also because not only will you see a lot of congressional fighting if Democrats take the House and Republicans maintain the Senate. House Republicans and Senate Republicans already hate each other, so I don't see -- I don't see how they pass something like this. The only thing meaningful thing they've been able to come to any agreement on is the tax cuts so far and immigration.

That is something that is much, much more hotly contested as we are seeing right now. Go ahead, last word.

SHAPIRO: My position on the policy side is we don't want to create a permanent underclass like Germany has with its third generation Turks that are still not citizens that sort of thing. But on the legality, it's a closer call for me than the policy. I think you need a constitutional amendment, but there are good arguments on both sides as long as you don't do it by executive order. A president is not a king.

MONTGOMERY: Absolutely right. Not yet. We'll see what happens in 2020. It's only going to get stranger. Ilya Shapiro, thank you so much.

SHAPIRO: My pleasure.

MONTGOMERY: Very good. Coming up, we got much more on immigration including the number of people in that caravan on its way to the U.S. It's reportedly shrinking like we've been telling you for weeks. So why are we sending more U.S. troops down to the border and how much is that going to cost? What happens when they get there? The panel, they're going to come by to explain how the caravan really affects you. That's coming up after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MONTGOMERY: What happens to the asylum seekers when the caravan arrives at the U.S. border? Why am I talking like a 1930s movie star? I don't know. President Trump sat down with our own Laura Ingraham to answer that very question last night. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We're not letting them into this country. We're not going to let gang members --

(CROSSTALK)

LAURA INGRAHAM, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST: But what if they're applying for asylum, isn't the law because Congress is --

(CROSSTALK)

TRUMP: If they apply for asylum, we're going to hold them until such time as their trial took place --

(CROSSTALK)

INGRAHAM: Where? Do we have the facility?

TRUMP: We're going to put up. We're going to build tent cities. We're going to put tends up all over the place. We're not going to build structures and spend all of these, you know, hundreds of millions of dollars. We're going to have tents. They're going to be very nice.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: We're going to have some Coleman camping stoves and maybe some marshmallows and hot dogs and we're going to roast your wiener. Here's the thing. Tent cities believe it or not, not cheap. According to the Department of Health and Human Services, the government run tent city currently operating in Texas was expected to cost $367 million. And that's the final three months of the year. This as the military prepares to send over 5,000 troops to the southwestern is U.S. border which means we could soon have more U.S. military personnel at the border here in our country than in Iraq and Syria combined.

Is this the best use of our military's time and money? The panel is here to answer that. I got Republican pollster and Maslansky + Partners President, it is Lee Carter. It should be Carter Maslansky and friends' president, former Senior Adviser to the Hillary Clinton campaign, what happened, and former adviser of the DNC, Antjuan Seawright is here. And comedian and head writer of the greatest show in cable news, this very program right here, Jimmy Failla. Welcome, everyone.

ANTJUAN SEAWRIGHT, FORMER ADVISER, DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL COMMITTEE: Great to see you, champ.

JIMMY FAILLA, COMEDIAN: Welcome.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

MONTGOMERY: So tent cities, best idea?

CARTER: No, it's not the best idea. In fact, I think it's a terrible idea. And sometimes I watch the president and I think, are you just doing this to taunt Democrats and the media so they're going to bite and go crazy? Because this just doesn't seem like a reasonable thought-out plan. I understand people are afraid of the caravan coming in. There are better ways to solve this problem than to do this. But this man, he loves the marionette and he also loves symbolic gestures, so to say that and everybody is going to say, well, we're all talking about it, aren't we?

MONTGOMERY: Yes. No, I think there is laziness to a lot of the narrative in politics today and the president is doing a good job of leading them wherever he wants them to go.

SEAWRIGHT: The president has a natural ability to behave like a distractor in chief. He has a natural ability to manufacture a crisis in a time where there's not a need for a crisis. And that's why you see him talking about this caravan and that's why you see him talking about border security, sending troops. Why? Because the media goes like this when he goes like this and it's a distraction. So instead of talking about the issues that really run the day, the issues that matter to voters, the things that the Republican Party and this president has failed on.

We're talking about something that will not even matter come next week, seven days from now. And he's done a masterful job of that, and I'm so frustrated that even my own party who go off on this chase when he throws out this red meat --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: You know what it's like? Have you ever seen five-year-olds play soccer? It looks like -- they don't do a zone strategy. They clump around the ball and they all, you know, it's like a mole -- it's like a millipede. They just -- all over the field. Jim?

FAILLA: True story. I do support efforts to strengthen the border. I disagree with the idea of tents in Texas because you're going to have every hipster in Austin glimpsing thinking it's OK. People are going to be --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: Where is the yurt? I was told there would be some wonderful El Salvadorians here with whom I could culturally appropriate.

FAILLA: But how are we paying $367 million for tents? Like we got a better deal --

MONTGOMERY: We're borrowing the money from China. That's how we're paying for it.

FAILLA: It would have been -- it would have been cheaper to buy them off the fire festival which was a little bit of an overcharge the last I check. But it's like -- it's embarrassing. But in that regard to your point, I do agree that he does a masterful job of orchestrating the news cycle. But at the same time, when you say, you know, the superficial issue that we shouldn't care about, that is the only thing we've talking about for two years anyway which is like Stormy Daniels, and Russia, and stuff like this. I do think this issue resonates with voters that's why I think he --

(CROSSTALK)

CARTER: And more of than half of voters. You're right. 52 percent of voters want stronger borders for security. So this is a winning issue for the president.

MONTGOMERY: But there's a difference, huge difference -- stronger border security and security theater because people start to see through that. Last word, Antjuan.

SEAWRIGHT: You know what, it does not caught -- cost millions of dollars if the president behaving like an adult sitting down with Democrats and Republicans coming up with comprehensive immigration reform --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: He did. He sat down with Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi.

SEAWRIGHT: He sat down with them but rejected their proposal by Graham, and Durbin, and others even the --

MONTGOMERY: OK. Let's stop acting like they were being chivalrous and benevolent, and reached out to the president said, you know what, we'll take this Dreamers. We'll give you the wall. That is hot malarkey. They're all disconnected in wedges --

(CROSSTALK)

SEAWRIGHT: But at least let's talk about -- let's come to an agreement. I think this is just a disaster waiting to happen. A political disaster because you know what he wants to gin up his base. The Republican Party is going to give it so much red meat the past couple of week the overall cholesterol of that party it's going to go out of the roof.

MONTGOMERY: Have you seen what comes out of Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's mouth? I mean that's what -- that's the red meat that the far-left is offering to Democrats right now. It's all populist and disingenuous. It's all very expensive and it all will make this country go swirling down the toilet like a hot unacceptable turd --

(CROSSTALK)

SEAWRIGHT: -- of the United States, Kennedy. There's a difference.

MONTGOMERY: Yes. Well, she's never going to be elected President of the United States because she can't be challenged in an interview. She falls apart like a balsam wood Barbie house on fire.

FAILLA: It is a funny point. They --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: I gave him last word. But you have like -- you have five last words.

FAILLA: Oh, quick. No. I was just going to say they always say that if you hate something long enough, you'll be comet. The left hated Sarah Palin so much they became Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and here we are. Thanks for the time.

MONTGOMERY: Very funny. You know what I always hated?

FAILLA: What?

MONTGOMERY: Gisele.

FAILLA: Gisele? Hold on. Speaking of --

SEAWRIGHT: OK.

MONTGOMERY: I'm going to see the panel later. First up, President Trump was in Pittsburgh today where he visited the synagogue where a gunman killed 11 people as they prayed on Saturday. Fox's Garrett Tenney, he is there in Pittsburgh with all the details. Garrett?

GARRETT TENNEY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Kennedy. The president and his family came to pay homage to the 11 people who were killed in what's now the worst anti-Semitic attack in U.S. history and also to deliver a message of support to the Jewish community. Not everyone welcomed that message though. Hundreds of protesters filled the streets here near the Tree of Life Synagogue as the president, First Lady, and Ivanka, and Jared Kushner both of whom are practicing Jews visited the site where 11 people were killed.

The first couple laid stones and white roses from the White House garden at a Star of David for each victim. His second stop was the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center where he visited the four officers injured during the attack, their families, and the medical team that's treated them and the two other victims.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DON YEALY, CHAIR OF EMERGENCY MEDICINE, UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH MEDICAL CENTER: He expressed his thanks for their service and sorrow over their injuries and really wanted to hear some of their stories about the event and what's been going on since then.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TENNEY: The city's mayor did not join the president during his visit and saying that he wanted to focus on helping his city recover. A group of progressive rabbis say the president's divisive rhetoric about minorities is partly to blame for the attack, but other Jewish leaders say the president's visit is welcome.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JEREMY WEISBLATT, RABBI, TEMPLE OHAV SHALOM: He's our president and if he chooses to come here to be with us, I would hope as Rabbi Myers that he would be willing to engage in a conversation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TENNEY: The White House tells us that during his visit to the hospital, the president spent at least an hour with the widow of Dr. Richard Gottfried who was killed in the attack, and we're told that she asked to meet with the president to thank him for coming and to let him know that unlike the protesters, there are many others who wanted him to be here today, Kennedy.

MONTGOMERY: Thank you so much, Garrett. All right. Coming up, tech companies and the government have been spying on you for years. But Apple CEO Tim Cook says that's enough. He wants to enact better privacy laws. But what's his motivation now and is there any hope he'll succeed? My monologue is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MONTGOMERY: Apple's Tim Cook was spitting mad at Brussels the other day, as he tore into his rabid rivals at Facebook and Google, who are peeking into your business and selling you out like a neighborhood hussy.

Cook, repurposing a phrase from old Ike, called the shady enterprise and data industrial complex. Zuck and Gubes have made a tidy industry off of your data, and now, Tim Cook is fighting to put his worm in your Apple. God, that sounds dirty, while touting his company's beefy and bolstered new security measures.

T.V. time turned into a flash fan boy, as he raved about Europe's new privacy laws, the GDPR, and how he hopes this United States will follow suit.

While I applaud Cook's natural inclination toward privacy and less liberty, which is implied in several amendments, the constitution, especially the first and fourth, it is the special insidious cronyism that has developed between big tech and big government that's most worrisome.

Silicon Valley is a grab bag for sticky fingered politicians in particular, California Democrats, who were more than happy to steal your wealth to ensure their power. And if they're on the take and beholden to hoodie wrapped millennial billionaires, why wouldn't they let this technocratic pentaverate fiddle with the legislative nib?

Now, that's cronyism, and that's how it works. Just look at the history of liberty destroying public unions to see how quickly such systems corrupt themselves. Also, tech companies who wield that much power and influence, shouldn't have to be told what to do. And a new series of laws shouldn't need crafting when they invent new ways to thieve and lie.

It's not right to steal and sell information, and who's to say Facebook isn't buying favor to stay in Uncle Sam's good graces? Tech companies will shamelessly work with the government to help the feds streamline what they already do so clumsily. Take your stuff.

But tech will always be ahead of government, and they should use that advantage to bolster the lives and experiences of individuals and not to boost their unholy alliance with the bumbling and corruptible state. And that's the memo.

The constitution enshrines our right to privacy but the world is a tad different than it was in the 18th century. So, how do we ensure our privacy in this brave new world? Joining me now, Former Utah Congressman and FOX News Contributor, Jason Chaffetz is back. Welcome back, sir.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Thanks, Kennedy. Glad to be with you.

MONTGOMERY: So, let's talk a little bit about what Tim Cook was saying, because I agree with him that privacy is certainly a right, and you know, you can be backed up by reading and interpreting the constitution, but do we really need new laws?

CHAFFETZ: Well, we've got to be very diligent about what our government is doing. I think Tim Cook is right, and what I'm really worried about is, I think most Americans have no idea what these tech companies are doing, diving into our personal lives and doing things in cahoots with our government.

Most people don't realize that more than one out of every two people in the United States is in the FBI database. They may be suspicionless Americans but facial recognition is in use by the government and they're getting that when you go to get your driver's license photos.

MONTGOMERY: Yes. Also, clear at the airport. I just signed up for it which goes to show you that you think there's a certain level of ignorance. I think it is rational ignorance. And i do think it's generational. I think our entire generation of younger Americans; particularly those were raised on technology and have known only that, who just assumes there is no such thing as privacy.

So, what happens when they assume power?

CHAFFETZ: Well, and that's what I worry about. The laws changed a couple decades ago, so that a 13-year-old can enter into a user agreement. You are basically trading your personal information, everything you look and see online, then, becomes the data and property of these companies who go and sell it for a profit.

But what I think is -- you give that consideration and you get some value out of that, but you can't ever get out of that contract. That's what I'm worried about.

MONTGOMERY: I know, but the thing --

CHAFFETZ: There's a 13-year --

MONTGOMERY: I understand that -- but the thing -- there are two things here that I think are right. One, Tim Cook bringing up the implicit right to privacy in this country, and that being a natural right, and number two, the free market doing the job it's supposed to do without government force, which is someone saying to his competitors, you are stealing information; we are good at protecting that information.

Therefore, people should buy our products and I think that's why Apple has a lot of very devoted adherence. But, the other thing, the thing that I bring up in my monologue is there are so much money in Silicon Valley, between Facebook and Google alone.

You don't even have to name other social media companies or tech companies. And they're more than happy to sit down and help craft these laws, to their benefit. That's how cronyism works. I mean, that -- look at what's happened with the health care industry.

You know, I brought up the unions as an example, but, you know, look at teachers' unions, and there are so many examples of this, where big money sits down with the big government and crafts things in their favor.

CHAFFETZ: Well, we have about 250,000 employees that work on I.T., and they make a handsome salary. They have -- we spend about $90 plus billion a year, billion, more than the tech companies are able to spend. The federal government spends and it doesn't work.

And so, they still rely on these tech companies, very hard to attract the talent. But I worry about what they're doing with the data. The government can't secure this information. They demonstrated it through the Office of Professional Management, OPM, but now, they're out collecting the Department of Justice.

You're suspicionless, why am I in an FBI database and being able to be searched through public cameras, when you've done nothing wrong? That is just wrong. We don't collect DNA, we don't collect fingerprints when you're born. But we are collecting now, your face, and that scares me.

MONTGOMERY: Yes. Biometrics, and -- but that's the thing, that's the other thing tech will always be ahead of the government. So, even if they pass some laws now, they will find a way to scrub around it. And that's fine, as long as they're using technology to benefit humanity, if there are no other tech companies should call them out.

And I have more faith in the free market than I do the federal government. Jason Chaffetz, thank you very much.

CHAFFETZ: Amen, thank you.

MONTGOMERY: That's right. The U.S. has enjoyed a surging stock market for several years now. And it was up more than 400 points today. We're all rich. However, October has been through a very rough patch for investors. President Trump warned it's only going to get worse if Democrats take Congress in November.

He tweeted -- the stock market is up massively since the election, but is now taking a little pause - people want to see what happens with the midterms. If you want your stocks to go down, I strongly suggest voting Democrat. They like the Venezuela financial model, high taxes and open borders!

The President's trade war with China has been a big driver of stock volatility and last night, he told Laura Ingraham, there could be more bumps in the road.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

INGRAHAM: How confident are you about the deal?

TRUMP: I can make a deal right now. I just say they're not ready.

INGRAHAM: $250 billion additional tariffs if that deal doesn't go through.

TRUMP: $250 billion and have $267 billion waiting to go if we can't make a deal.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: Oh Lord. The Dow tumbled yesterday. Shot back up today. It's down about seven percent, this month. So, how do you keep your money safe in uncertain times? Joining me now, National Taxpayers Union Senior Fellow and Center for a Free Economy Board Member, Mattie Duppler is back. Welcome back, Mattie.

MATTIE DUPPLER, SENIOR FELLOW, NATIONAL TAXPAYERS UNION: Hey, Kennedy.

MONTGOMERY: So, a lot of people are looking at this, they're checking their 401(k)s and they are kind of freaking out. What should people do?

DUPPLER: Well, first, they should stop freaking out. Everybody, just be cool. There are two reasons that people need to look at this, with a little bit of sober reflection. One, is that price in stocks really isn't that relevant.

What matters when it comes to the stock market is the price of a stock relative to the value of that stock. And remember, this year, we saw for the first time, companies reach trillion dollar values, that's Amazon and Apple, of course, big tech stocks, and those are massive valuations.

So, in some sense, it's not totally surprising that at some point, the stock market had to cool down a little bit. And you saw Trump too talk a little bit about context. Context matters when it comes to the stock market. For too long, we've been conflating the stock market and our economy, rather than looking at the stock market for what it is.

MONTGOMERY: But the President -- the President does take credit for it when the stock market goes up. Will he take responsibility when it flattens?

DUPPLER: Well, and this is the question that all observers have been asking all year, which is, when is the stock market finally going to price in all of this trade anxiety? We've been waiting for months for the market to finally start to behave --

MONTGOMERY: Is that what's happening?

DUPPLER: in a way that prices -- that is -- that is a -- I think, a major factor on what we've seen this week. Now, you mentioned before that all of October, we've seen a lot of volatility, but remember, the fall is generally September and October are generally pretty volatile months for the stock market. End of October, we generally see a little bit of an uptick, but September was not as bad as anticipated.

So, again, I go back to my original point that stock market movement is relative. We thought we would see a little bit more of a downfall in September, we didn't see that, we're seeing it now in October, ahead of a midterm, where you heard from the President.

Democrats may take control of the House, in which case, we'll certainly see some of the economic fundamental policies shift, tax reform, regulatory reform, all of the things that have contributed to positive stock market conditions. That is certainly is in danger when it comes to the midterm.

MONTGOMERY: So, you're saying that I should grow a victory garden and put all my money in gold.

DUPPLER: I think what you need to do, if you are someone who is looking at this and you're anxious about the stock market, you need to ask yourself what your goals are with your investment. Talk to your financial manager and ask, are my goals being met? If your goals are long-term growth, which generally should be your goal, if you are investing in the stock market, you don't need to worry about one month dip on your numbers. That's certainly (INAUDIBLE)

MONTGOMERY: No. This is -- this is -- we're playing long ball here, Mattie.

DUPPLER: That's exactly right, years and years. You want to be in the stock market, you want to be -- you want to be looking years ahead. So, don't be worried about one month at a time.

MONTGOMERY: It's raining men and money, always, on this show. Mattie Duppler, thank you so much.

DUPPLER: That's why I come back, Kennedy, thanks a lot.

MONTGOMERY: Thank you. Coming up, Kanye West has just made a huge political announcement. Tell you about his plans and get reaction from the panel, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MONTGOMERY: Just a couple of weeks ago, Kanye West made headlines when he hugged the President in the Oval Office and said the M.F. word. Today, he says he feels people have taken advantage of his political passion, and he says he's taking a break.

He tweeted "My eyes are now wide open and now realize I've been used to spread messages I don't believe in. I am distancing myself from politics and completely focusing on being creative!"

So, is Ye, really done with politics? The panel is back, Lee, Antjuan and Jimmy. Antjuan, I will start with you, boy did Kanye West go through a meat grinder after he met with the President and he was wearing the Make America Great Again hat for a while.

SEAWRIGHT: Well, well-deserved. But I say --

MONTGOMERY: Come on. Can you disagree with some of the things he said, certainly not all of them?

SEAWRIGHT: What I said from the beginning, Donald Trump and Kanye West have a lot in common, everything they do is about them and furthering their brand. This was no different. Today is no different. I hope that Candace Owens and Charlie Kirk got the memo about today. In fact, he tweeted at Candace, directly.

MONTGOMERY: Yes, he was mad at Candace.

SEAWRIGHT: Very much so, because they were riding his wave, his brand, leading some imaginary Blaxit plan, or whatever it's called, that was going nowhere very, very fast.

MONTGOMERY: See, I thought it had to do with Lichtenstein leaving the E.U.

FAILLA: Yes. By the way, who would have thought someone would break up with politics faster than Taylor Swift? I thought it was over in two weeks. Then, he took over two weeks on Taylor and made money. Good for Kanye, from a sense of, I think, every celebrity could learn something from this.

And that none of us actually care what they think, like, they get a lot of press attention for this, but you know, if Kanye West or Taylor Swift or God forbid, Alyssa Milano, are influencing your policy positions, you shouldn't be in a booth.

Like, that's first and foremost. But we got to this age, I think, because of social media, where these stuff garner so much attention that celebrities have started to think we care. But if we cared, Trump wouldn't be President, because the entirety of Hollywood campaigned against him for two years, so I'm happy for Yeezy.

MONTGOMERY: Lee?

CARTER: You know, I'm just curious --

MONTGOMERY: Leezy.

CARTER: My stepson calls me that sometimes. You know, I think the thing that's going to be interesting to see is what happens now? Is this going to be somebody anybody cares about? I'm not so sure or the Democrats going to try and celebrate that he's come to his senses and now must be OK?

MONTGOMERY: I think the way he was described in certain circles, I think it was reprehensible and I think it was racist. I was really disgusted by it, and it's not accessible, and I don't want my daughters engaging in that kind of conversation.

SEAWRIGHT: Well, I don't want anyone to do, Democrat or Republican, black or white, support the President or not, is getting distracted by this. We have so many bigger issues on the table that we have to face as a country.

MONTGOMERY: I like what he said about love and creativity. I appreciate what he said about bringing manufacturing to parts of the country that need it most, who have never recovered when manufacturing left. And the fact that --

SEAWRIGHT: The haves and have nots. That's what I call it.

MONTGOMERY: Marrying these two things but that part of his message was roundly ignored. And that's too bad, because that could have been an interesting part of the conversation.

CARTER: Absolutely.

MONTGOMERY: This part is done.

SEAWRIGHT: If he came from the right place.

MONTGOMERY: Yes. Oh, there I am. I would like to thank this glorious panel, Jimmy, Antjuan and Lee. Thank you. Hey, you know what? We may not agree about everything, but we love talking about it.

SEAWRIGHT: That's right.

MONTGOMERY: Topical Storm is next, stay put.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MONTGOMERY: A new study finds that colleges can reduce stress levels among students by providing them with therapy dogs. For instance, it can be very comforting for an art history major to snuggle with someone else who relies on their parents for food and shelter. That's a true story.

And this is the Topical Storm topic number one. We begin tonight in Turkey, so lean, when there was a bit of confusion over who belongs on the catwalk. Yes, guests at the Esmond International Fashion Show were shocked to see a seven-pound cat hit the runway and the supermodels were shocked to see a female that heavy.

They're like, here's the plus sized gal. It was actually a cute moment until the social justice crowd flipped out for wearing fur. Fortunately for the designer, the feline fashionista didn't stay long because an audience member used the laser pointer to lure the cat onto a busy highway. I'm kidding! It's Turkey. They locked her up for life.

Topic number two. There it is, we head now to the great state of Texas, where a school bus driver has landed in some serious hot water. And this is why you never ask a driver to work on a floating holiday. This brainiac drove right past the barricade and got washed off the road. It was so choppy; the students couldn't even light their cigarettes in the back!

One poor kid even carved the wrong initials into his seat! And now, his girlfriend thinks he's cheating! Fortunately, no one was injured in the incident, but the bad news is, the driver was arrested. The good news is, it won't be his first time, going up the river! Get it? No, because you're too sad about Whitey Bulger, too soon.

Topic number three. The Halloween and Costume Association has started a petition to change the date of Halloween. I think the story here is that there's something called the Halloween and Costume Association. We Googled it, and unlike Elizabeth Warren's heritage, it's a real thing.

The change.org petitioned demands that all Halloween celebrations take place on the last Saturday of October to ensure a longer, safer day of trick or treating, because what's the point of blowing a 90 bucks on a slutty peanut M&M costume if you can't wear it for 20 hours? Twenty-eight thousand people have signed it, and by 28,000, they mean, millennials, true story.

According to the association, 51 percent of millennials say Halloween is their favorite holiday, that's because it's the one day they get to dress like someone with a job.

Topic number four. I love generational warfare deal. Brewdog beer is launching the world's first craft beer airline where, "the beer will flow like water." emphasis on the word, water, because that's where you'll be landing.

The good news is, you'll be flying at the time. Each flight promises on board beer experts, loads of food craft beers, oh my God, this sounds like a hipster nightmare. Hit me over the head with your banjo, while you're at it. Smother me with your long beard. Oh, sure. Who doesn't love beer and food? But they leave out the fact that you'll be sharing a row with some freelance juggling teacher's therapy llama.

Earth to Brewdog, nobody wants a pilot with a handlebar mustache. Nobody wants to hear, good evening, ladies and gentlemen, my name is Captain Morgan. I don't know (INAUDIBLE) only my friend, Trish, would agree.

It will take place in 2019. Tickets cost $1,600 American dollars, but you can save money if you book a flight and a unicycle at the same time. In the event of change in cabin pressure, please pull down on your oxygen mason jar. God, a bunch of hipster jack asses. I love the good old days. Get off my lawn. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MONTGOMERY: Thank you so much for watching the best hour of your day, and like to take this moment to apologize to no one for anything, ever. Oh, there you go, you can follow me on Twitter and Instagram, @kennedynation, on Facebook, it's kennedyFBN, e-mail, kennedyfbn@foxbusiness.com

Tomorrow night on the show, Mike Baker, Marc Lotter, Matt Welch and not me, I'll be trick-or-treating with my girls, because I'm not a communist. Goodnight.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W8B-GB31-JBHT-D4WB-00000-00Tight Race In South Carolina, Heckling In Florida, New Poll In Texas; Donald Trump Pays Tribute To Pittsburgh Synagogue Shooting Victims; Apple CEO Tim Cook Calls For 'Comprehensive Federal Privacy Law;' Stock Market Volatility; Kanye's Done With Politics2018-10-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisTight Race In South Carolina, Heckling In Florida, New Poll In Texas; Donald Trump Pays Tribute To Pittsburgh Synagogue Shooting Victims; Apple CEO Tim Cook Calls For 'Comprehensive Federal Privacy Law;' Stock Market Volatility; Kanye's Done With PoliticsLanhamFULL TEXT

LISA KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Thanks so much, Trish. The most important midterm election in the history of the world just one week from today, and by all accounts it will be a brutal sprint to the finish line. The Senate up for grabs, the House up for grabs, and so are many governor's mansions, so which party has the edge as we enter this critical homestretch? Well, first, let's go to the high-profile gubernatorial race in Florida, former Republican Congressman Ron DeSantis is battling Tallahassee's Democratic Mayor Andrew Gillum.

And several polls show Gillum still in the lead today. They each made a pitch to voters. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. RON DESANTIS (R-FL), GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE: Andrew Gillum, he may be a third rate mayor, but he is a first class demagogue and I think he's been doing this stuff throughout the whole campaign.

ANDREW GILLUM (D), GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE, FLORIDA: On November 6th right here in the State of Florida, we have a chance to send a message to Donald Trump and all of their followers that America is still America and the common sense and decency can still prevail right here in our state.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: Hallelujah. The race for Senate in Texas also a nail-biter, a new Quinnipiac poll shows Republican incumbent Ted Cruz, lying Ted, he's up by five points over the skateboarding challenger Beto O'Rourke. That number seeming to narrow by the day. Most analysts will tell you Republicans will likely hold onto the Senate. But the House, that's a vastly different story. If Democrats win in that of 23 seats, they take control. That's right. Nancy Pelosi gets her hands right the end on the scepter once more.

The stakes are very high because many Democrats have promised to impeach the president to undo the tax cuts and to generally stymie the Republican agenda and the latest real clear politics average has Democrats almost eight points ahead on that generic House ballot. That apparently has the Republican Party pretty spooked. As we are already seeing some finger- pointing as to why they may lose. But is it possible the blue wave stalls at the last moment?

Joining me now Fox News Politics Editor Chris Stirewalt. Welcome back.

CHRIS STIREWALT, FOX NEWS POLITICS EDITOR: Ma'am.

MONTGOMERY: I'm so glad your tie and my dress are of a matching hue, sir.

STIREWALT: Kiss met, meant to be. Meant to be this Tuesday.

MONTGOMERY: Great word. You win. So let's talk about this a little bit because Republicans are hoping some of these last-ditch efforts and some of the immigration passion translates to secret voters who have been hanging up on pollsters where Democrats just want to ride the donkey of history right into the stable. What do you think is going to happen?

STIREWALT: I think that your metaphors will collide somewhere over the third District of Iowa and we may all be crushed. Look, I think -- I think this. I think that people have overstated the polls. They have overstated the -- the polls are always wrong. How about this? The polls are generally right but they're always wrong somewhere, and they're always wrong somehow, and we don't know whether we're going to have Republicans outperforming a point or so which could save a bunch of House seats for them in key districts that might hold on for them, or the Democrats could outperform by three or four points because we have a hard time polling lower income and especially Hispanic voters in places like Texas --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: OK. There are certain groups that are difficult to poll and others who are just abstinent and leave it -- flat-out lie or just will not answer the phone. We saw that in 2016. That obviously changed polling. So those seem like some static variables, what are the dynamic ones? What are the ones that can actually be influenced in this last minute jockeying?

STIREWALT: So that's why the president all of a sudden is revisiting birthright citizenship. Remember, he started talking about Ted Cruz. You revisit stuff like that. You talk about the caravan. You try to keep people afraid. The goal here is you got to have people either angry or afraid. Those are the good motivators, right? You heard Andrew Gillum, be angry at Donald Trump. You challenge your -- channel your anger for Donald Trump into something, so the way that you want to keep your voters at a frenetic pace.

You want them federative and feverish because it's not enough for them to go vote. They also -- you need them to drag their spouse. Get their family, drive their mother. You want them so fired up that they're a forced multiplier and fear and anger are the politician's best tools to do those things.

MONTGOMERY: Interesting. And I don't know that a stock market that has the yips right now is helpful to that economic message that has been driving the president's improving poll numbers. That's how the president has been tweeting about it. But you're absolutely right about immigration. One thing that's interesting, there was talk of impeaching Justice Brett Kavanaugh, but with all the horrific news that we saw last week with the shooting at the Pittsburgh synagogue and, of course, with the pipe bombs, Brett Kavanaugh is way on the back burner.

Is there anything within this seven-day forecast that you see coming up that we haven't thought about that also might influence?

STIREWALT: It's the silly season now and it's hard to have it actually come in effect. But you're quite right. The consequence -- the electoral consequence, the polls are unambiguous on this count. It's a sharp turn away from the Republicans and sharp turn away from the president in the wake of the pipe bombing guy, but specifically on Saturday was unmistakable. We've seen it already. People are grossed out about the national conversation about how rough they are, and now the Democrats and Republicans are fighting about whose fault it is.

MONTGOMERY: Come on. Can you disagree with some of the things he said, certainly not all of them?

SEAWRIGHT: What I said from the beginning, Donald Trump and Kanye West have a lot in common, everything they do is about them and furthering their brand. This was no different. Today is no different. I hope that Candace Owens and Charlie Kirk got the memo about today. In fact, he tweeted at Candace, directly.

MONTGOMERY: Yes, he was mad at Candace.

SEAWRIGHT: Very much so, because they were riding his wave, his brand, leading some imaginary Blaxit plan, or whatever it's called, that was going nowhere very, very fast.

MONTGOMERY: See, I thought it had to do with Lichtenstein leaving the E.U.

FAILLA: Yes. By the way, who would have thought someone would break up with politics faster than Taylor Swift? I thought it was over in two weeks. Then, he took over two weeks on Taylor and made money. Good for Kanye, from a sense of, I think, every celebrity could learn something from this.

And that none of us actually care what they think, like, they get a lot of press attention for this, but you know, if Kanye West or Taylor Swift or God forbid, Alyssa Milano, are influencing your policy positions, you shouldn't be in a booth.

Like, that's first and foremost. But we got to this age, I think, because of social media, where these stuff garner so much attention that celebrities have started to think we care. But if we cared, Trump wouldn't be President, because the entirety of Hollywood campaigned against him for two years, so I'm happy for Yeezy.

MONTGOMERY: Lee?

CARTER: You know, I'm just curious --

MONTGOMERY: Leezy.

CARTER: My stepson calls me that sometimes. You know, I think the thing that's going to be interesting to see is what happens now? Is this going to be somebody anybody cares about? I'm not so sure or the Democrats going to try and celebrate that he's come to his senses and now must be OK?

MONTGOMERY: I think the way he was described in certain circles, I think it was reprehensible and I think it was racist. I was really disgusted by it, and it's not accessible, and I don't want my daughters engaging in that kind of conversation.

SEAWRIGHT: Well, I don't want anyone to do, Democrat or Republican, black or white, support the President or not, is getting distracted by this. We have so many bigger issues on the table that we have to face as a country.

MONTGOMERY: I like what he said about love and creativity. I appreciate what he said about bringing manufacturing to parts of the country that need it most, who have never recovered when manufacturing left. And the fact that --

SEAWRIGHT: The haves and have nots. That's what I call it.

MONTGOMERY: Marrying these two things but that part of his message was roundly ignored. And that's too bad, because that could have been an interesting part of the conversation.

CARTER: Absolutely.

MONTGOMERY: This part is done.

SEAWRIGHT: If he came from the right place.

MONTGOMERY: Yes. Oh, there I am. I would like to thank this glorious panel, Jimmy, Antjuan and Lee. Thank you. Hey, you know what? We may not agree about everything, but we love talking about it.

SEAWRIGHT: That's right.

MONTGOMERY: Topical Storm is next, stay put.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MONTGOMERY: A new study finds that colleges can reduce stress levels among students by providing them with therapy dogs. For instance, it can be very comforting for an art history major to snuggle with someone else who relies on their parents for food and shelter. That's a true story.

And this is the Topical Storm topic number one. We begin tonight in Turkey, so lean, when there was a bit of confusion over who belongs on the catwalk. Yes, guests at the Esmond International Fashion Show were shocked to see a seven-pound cat hit the runway and the supermodels were shocked to see a female that heavy.

They're like, here's the plus sized gal. It was actually a cute moment until the social justice crowd flipped out for wearing fur. Fortunately for the designer, the feline fashionista didn't stay long because an audience member used the laser pointer to lure the cat onto a busy highway. I'm kidding! It's Turkey. They locked her up for life.

Topic number two. There it is, we head now to the great state of Texas, where a school bus driver has landed in some serious hot water. And this is why you never ask a driver to work on a floating holiday. This brainiac drove right past the barricade and got washed off the road. It was so choppy; the students couldn't even light their cigarettes in the back!

One poor kid even carved the wrong initials into his seat! And now, his girlfriend thinks he's cheating! Fortunately, no one was injured in the incident, but the bad news is, the driver was arrested. The good news is, it won't be his first time, going up the river! Get it? No, because you're too sad about Whitey Bulger, too soon.

Topic number three. The Halloween and Costume Association has started a petition to change the date of Halloween. I think the story here is that there's something called the Halloween and Costume Association. We Googled it, and unlike Elizabeth Warren's heritage, it's a real thing.

The change.org petitioned demands that all Halloween celebrations take place on the last Saturday of October to ensure a longer, safer day of trick or treating, because what's the point of blowing a 90 bucks on a slutty peanut M&M costume if you can't wear it for 20 hours? Twenty-eight thousand people have signed it, and by 28,000, they mean, millennials, true story.

According to the association, 51 percent of millennials say Halloween is their favorite holiday, that's because it's the one day they get to dress like someone with a job.

Topic number four. I love generational warfare deal. Brewdog beer is launching the world's first craft beer airline where, "the beer will flow like water." emphasis on the word, water, because that's where you'll be landing.

The good news is, you'll be flying at the time. Each flight promises on board beer experts, loads of food craft beers, oh my God, this sounds like a hipster nightmare. Hit me over the head with your banjo, while you're at it. Smother me with your long beard. Oh, sure. Who doesn't love beer and food? But they leave out the fact that you'll be sharing a row with some freelance juggling teacher's therapy llama.

Earth to Brewdog, nobody wants a pilot with a handlebar mustache. Nobody wants to hear, good evening, ladies and gentlemen, my name is Captain Morgan. I don't know (INAUDIBLE) only my friend, Trish, would agree.

It will take place in 2019. Tickets cost $1,600 American dollars, but you can save money if you book a flight and a unicycle at the same time. In the event of change in cabin pressure, please pull down on your oxygen mason jar. God, a bunch of hipster jack asses. I love the good old days. Get off my lawn. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MONTGOMERY: Thank you so much for watching the best hour of your day, and like to take this moment to apologize to no one for anything, ever. Oh, there you go, you can follow me on Twitter and Instagram, @kennedynation, on Facebook, it's kennedyFBN, e-mail, kennedyfbn@foxbusiness.com

Tomorrow night on the show, Mike Baker, Marc Lotter, Matt Welch and not me, I'll be trick-or-treating with my girls, because I'm not a communist. Goodnight.

END
