Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TMM-HSS1-DY0W-42Y4-00000-00Tight Race In South Carolina, Heckling In Florida, New Poll In Texas; Donald Trump Pays Tribute To Pittsburgh Synagogue Shooting Victims; Apple CEO Tim Cook Calls For 'Comprehensive Federal Privacy Law;' Stock Market Volatility; Kanye's Done With Politics2018-10-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisTight Race In South Carolina, Heckling In Florida, New Poll In Texas; Donald Trump Pays Tribute To Pittsburgh Synagogue Shooting Victims; Apple CEO Tim Cook Calls For 'Comprehensive Federal Privacy Law;' Stock Market Volatility; Kanye's Done With PoliticsLanhamFULL TEXT

LISA KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Thanks so much, Trish. The most important midterm election in the history of the world just one week from today, and by all accounts it will be a brutal sprint to the finish line. The Senate up for grabs, the House up for grabs, and so are many governor's mansions, so which party has the edge as we enter this critical homestretch? Well, first, let's go to the high-profile gubernatorial race in Florida, former Republican Congressman Ron DeSantis is battling Tallahassee's Democratic Mayor Andrew Gillum.

And several polls show Gillum still in the lead today. They each made a pitch to voters. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. RON DESANTIS (R-FL), GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE: Andrew Gillum, he may be a third rate mayor, but he is a first class demagogue and I think he's been doing this stuff throughout the whole campaign.

ANDREW GILLUM (D), GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE, FLORIDA: On November 6th right here in the State of Florida, we have a chance to send a message to Donald Trump and all of their followers that America is still America and the common sense and decency can still prevail right here in our state.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: Hallelujah. The race for Senate in Texas also a nail-biter, a new Quinnipiac poll shows Republican incumbent Ted Cruz, lying Ted, he's up by five points over the skateboarding challenger Beto O'Rourke. That number seeming to narrow by the day. Most analysts will tell you Republicans will likely hold onto the Senate. But the House, that's a vastly different story. If Democrats win in that of 23 seats, they take control. That's right. Nancy Pelosi gets her hands right the end on the scepter once more.

The stakes are very high because many Democrats have promised to impeach the president to undo the tax cuts and to generally stymie the Republican agenda and the latest real clear politics average has Democrats almost eight points ahead on that generic House ballot. That apparently has the Republican Party pretty spooked. As we are already seeing some finger- pointing as to why they may lose. But is it possible the blue wave stalls at the last moment?

Joining me now Fox News Politics Editor Chris Stirewalt. Welcome back.

CHRIS STIREWALT, FOX NEWS POLITICS EDITOR: Ma'am.

MONTGOMERY: I'm so glad your tie and my dress are of a matching hue, sir.

STIREWALT: Kiss met, meant to be. Meant to be this Tuesday.

MONTGOMERY: Great word. You win. So let's talk about this a little bit because Republicans are hoping some of these last-ditch efforts and some of the immigration passion translates to secret voters who have been hanging up on pollsters where Democrats just want to ride the donkey of history right into the stable. What do you think is going to happen?

STIREWALT: I think that your metaphors will collide somewhere over the third District of Iowa and we may all be crushed. Look, I think -- I think this. I think that people have overstated the polls. They have overstated the -- the polls are always wrong. How about this? The polls are generally right but they're always wrong somewhere, and they're always wrong somehow, and we don't know whether we're going to have Republicans outperforming a point or so which could save a bunch of House seats for them in key districts that might hold on for them, or the Democrats could outperform by three or four points because we have a hard time polling lower income and especially Hispanic voters in places like Texas --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: OK. There are certain groups that are difficult to poll and others who are just abstinent and leave it -- flat-out lie or just will not answer the phone. We saw that in 2016. That obviously changed polling. So those seem like some static variables, what are the dynamic ones? What are the ones that can actually be influenced in this last minute jockeying?

STIREWALT: So that's why the president all of a sudden is revisiting birthright citizenship. Remember, he started talking about Ted Cruz. You revisit stuff like that. You talk about the caravan. You try to keep people afraid. The goal here is you got to have people either angry or afraid. Those are the good motivators, right? You heard Andrew Gillum, be angry at Donald Trump. You challenge your -- channel your anger for Donald Trump into something, so the way that you want to keep your voters at a frenetic pace.

You want them federative and feverish because it's not enough for them to go vote. They also -- you need them to drag their spouse. Get their family, drive their mother. You want them so fired up that they're a forced multiplier and fear and anger are the politician's best tools to do those things.

MONTGOMERY: Interesting. And I don't know that a stock market that has the yips right now is helpful to that economic message that has been driving the president's improving poll numbers. That's how the president has been tweeting about it. But you're absolutely right about immigration. One thing that's interesting, there was talk of impeaching Justice Brett Kavanaugh, but with all the horrific news that we saw last week with the shooting at the Pittsburgh synagogue and, of course, with the pipe bombs, Brett Kavanaugh is way on the back burner.

Is there anything within this seven-day forecast that you see coming up that we haven't thought about that also might influence?

STIREWALT: It's the silly season now and it's hard to have it actually come in effect. But you're quite right. The consequence -- the electoral consequence, the polls are unambiguous on this count. It's a sharp turn away from the Republicans and sharp turn away from the president in the wake of the pipe bombing guy, but specifically on Saturday was unmistakable. We've seen it already. People are grossed out about the national conversation about how rough they are, and now the Democrats and Republicans are fighting about whose fault it is.

But generally, the -- here's the rule. When things aren't good, the party in power pays the price and the Republicans are the party of power.

MONTGOMERY: And they're also trying to make the case that things are good and to maintain the status quo. Now, let's say and the off chance that Republicans lose the house, who gets the blame?

STIREWALT: There will be plenty to go around and everybody will say that if only the party would have followed whatever their own ideological -- ideologically based argument was then they would have won. And none of it will matter because it will start a bitter period of recriminations. That's OK thought for whether you're a Republican or Democrat, that's OK because the real show will be one day -- one week from tomorrow when the Democratic 2020 primary starts in earnest.

MONTGOMERY: Now, the president has a lot invested in Florida, and some of the House races and certainly with the governor's race, is he somehow laying the foundation for 2020? Is that part of his two-year strategy?

STIREWALT: Yes. He can't win without Florida in 2020. And the other -- here's the big test that's coming up for Donald Trump. Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan, Wisconsin, in the upper Midwest, he has stunning victories especially in Michigan, Wisconsin, and Pennsylvania. If voters are this sour on Republicans, that's a big warning sign for his party, so he's looking at Scott Walker in Wisconsin. He's looking at host ever congressional seats in Pennsylvania. He's --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: Does Walker have a chance by the way?

STIREWALT: He's got a chance. But boy, if -- he's in for some very rough sledding and he knows it. And he's been one of the people whose been telling Republicans for six months, hey, this is happening. Get serious.

MONTGOMERY: Yes. And don't take anything for granted and certainly don't get complacent. He is one of the few people who was like, we're going to get chillax. But if he does survive, what will that do for -- how does that cement his legacy?

STIREWALT: If Scott Walker can survive this, this will be his fourth -- his fourth statewide win in like five years against all odds. And he's a guy who wore a duck hunting overcoat with a suit to be interviewed by Bret Baier yesterday, so this would just mean that he can do anything.

MONTGOMERY: He really can. I think the man can levitate quite -- he doesn't even need a hover board. Chris Stirewalt, thank you so much.

STIREWALT: You bet.

MONTGOMERY: I can't wait to see what happens this next week. President Trump always talked tough on immigration. But today, he dialed it up to 11 and said he plans to sign an executive order that would end the practice of birthright citizenship. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We can definitely do it with an act of Congress. But now they're saying I can do it just with an executive order. Now, how ridiculous. We're the only country in the world where a person comes in, has a baby, and the baby is essentially a citizen of the United States for 85 years with all of those benefits. It's ridiculous. It's ridiculous. And it has to end.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Have you talked about that with counsel?

TYRUMP: Yes, I have.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: So where in the process --

TRUMP: It's in the process. It will happen with an executive order.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: Man, those things make me nervous. Legal experts believe such an order would lead to a battle in the Supreme Court over the 14th Amendment which states that all persons, "Born or naturalized in the United States are citizens of the United States and of the state wherein they reside." But the president is facing skepticism even from some in his own party including that rascal Paul Ryan.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. PAUL RYAN (R-WI), SPEAKER OF THE UNITED STATES HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES: Well, you obviously cannot do that. You cannot end birthright citizenship with an executive order. We didn't like it when Obama tried changing immigration laws, the executive action. And, obviously, as conservatives, you know, we believe in the constitution.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: I love the constitution so much. Democratic lawmakers have roundly trashed the president as racist and accused him of demagoguery. But despite the blowback, Republican Senator Lindsey Graham says he plans to introduce legislation that would end birthright citizenship when Congress returns. There is fighting words everywhere you look on this issue. But will the president's pen be mightier than the legislative or cultural sword?

Joining me now, Cato Supreme Court Review Editor, and Senior Fellow there at the Cato Institute, it's Ilya Shapiro. He is back. Welcome back.

ILYA SHAPIRO, SENIOR FELLOW, CATO INSTITUTE: Good to be back, Kennedy.

MONTGOMERY: It is great to have you. So let's talk a little bit about this and let's talk about it from a constitutional angle because there is a bit of wiggle room you pointed out within the 14th Amendment because obviously the president cannot undo a constitutional amendment with executive order, but there is a tricky line in there which gives him some leeway. What is that?

SHAPIRO: Well, the part of the 14th Amendment opening clause that you didn't read when you quoted it. I have my handy Cato pocket constitution. Shapiro wedding edition I might add. And subject to the jurisdiction thereof that is where the debate is. That is originally that excluded the kids of diplomats, foreign armies, and Indian tribes because those are foreign sovereigns. Those are different sovereigns. They're not beholden to the United States.

At the time in 1868, there was no such thing as illegal immigrants. But I think it's a close call. There are good arguments on both sides. But I think that you would need a constitutional amendment because the kids of immigrants, tourists, what have you, unless they're diplomats or, you know, these foreign aggressors what have you, they are -- they are subject to the jurisdiction of the United States. If illegal immigrants commit crimes, form contracts, they are subject to American law.

And by the way, this is a debate about whether you need a constitutional amendment or an act of law like what Lindsey Graham is proposing. That's where the fight is going to be. I can't fathom a plausible legal argument for how the president can do this by himself. If the Justice Department offers legal counsel or whatever is hiding some sort of memo, I would love to see that because that would be some ingenious lawyering.

MONTGOMERY: Well, I agree with Paul Ryan here that I was critical of President Obama when he was issuing so many executive orders on immigration because he said he just simply couldn't work with Congress. But said he had a pen and he had a phone, and by gum, he was going to get stuff done. But as we've seen, as this president continues to undo much of President Obama's legacy. The next president is going to do the exact same thing and it's going to be even more chaotic and more confusing for people who are trying to come to this country legally.

SHAPIRO: That's right. If you -- if you live by the pen and phone, you die by the pen and phone, and I was highly critical of President Obama. The president simply doesn't get more power when Congress doesn't act. That's not part of the constitution. I think this was more of a political ploy by Donald Trump. It might be effective. We'll see what happens in the elections next week as Chris was just describing. But ultimately, the legal debate before we even get to the policy debate about whether we should end birthright citizenship.

The legal debate is going to be over Lindsey Graham's legislation. He has proposed it before. I'm not sure he can get it through Congress frankly. You would have to get rid of the legislative filibuster. I'm not sure cocaine Mitch in the Senate is willing to go there. But that's where the debate is --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: I want to bring something also because not only will you see a lot of congressional fighting if Democrats take the House and Republicans maintain the Senate. House Republicans and Senate Republicans already hate each other, so I don't see -- I don't see how they pass something like this. The only thing meaningful thing they've been able to come to any agreement on is the tax cuts so far and immigration.

That is something that is much, much more hotly contested as we are seeing right now. Go ahead, last word.

SHAPIRO: My position on the policy side is we don't want to create a permanent underclass like Germany has with its third generation Turks that are still not citizens that sort of thing. But on the legality, it's a closer call for me than the policy. I think you need a constitutional amendment, but there are good arguments on both sides as long as you don't do it by executive order. A president is not a king.

MONTGOMERY: Absolutely right. Not yet. We'll see what happens in 2020. It's only going to get stranger. Ilya Shapiro, thank you so much.

SHAPIRO: My pleasure.

MONTGOMERY: Very good. Coming up, we got much more on immigration including the number of people in that caravan on its way to the U.S. It's reportedly shrinking like we've been telling you for weeks. So why are we sending more U.S. troops down to the border and how much is that going to cost? What happens when they get there? The panel, they're going to come by to explain how the caravan really affects you. That's coming up after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MONTGOMERY: What happens to the asylum seekers when the caravan arrives at the U.S. border? Why am I talking like a 1930s movie star? I don't know. President Trump sat down with our own Laura Ingraham to answer that very question last night. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We're not letting them into this country. We're not going to let gang members --

(CROSSTALK)

LAURA INGRAHAM, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST: But what if they're applying for asylum, isn't the law because Congress is --

(CROSSTALK)

TRUMP: If they apply for asylum, we're going to hold them until such time as their trial took place --

(CROSSTALK)

INGRAHAM: Where? Do we have the facility?

TRUMP: We're going to put up. We're going to build tent cities. We're going to put tends up all over the place. We're not going to build structures and spend all of these, you know, hundreds of millions of dollars. We're going to have tents. They're going to be very nice.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: We're going to have some Coleman camping stoves and maybe some marshmallows and hot dogs and we're going to roast your wiener. Here's the thing. Tent cities believe it or not, not cheap. According to the Department of Health and Human Services, the government run tent city currently operating in Texas was expected to cost $367 million. And that's the final three months of the year. This as the military prepares to send over 5,000 troops to the southwestern is U.S. border which means we could soon have more U.S. military personnel at the border here in our country than in Iraq and Syria combined.

Is this the best use of our military's time and money? The panel is here to answer that. I got Republican pollster and Maslansky + Partners President, it is Lee Carter. It should be Carter Maslansky and friends' president, former Senior Adviser to the Hillary Clinton campaign, what happened, and former adviser of the DNC, Antjuan Seawright is here. And comedian and head writer of the greatest show in cable news, this very program right here, Jimmy Failla. Welcome, everyone.

ANTJUAN SEAWRIGHT, FORMER ADVISER, DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL COMMITTEE: Great to see you, champ.

JIMMY FAILLA, COMEDIAN: Welcome.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

MONTGOMERY: So tent cities, best idea?

CARTER: No, it's not the best idea. In fact, I think it's a terrible idea. And sometimes I watch the president and I think, are you just doing this to taunt Democrats and the media so they're going to bite and go crazy? Because this just doesn't seem like a reasonable thought-out plan. I understand people are afraid of the caravan coming in. There are better ways to solve this problem than to do this. But this man, he loves the marionette and he also loves symbolic gestures, so to say that and everybody is going to say, well, we're all talking about it, aren't we?

MONTGOMERY: Yes. No, I think there is laziness to a lot of the narrative in politics today and the president is doing a good job of leading them wherever he wants them to go.

SEAWRIGHT: The president has a natural ability to behave like a distractor in chief. He has a natural ability to manufacture a crisis in a time where there's not a need for a crisis. And that's why you see him talking about this caravan and that's why you see him talking about border security, sending troops. Why? Because the media goes like this when he goes like this and it's a distraction. So instead of talking about the issues that really run the day, the issues that matter to voters, the things that the Republican Party and this president has failed on.

We're talking about something that will not even matter come next week, seven days from now. And he's done a masterful job of that, and I'm so frustrated that even my own party who go off on this chase when he throws out this red meat --

MONTGOMERY: You know what it's like? Have you ever seen five-year-olds play soccer? It looks like -- they don't do a zone strategy. They clump around the ball and they all, you know, it's like a mole -- it's like a millipede. They just -- all over the field. Jim?

Not everyone welcomed that message though. Hundreds of protesters filled the streets here near the Tree of Life Synagogue as the president, First Lady, and Ivanka, and Jared Kushner both of whom are practicing Jews visited the site where 11 people were killed.

The first couple laid stones and white roses from the White House garden at a Star of David for each victim. His second stop was the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center where he visited the four officers injured during the attack, their families, and the medical team that's treated them and the two other victims.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DON YEALY, CHAIR OF EMERGENCY MEDICINE, UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH MEDICAL CENTER: He expressed his thanks for their service and sorrow over their injuries and really wanted to hear some of their stories about the event and what's been going on since then.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TENNEY: The city's mayor did not join the president during his visit and saying that he wanted to focus on helping his city recover. MONTGOMERY: Thank you so much, Garrett. All right. Coming up, tech companies and the government have been spying on you for years. But Apple CEO Tim Cook says that's enough. MONTGOMERY: Apple's Tim Cook was spitting mad at Brussels the other day, as he tore into his rabid rivals at Facebook and Google, who are peeking into your business and selling you out like a neighborhood hussy.

Cook, repurposing a phrase from old Ike, called the shady enterprise and data industrial complex. Zuck and Gubes have made a tidy industry off of your data, and now, Tim Cook is fighting to put his worm in your Apple. God, that sounds dirty, while touting his company's beefy and bolstered new security measures.

T.V. time turned into a flash fan boy, as he raved about Europe's new privacy laws, the GDPR, and how he hopes this United States will follow suit.

While I applaud Cook's natural inclination toward privacy and less liberty, which is implied in several amendments, the constitution, especially the first and fourth, it is the special insidious cronyism that has developed between big tech and big government that's most worrisome.

Silicon Valley is a grab bag for sticky fingered politicians in particular, California Democrats, who were more than happy to steal your wealth to ensure their power. And if they're on the take and beholden to hoodie wrapped millennial billionaires, why wouldn't they let this technocratic pentaverate fiddle with the legislative nib?

Now, that's cronyism, and that's how it works. Just look at the history of liberty destroying public unions to see how quickly such systems corrupt themselves. Also, tech companies who wield that much power and influence, shouldn't have to be told what to do. And a new series of laws shouldn't need crafting when they invent new ways to thieve and lie.

It's not right to steal and sell information, and who's to say Facebook isn't buying favor to stay in Uncle Sam's good graces? Tech companies will shamelessly work with the government to help the feds streamline what they already do so clumsily. Take your stuff.

But tech will always be ahead of government, and they should use that advantage to bolster the lives and experiences of individuals and not to boost their unholy alliance with the bumbling and corruptible state. And that's the memo.

The constitution enshrines our right to privacy but the world is a tad different than it was in the 18th century. So, how do we ensure our privacy in this brave new world? Joining me now, Former Utah Congressman and FOX News Contributor, Jason Chaffetz is back. Welcome back, sir.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Thanks, Kennedy. Glad to be with you.

CHAFFETZ: Well, we've got to be very diligent about what our government is doing. MONTGOMERY: Yes. Also, clear at the airport. I just signed up for it which goes to show you that you think there's a certain level of ignorance. I think it is rational ignorance. I think our entire generation of younger Americans; particularly those were raised on technology and have known only that, who just assumes there is no such thing as privacy.

CHAFFETZ: Well, and that's what I worry about. The laws changed a couple decades ago, so that a 13-year-old can enter into a user agreement. MONTGOMERY: I know, but the thing --

CHAFFETZ: There's a 13-year --

MONTGOMERY: I understand that -- but the thing -- there are two things here that I think are right. CHAFFETZ: Well, we have about 250,000 employees that work on I.T., and they make a handsome salary. They have -- we spend about $90 plus billion a year, billion, more than the tech companies are able to spend. The federal government spends and it doesn't work.

MONTGOMERY: Yes. Biometrics, and -- but that's the thing, that's the other thing tech will always be ahead of the government. And that's fine, as long as they're using technology to benefit humanity, if there are no other tech companies should call them out.

And I have more faith in the free market than I do the federal government. Jason Chaffetz, thank you very much.

CHAFFETZ: Amen, thank you.

MONTGOMERY: That's right. The U.S. has enjoyed a surging stock market for several years now. And it was up more than 400 points today. We're all rich. MATTIE DUPPLER, SENIOR FELLOW, NATIONAL TAXPAYERS UNION: Hey, Kennedy.

MONTGOMERY: But the President -- the President does take credit for it when the stock market goes up. Will he take responsibility when it flattens?

DUPPLER: Well, and this is the question that all observers have been asking all year, which is, when is the stock market finally going to price in all of this trade anxiety? We've been waiting for months for the market to finally start to behave --

DUPPLER: in a way that prices -- that is -- that is a -- I think, a major factor on what we've seen this week. End of October, we generally see a little bit of an uptick, but September was not as bad as anticipated.

Democrats may take control of the House, in which case, we'll certainly see some of the economic fundamental policies shift, tax reform, regulatory reform, all of the things that have contributed to positive stock market conditions. That is certainly is in danger when it comes to the midterm.

That's certainly (INAUDIBLE)

MONTGOMERY: No. This is -- this is -- we're playing long ball here, Mattie.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VYY-RMT1-JDP0-53DM-00000-00Tik op de vingers van 3 miljard dollar;Facebook springt te los om met data gebruikers, eerste Amerikaanse boete voor techgigant2019-04-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisBlz. 30Tik op de vingers van 3 miljard dollarFacebook springt te los om met data gebruikers, eerste Amerikaanse boete voor techgigantKarsten lemmens

Miljardenboetes voor grote Amerikaanse techbedrijven: ze leken lang een Europese zaak te zijn. Maar nu Facebook ook in de VS een miljardenboete boven het hoofd hangt, lijkt het tij gekeerd.

Facebook heeft drie miljard dollar opzijgezet omdat het een boete verwacht van de Amerikaanse Federal Trade Commission (FTC). Sinds begin dit jaar doen geruchten de ronde over een sanctie, omdat Facebook niet omzichtig omspringt met de data van zijn gebruikers. Het zou de eerste Amerikaanse boete ooit voor Facebook worden, en meteen ook de grootste boete voor een techbedrijf die de FTC ooit oplegde. Volgens Facebook zal het bedrag ergens tussen 3 en 5 miljard dollar (3,3 miljard en 5,56 miljard euro) landen.

De monsterboete zou dan ook een nieuw tijdperk inluiden. Boetes voor Amerikaanse techbedrijven leken eerder iets waar vooral de Europese Unie zich in bekwaamde.

Aangeschoten wild

De acties van de FTC maken duidelijk dat big tech ook in de VS almaar meer aangeschoten wild is. "In de VS zie je almaar meer regels en wetten", zegt Leighton Andrews, professor aan de Cardiff Business School. "De stemming is dat je niet op Facebook kunt vertrouwen om zichzelf binnen de perken te houden." Volgens hem beschouwt de FTC Facebook intussen als een recidivist. De verwachte miljardenboete kadert in een onderzoek van de FTC over hoe Facebook met data van zijn gebruikers omgaat.

In 2011 sloot het daarover een overeenkomst met de regulator. Gebruikers zouden onder meer "nadrukkelijke toestemming" moeten geven vooraleer hun data kunnen worden gedeeld met andere partijen. Maar tal van schandalen, en dan vooral het verhaal rond Cambridge Analytica, maakten duidelijk dat Facebook zich niet aan de afspraken hield. Toch lijkt Facebook niet wakker te liggen van 3 miljard dollar. Het bedrijf heeft een cashberg van zo'n 44 miljard dollar (49 miljard euro), en de resultaten in het eerste kwartaal van dit jaar waren uitstekend.

De koers ging na de aankondiging met 8% omhoog. Facebook werd zo op de beurs zomaar eventjes 40 miljard dollar meer waard.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60NK-88W1-JBSN-1195-00000-00TikTok Acquisition Poses Risks for U.S. Buyer2020-08-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:50ZLexisNexisTikTok Acquisition Poses Risks for U.S. Buyerby David Hatch

If Microsoft Corp. (MSFT), Oracle Corp. (ORCL) or another major American corporation buys TikTok's U.S. business, the acquirer would gain overnight entrÃ©e into the hotly competitive social media market.

To reach the coveted millennial demographic, an American tech behemoth might spend an estimated $40 billion on a mobile app downloaded more than 1 billion times worldwide that makes it easy to share 15-second videos of goofy dance routines or adorable pet interactions.

Despite the rare buying opportunity created by the Trump administration, Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella or Oracle chairman Larry Ellison might be reaching for the antacid more frequently if either finalizes a purchase with ByteDance Ltd., TikTok s Beijing-based parent.

That s because the acquisition would feature a high degree of risk, from security vulnerabilities and brand dilution to friction with Beijing and Washington, three specialists in cross-border transactions and post-merger integration told The Deal.

Among the thorny issues to be worked out is whether post-divestiture the American buyer would share information with ByteDance and rely on its software code, said Brad Haller, director of mergers and acquisitions for West Monroe, an investment consulting firm.

There s a lot of downsides, Haller said, which explains why only a company of Microsoft s size and resources could tackle the national security and jurisdictional issues that would arise.

The devil will be in all the details, and that will be something important for other companies to watch, said Doreen Edelman, partner at Lowenstein Sandler LLP and chair of the global trade and policy practice.

Microsoft will decide by Sept. 15 whether to purchase TikTok in the U.S. and perhaps Canada, the U.K., Australia and New Zealand.

While the Committee on Foreign Investment in the U.S. has forced Chinese companies to shed U.S. assets before, the extensive White House engagement is unusual and unprecedented.

President Donald Trump issued two executive orders on TikTok in two weeks, imposing strict and seemingly conflicting deadlines as he spoke publicly about a possible sale.

His suggestion that Microsoft compensate the Treasury Department for the purchase initially was https://www.foxbusiness.com/technology/trump-microsoft-money-treasury-tiktok-deal|downplayed by White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow, who later suggested it might be https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/19/larry-kudlow-on-trumps-desire-for-us-to-get-cut-of-a-tiktok-sale.html |plausible.

In its rush to act against ByteDance, the administration sent mixed signals.

An Aug 6. presidential https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/executive-order-addressing-threat-posed-tiktok/|directive invoked emergency powers that set a 45-day deadline for TikTok to cease U.S. operations.

Timothy O Toole, head of the white collar defense practice group at Miller & Chevalier Chartered, noted that the order provided TikTok with strong grounds to sue.

That s because the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, or IEPA, cited by Trump has an exception that doesn t allow the president to regulate communications during an emergency.

The reason for the exception to IEPA is basically a free flow of information rationale, O Toole explained, adding that civil liberties groups were ready to litigate over alleged First Amendment violations.

A week later, citing Cfius, a second Trump https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/order-regarding-acquisition-musical-ly-bytedance-ltd/|order appeared to supersede the first, setting a 90-day divestiture deadline with an optional 30-day extension.

Regulatory Risk

On the surface, a purchase of TikTok s U.S. division by an established American brand wouldn t raise the sorts of security fears that might be triggered by Chinese investment in Silicon Valley, for example.

Even so, Microsoft or any other buyer could still be vulnerable to espionage or theft of intellectual property or trade secrets, especially during the handover.

As a result, Cfius mitigation might be needed to protect U.S. interests if the buyer uses technology or personnel in China to ramp up operations.

With the Trump administration fearful that Beijing mines personal information for espionage, blackmail and stolen identities, a ban on foreign access to user data is likely, Edelman said.

There will have to be separate servers, locations will not be in China, [and] there will be different policies and procedures that will affect the U.S. company, she added.

It s happening so fast, O Toole said, explaining that at the very least, restrictions would be necessary for the handover of software and data.

If there s an ongoing business relationship between the U.S.- and China-based TikToks, you would need a mitigation plan in place for that, he said.

Brand Identity

Any U.S. company that purchases TikTok assets faces the specter of brand dilution.

Haller noted Microsoft has succeeded at maintaining distinct identities for some acquired products, such as LinkedIn and Skype. I don t think the average user of LinkedIn is aware that Microsoft owns them, he said.

Nevertheless, there's no guarantee the brand wouldn t be harmed.

Right now, TikTok is built around a single software code base. If Microsoft were forced to diverge from ByteDance s intellectual property, you lose some synergies," Haller said. That, in turn, might undermine the attractiveness of the platform."

It s also unclear whether the buyer could use TikTok or a variant, such as TikTok U.S., for marketing.

Doing so would reinforce the trade name but also could sow confusion with ByteDance s TikTok. Any switch to a different moniker might undermine the popularity of the instantly recognizable app.

TikTok provides access to video clips from around the globe, a feature that could be limited following a divestiture, potentially alienating some users.

If you change what the product is, you ll really run the risk that you ll destroy it in the process, O Toole cautioned.

The Miller & Chevalier attorney said the buyer would want enough separation from ByteDance to satisfy regulators without altering TikTok s DNA.

On Capitol Hill, however, a clean break may be the only acceptable outcome.

In an Aug. 5 https://www.hawley.senate.gov/sites/default/files/2020-08/Hawley-Letter-Microsoft-TikTok-Purchase.pdf|letter to Microsoft, Sen. Josh Hawley, R-Mo., a Senate antitrust subcommittee member, warned that anything short of severing all ties between the buyer and potential proxies for the Chinese Communist Party, including but not limited to ByteDance, is unacceptable.

Edelman sees total separation as the only option. There s no way that it can remain integrated because then it would still have Chinese government access to the data, she said.

Beijing and Washington

If an American corporation strikes a deal with ByteDance, it runs the risk of aggravating Beijing when bilateral tensions already are strained.

The purchaser might be blamed for facilitating the forced takeover of a Chinese business, with the added insult bidding was limited to American entities.

It also could rile China by exposing any backchannel connections between Beijing and ByteDance. Microsoft s engineers are going to be able to understand what they were or weren t doing with that data, Chicago-based Haller predicted.

Only 2% of Microsoft s revenue comes from China, meaning the company s growth potential would be on the line. Are they shooting themselves in the foot because they re burning bridges now? he asked rhetorically.

By contrast, Apple Inc. (AAPL) has taken steps not to offend the Chinese government, Haller noted.

Microsoft would be easy prey for retaliation because the software giant has manufacturing and other business interests in China. While Oracle shuttered its China research unit, it still has facilities there.

If there s a backlash, either might be the most obvious and first target of any retaliatory steps by the Chinese government, O Toole said.

On the flipside, a generous carve-out offer could be viewed favorably, as it would allow ByteDance to avoid its worst-case scenario: an abrupt U.S. shutdown without compensation.

In Washington, the purchase would coincide with heightened scrutiny of Big Tech acquisitions and deepening worries about data privacy.

But privacy concerns wouldn't be unique to this transaction, and so far, Microsoft and Oracle haven t been the focus of DC s techlash.

Other U.S. companies could get caught in the downdraft of a fresh spat with China.

If Beijing were to become incensed about a TikTok divestiture, it could pursue an asymmetric response such as holding up an unrelated transaction.

There s always the concern that the other side will cause the same amount of pain against you as you cause against them, O Toole said.

Reports that Oracle is an interested buyer are positive for TikTok because multiple bidders could drive the price up. At the same time, White House pressure could push it down.

It s usually not the best thing for a seller to have everyone in the world know that they have no choice other than to sell, O Toole quipped. It makes it hard to have much leverage.

Microsoft, Oracle and ByteDance declined comment.

DEAL SIZE

$ 10-50 Billion

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60JT-8XW1-JCMN-Y381-00000-00TikTok and Microsoft: government agendas are driving businesses like no time since WW2 - here's what they can do about it2020-08-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisTikTok and Microsoft: government agendas are driving businesses like no time since WW2 - here's what they can do about itilene

Aug 10, 2020( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) TikTok and Microsoft: government agendas are driving businesses like no time since WW2 - here's what they can do about it Time's up for TikTok. Ascannio[1] Courtesy ofHoward Yu[2], International Institute for Management Development (IMD)[3] The Trump administration has turned up the heat on Chinese tech companies TikTok and WeChat with an executive order[4] that US companies have 45 days to stop transacting with them. The administration has also[5] recommended that Chinese firms listed on US exchanges be removed unless they provide US regulators access to their audited accounts. It comes only days after the US president gave the go-ahead[6] for Microsoft (or rival US bidders) to buy TikTok if the purchase can be completed by September 15[7]. Failing that, Trump says he will shut down the video-sharing app in the US.

Zhang Yiming, the chief executive of ByteDance, which owns TikTok, wrote to employees telling them he has no choice[8] but to abide by US laws. Thanks to the tight deadline, Microsoft is likely to snap up a crown jewel[9] at a discount - TikTok is the fourth most popular[10] app in the world. Trump also said the US Treasury should get 'a very substantial portion[11]' of the sale price, 'because we're making it possible for this deal to happen'. The mechanics of this are unclear. Microsoft said it[12] 'appreciates the US government's and President Trump's personal involvement'. Business and the national agenda Not since the second world war has the US government expected big businesses to champion a national agenda in this way. It's one thing to expect businesses to be socially responsible toward local communities. But to ban access of foreign companies, and then to expect domestic companies and the government to profit profit directly from it, is a dangerous line to cross. Most dangerous is to expect big companies to carry out 'national duties' because the country is facing 'foreign adversaries'. Do it my way, the leader might say, or I could break you apart. After all, this comes at a time when the excessive size and power of tech rivals such as Google, Facebook and Amazon is already the subject[13] of a fierce congressional debate. What the White House has set in motion is in fact a new norm around the world. Governments now feel compelled and are urged to intervene in a company's operations because of concerns over 'privacy issues', 'national security', 'local jobs' or the 'local economy'. India has[14] already banned TikTok, WeChat and another Chinese tech company, Baidu. The UK is removing Huawei[15] from its telecoms network. Japanese clothing retailer Uniqlo is closing stores[16] in South Korea in the midst of the ongoing trade dispute. In the fog of these skirmishes, there is a total absence of intergovernmental organisation. The crackdown on TikTok and WeChat has been instigated purely by Trump's executive order[17]. When it comes to trade disputes and tariffs, the World Trade Organization (WTO) is delegitimised so completely[18] through long failures over world trade negotiations, the dispute settlement arm and so forth, that it is unable to meaningfully mediate between countries anywhere. This means that the burden of doing business falls back entirely upon executives. Before the WTO, tariffs were everywhere. In 1963, for example, the then US president, Lyndon Johnson, imposed a 25% tariff on light trucks imported to the US. This was to retaliate against European tariffs on American chicken imports. The 'chicken tax[19]', as the tariff on light trucks became known, was signed as representatives of the United Auto Workers union from Detroit were threatening to call a strike just before the 1964 election. Johnson's tax gave them what they wanted: Volkswagen sales of trucks and vans in the US plummeted. Without the WTO to prevent this kind of dispute, companies had to rely on their own ingenuity. Mercedes was one that managed to avoid much of the pain. For years, the German automotive manufacturer would disassemble its vehicle parts and ship the pieces to South Carolina, where American workers put them back together in a small kit assembly building. The resulting vehicles were, therefore, 'locally made[20]' and free of the import tariff. Any additional costs resulting from this roundabout method were negligible in comparison to Mercedes' profits. How companies can respond Today's economic war between the US and China and the escalating political dispute dwarfs any 'chicken tax' in magnitude. The amount of US imports at stake[21] in the countries' next negotiation during mid-August is US$200 billion (153 billion). As a result of the trade hostilities, some US$1.7 trillion[22] has been wiped off the value of US-listed firms over the past two years. One immediate consequence is that US companies are moving manufacturing activities out of China[23], to places like Thailand and Vietnam and Bangladesh. Successful executives are those who are capable of recognising the need to change business practices ahead of political sentiment and pivoting toward a new operating model quickly, whether in China or by moving to new markets. Zoom, for instance, has stopped selling new and upgraded products directly to customers in mainland China. Instead, it is shifting to a 'partner-only model[24]' in the country, outsourcing commercial activities to Bizconf Communications, Suiri Zhumu Video Conference and Systec Umeet. It's the sort of partnership model that Microsoft also has[25] in China for cloud-computing service Azure. https://images.theconversation.com/files/351779/original/file-20200807-22-jouvys.jpg?ixlib=rb-1.1.0&q=45&auto=format&w=1000&fit=clip Zoom is partnering up in China. Metamorworks[26] To see what lies ahead, effective managers look to extreme cases in sectors other than their own. Nowhere is stored data more sensitive than in the financial sector. In Europe, German and French[27] government officials are in talks to create a continental cloud service run by local tech companies for banks. This is part of Europe's strategy for 'ensuring technological sovereignty and reducing its dependence' on US providers. It's not safe enough to simply buy from Amazon, Microsoft or Google. All these are extra burdens and considerations for executives who are already too busy. As I argue here[28], automating mundane decisions using AI is now of even greater urgency. Business people have long despised politics. But 'politics' is now shaping corporate strategy from boardrooms down to assembly lines. Some such as Zoom, and once upon a time Mercedes, adapt to this climate and thrive. Others like TikTok are finding themselves caught on the wrong side of history. Howard Yu[29], Professor of Management and Innovation, International Institute for Management Development (IMD)[30] This article is republished from The Conversation[31] under a Creative Commons license. urn:contentItem:60HY-X461-JDVW-N09J-00000-00TikTok buy 'unique deal of a decade opportunity' for Microsoft2020-08-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisExclusiveTikTok buy 'unique deal of a decade opportunity' for MicrosoftAnna Akins

This is part 1 of our coverage on recent developments around the short-video sharing app TikTok. Part 2 analyzes the impact of a potential TikTok sale on its parent company.

This is part 1 of our coverage on recent developments around the short-video sharing app TikTok. Part 2 analyzes the impact of a potential TikTok sale on its parent company.

Though it faces challenges in Washington, analysts are bullish on Microsoft Corporation's intended purchase of video-sharing app TikTok Inc., noting that the deal should bolster the tech company's portfolio and broaden its appeal beyond enterprise software.

Microsoft recently said it will move forward with plans to acquire the U.S. operations of Chinese-owned TikTok, with the goal of completing negotiations with parent-company Beijing Byte Dance Telecommunications Co. Ltd. by Sept. 15. However, the proposed deal has already encountered significant pushback from the Trump administration and several top lawmakers, who claim the app shares data collected from American users with the Chinese government. TikTok has denied that claim.

In spite of these concerns, analysts largely expect the deal to gain regulatory approval and say such a combination will enable TikTok to capitalize on Microsoft's software expertise while boosting Microsoft's social-networking offerings.

Wedbush Securities analyst Daniel Ives in an Aug. 3 report predicted that there is at least a 75% chance the deal will secure approval given that Microsoft has remained largely out of the regulatory spotlight compared to peers. Microsoft has said it would ensure all of the private data of TikTok's American users is transferred to and remains in the U.S. if the deal goes through.

"[Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella] recognizes that, with all the ... tech stalwarts in major regulatory crosshairs, [Microsoft] is the only game in town to go after this asset," Ives wrote. "We believe from a management and board perspective this is a unique deal of a decade opportunity with a price tag that could easily be consummated."

News of a potential Microsoft-TikTok deal comes as the chief executives of Facebook Inc., Amazon.com Inc., Google LLC-parent Alphabet Inc. and Apple Inc. are defending their business practices to lawmakers amid widespread calls to crack down on big tech's market power. The CEOs were called to testify at a July 29 congressional hearing, which aimed to document competition problems online and to assess whether current antitrust laws and enforcement levels are adequate.

Microsoft received the Trump administration's blessing to proceed with TikTok deal talks following an Aug. 2 phone call between Microsoft's CEO and Trump, marking a reversal from the president's prior comments expressing opposition to a deal and calling for an outright ban of TikTok in the U.S. Trump recently told reporters that the TikTok app will be shut down in the U.S. if it is not sold by Sept. 15 to Microsoft or another U.S. company and argued that the U.S. should receive money in return for allowing the deal to proceed. He did not provide specifics on how that plan would be carried out.

While chatter has circulated that Apple might also be eyeing TikTok, an Apple spokesperson said in a recent statement to Axios that the company is not interested.

Michael Goodman, director of television and media strategies at Strategy Analytics, said in an interview that Microsoft's TikTok purchase would help the company develop a stronger consumer strategy by expanding beyond its core focus of providing software services to businesses.

"They get a tremendous amount of information on their users, particularly on the business side, and they certainly get a lot of data from the game side, from the Xbox side, and how consumers are using gaming consoles," Goodman said. "But in the bigger picture of gaming, and particularly millennials and social networks and the consumer side, they've got a bit of a black hole there. TikTok will provide them with an awful lot of information on a generation that they are not that well connected to."

While Goodman conceded such a purchase will bring more scrutiny on Microsoft as large tech companies continue to be probed, he expects the benefits of the deal to outweigh any potential risks.

TikTok counted 315.0 million global downloads in the first quarter of 2020, up from 187.3 million in the same period a year prior, according to SensorTower, which provides research and data on the global app market.

Daniel Castro vice president of ITIF, an independent, nonpartisan research group based in Washington, D.C., that focuses on the intersection of technological innovation and public policy cautioned the Trump administration against banning TikTok, noting the U.S. has the most to lose from such a move.

Millions of Americans already use TikTok to create and share content, and banning the service could put over 1,000 U.S. jobs directly at risk, he said. Castro acknowledged that the app is owned by a Chinese company, but all of its data centers are located outside of China, and "there is no evidence that it presents a national security threat."

"In a week where many policymakers have called for more competition in the tech sector, undermining one of the fastest-growing social media platforms would be a step in the wrong direction," Castro said in a statement.

urn:contentItem:60G4-BK91-JCMN-Y08B-00000-00TikTok CEO says the app has 'become the target' but is 'not the enemy'2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisTikTok CEO says the app has 'become the target' but is 'not the enemy'Daniel Cooper

Jul 29, 2020( Engadget HD: http://www.engadget.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Jesse Grant via Getty Images It's fair to say that TikTok[1] is facing battles on several fronts, with the White House and Facebook both parking tanks on its lawn. The US is reportedly preparing to ban the Chinese-owned company as part of its broader crackdown on Chinese technology. And Facebook is launching Reels, a competitor product that will likely do for TikTok what Instagram Stories did for Snapchat.

So, in the run-up to today's Big Tech antitrust hearing, CEO Kevin Mayer[2] has published an open letter[3] defending TikTok to regulators.Mayer starts by listing the obvious highlights of TikTok's relatively short career, including its surprising entry into the social media scene. He adds that various lockdown challenges were birthed on the platform, as well as being the place that hit song Old Town Road first found an audience. Then, once the sales pitch is out of the way, the CEO can start talking about the looming political attacks in the works. 'We have received even more scrutiny due to the company's Chinese origins,' he wrote, adding that it's something TikTok[4] accepts, and even embraces. 'With our success comes responsibility and accountability,' and Mayer says that TikTok goes out of its way to show that the company to comply. 'We are responsible and committed members of the American community that follows US laws,' he added.Mayer says the solution to TikTok's woes is greater transparency and believes that all tech companies should be held to the same high standard. 'We believe that all companies should disclose their algorithms, moderation policies and data flows to regulators,' he said. Back in March, TikTok announced[5] that its Transparency and Accountability Center[6] would enable (authorized) third-parties to examine how TikTok works. That includes the app's source code, its algorithm and its moderation -- hopefully as a rebuttal of criticism that it has previously censored clips that are critical of China[7] and skews toward certain demographics[8]. He added that TikTok's opening up in this manner should compel others to do the same, hint hint, Facebook.The final portion of the letter is in the form of a sharp elbow thrown in the face of Mark Zuckerberg, creator of a 'another copycat product[9].' Mayer says that Reels[10] is the second attempt Facebook has made to defeat TikTok, with the third being Facebook's attempts to imply that TikTok is a malign presence in the US. He ends by saying that 'TikTok has become the latest target, but we are not the enemy.' It'll be interesting to see if lawmakers and regulators take any of this into their decisions in the coming weeks and months. urn:contentItem:5XJG-X8S1-JC8Y-836N-00000-00TikTok chief keen to prove video app is not a menace;In the US, there are fears app may be smuggling user data to Beijing's servers2019-11-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:49ZLexisNexisFINANCEPg. 9TikTok chief keen to prove video app is not a menaceIn the US, there are fears app may be smuggling user data to Beijing's serversRaymond Zhong

Like almost everybody who runs a big tech company these days, Alex Zhu, the head of the of-the-moment video app TikTok, is worried about an image problem. To him - and to millions of TikTok's users - the app is a haven for creativity, earnest self-expression and silly dance videos. In almost no time, TikTok has emerged as the refreshing weirdo upstart of the American social media landscape, reconfiguring the culture in its joyful, strange wake.

But to some people, TikTok is a menace. And one big reason is the nationality of its owner, a seven-year-old Chinese social media company called ByteDance. The fear is that TikTok is smuggling user data to Beijing's servers.

The desire to fix this perception gap is what brought Zhu last week to a WeWork in New York City, where a handful of his colleagues are based. Zhu, a trim 40-year-old who speaks fluent if lightly accented English, helped found Musical.ly, a Shanghai-based lip-syncing app that ByteDance acquired in 2017 and folded into TikTok.

Key accusations

In an interview - his first since taking the reins at TikTok this year - Zhu denied, in unambiguous terms, several key accusations. No, TikTok does not censor videos that displease China, he said. And no, it does not share user data with China, or even with its Beijing-based parent company. All data on TikTok users worldwide is stored in Virginia in the US, he said, with a backup server in Singapore.

But China is a murky place for companies. Even if TikTok's policies are clear on paper, what if Chinese authorities decided they didn't like them and pressured ByteDance? What if China's top leader, Xi Jinping, personally asked Zhu to take down a video or hand over user data?

"I would turn him down," Zhu said, after barely a moment's thought. US officials at this moment are suspicious of Chinese tech companies to a degree that can feel like paranoia. The Trump administration's biggest target has been Huawei, the giant supplier of smartphones and telecommunications equipment. But it has also tried kneecapping Chinese producers of microchips, surveillance gear and supercomputers.

That a video app now finds itself in the same position shows the extent to which any Chinese advancement is seen in Washington as harmful to American interests. Over the last year, TikTok's app has been downloaded more than 750 million times - more than Facebook, Instagram, YouTube and Snapchat, according to the research firm Sensor Tower.

The weapon being wielded against TikTok is the committee on foreign investment in the United States (CFIUS). The secretive federal panel, known as CFIUS, is looking into ByteDance's purchase of Musical.ly. Earlier this year, the committee forced a different Chinese company to relinquish control over the dating app Grindr, which it had bought in 2016. The concern was also that Beijing might gain access to personal information. Zhu said TikTok user data was segregated from the rest of ByteDance, and was not even used to help improve ByteDance's artificial intelligence and other technologies.

"The data of TikTok is only being used by TikTok for TikTok users," he said. It is unclear how such assurances will be received in Washington. "If Instagram or Facebook wanted to be sold to a Chinese firm in some way, I would 100 per cent see the same issues at hand," said Clark Fonda, a former congressional chief of staff and an author of a 2018 law that expanded CFIUS' powers. "It's about the underlying distrust of the Chinese government and what, theoretically, they could do with this data."

In this tense time, Zhu is an unlikely peacemaker. With his long salt-and-pepper hair and light moustache and goatee, he looks more like a poet than a tech founder. He seems to relish a little artsy oddness. On his LinkedIn profile, he describes himself as a "designtrepreneur" and gives his work location as "Mars".

"In the past, my personal focus was always design and user experience," Zhu said. He spent a lot of time thinking about the colours of buttons. Now as TikTok's boss, he reports to ByteDance's 36-year-old founder, Zhang Yiming. Zhu said dealing with TikTok's sudden crisis had been "very interesting", if nothing else. "I am quite optimistic," he said.

Zhu grew up in the landlocked Chinese province of Anhui. After studying civil engineering at Zhejiang University in eastern China, he worked in the United States at SAP, the German software company. As he tells it, the idea for Musical.ly came to him as an epiphany. On a train once from San Francisco to Mountain View, California, he noticed the teenagers around him listening to music, taking selfies and passing their phones around. Why not combine all that into a single app?

Musical.ly debuted in 2014. It quickly attracted tens of millions of monthly users, and Zhu moved to Shanghai. He went to great lengths to learn about the young - sometimes very young - Americans flocking to his platform. He registered fake Musical.ly accounts so he could comment on videos and understand their creators, he said in 2016. Around the same time, ByteDance was storming phone screens in China with a news aggregator called Jinri Toutiao. In 2016, the company released a video app for China named Douyin; TikTok followed soon after. The platforms are similar but separate - TikTok is unavailable in mainland China and vice versa.

In late 2017, Musical.ly agreed to be taken over by ByteDance. Last year, the Musical.ly app was merged into TikTok. Zhu stayed to help with the transition. He then took a few months off last year to rest, go clubbing in Shanghai and listen to jazz. He rejoined TikTok early this year, not long after ByteDance raised funding at a valuation of about $75 billion (EUR 68 billion), making it one of the planet's most richly valued start-ups.

TikTok surely owes some of its success to the sunny, fun-for-its-own-sake vibe it has cultivated. But that has led to suspicions that TikTok suppresses material, such as clips of the Hong Kong protests, that could be a buzzkill. The company says it previously penalised content that "promoted conflict".

Now "we don't take any action on any politically sensitive content as long as it goes along with our community guidelines," said Vanessa Pappas, general manager for TikTok in the United States. Those cover things like hate speech, harassment and misleading information.

Zhu said TikTok, which makes money by selling ads, was still drawing up its content policies. "Today, we are lucky," he said, "because users perceive TikTok as a platform for memes, for lip-syncing, for dancing, for fashion, for animals, but not so much for political discussion." He acknowledged this could change. "For political content that still aligns with this creative and joyful experience, I don't see why we should control it," he said.

Leverage

The deeper concern is that ByteDance's vast business in China could give Beijing leverage over the company, and over TikTok. In its brief existence, ByteDance has had plenty of run-ins with Chinese authorities. This month, regulators hauled up company executives after finding search results from ByteDance's search engine that supposedly defamed a revolutionary hero.

There are other steps ByteDance could take to try to convince western officials of TikTok's independence, such as reorganising TikTok as a separate company with a new board of directors. Zhu said the company wouldn't rule out such possibilities.

But there had been no discussion about selling off TikTok's American business, he said. Harry Clark, a CFIUS specialist at the law firm Orrick, said that was probably what the committee would end up demanding. CFIUS might have entertained other options had the companies applied for a review before doing the deal, Clark said. Now, he said, Washington's concerns about China and data protection are deepening.

"Three years ago, I doubt any CFIUS expert would have said it's crucial that you go to CFIUS here," Clark said. "Now, most would." - New York Times
